summary: Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend by mocking his seven-minute substitute appearance in Tottenham’s 0-0 draw at Burnley on Twitter, after having previously questioned Townsend’s England call-up in his Sky Sports column. Townsend hit back on Twitter, then proved Merson wrong by scoring England’s equaliser in a 1-1 friendly draw with Italy, earning public praise and an admission of error from Merson—only for Merson to resume his barbs following Townsend’s brief outing at Turf Moor.

Chelsea have submitted a formal summer offer, reportedly around £4 million, for 22-year-old Japan international forward Yoshinori Muto from FC Tokyo, with conditions including a season-long loan to Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem; FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane stressed that this interest is unrelated to Chelsea’s five-year, £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber beginning in 2015-16. Muto—who would become Chelsea’s first Japanese player—recently earned an economics degree from Keio University, has made 37 J-League appearances scoring 16 goals since turning professional in 2014, won 11 caps (one goal) for Japan, was named in the league’s Best XI in his debut season and has netted three times in four games this campaign, calling the offer an honour but remaining undecided about a move to Stamford Bridge.

A large-scale Finnish study published in Pediatrics of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds found that children exposed to antibiotics in the first six months of life—or repeatedly before age two—were significantly more likely to be overweight or obese (by age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls), with boys particularly prone to weight gain and slightly taller than unexposed peers; although causation remains unproven, researchers suggest antibiotic-induced disruption of gut bacteria may boost caloric absorption and appetite. The findings highlight a potential contributor to the childhood obesity epidemic, echo previous links between early antibiotic use and eczema or digestive problems, and underscore calls for more judicious prescribing amid broader concerns about antibiotic overuse, resistance, and emerging superbugs.

A young Queen’s Guard slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, sliding sideways, knocking his bearskin into his sentry box and dropping his rifle in front of hundreds of tourists. The tumble was filmed by holidaymaker David Meadwell, who said the guard quickly scrambled to his feet as his colleagues marched on, visibly embarrassed at the gasps from the crowd. Observers believe the slip was due to metal protectors on his boots. The daily 11.30 am ceremony features fully operational soldiers under the Captain of the Queen’s Guard, and the Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E Networks—including A&E, Lifetime and History—will simulcast in 2016 a new, “original” and “contemporary” remake of the 1977 miniseries Roots, drawing more directly on Alex Haley’s Roots: The Saga of an American Family and consulting African and African-American history scholars for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will serve as co-executive producer alongside Mark Wolper, son of the original producer, and History executive Dirk Hoogstra highlights the miniseries’ enduring impact. The reboot aims to introduce Kinte’s story to a generation shaped by Barack Obama’s presidency, the Oscar-winning 12 Years a Slave and ongoing racial unrest, many of whom are unfamiliar with the original series’ significance.

Police are investigating claims by former royal footman Christopher Lawler, who says that on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978 aides tried to force him into an orgy, groping and pinning him to a chair before he escaped and quit immediately; though his initial complaint drew an angry response and went unaddressed for months, he renewed it last year amid inquiries into historical VIP paedophile rings, prompting Scotland Yard to interview a retired royal aide who denies involvement, and the Royal Household has since vowed to cooperate fully with the ongoing investigation.

Oregon couple Jesse and Melissa Meek announced their pregnancy with a parody rap video set to The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air theme, rapping about buying a house, trying to conceive for two months, discovering Melissa’s positive test and ending with a sonogram reveal; the five-take clip has amassed over 1.7 million YouTube views and was made so far-away loved ones could learn the news. According to KPTV and a Fox affiliate, the Meeks were surprised by its viral success and, after finding out the baby’s gender, may film another video. Jesse—great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek—told The Oregonian it’s been more fun and attention than expected. Melissa had earlier captured his reaction in a separate reveal using their dog’s tag, and a similar Fresh Prince–themed announcement was made last year by a Pennsylvania couple.

A slate blue-gray jacket-and-skirt ensemble with a black zigzag appliqué worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in key scenes of the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills, where over 150 film items—among them Leigh’s straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable’s Rhett Butler suit ($55,000) and a bonnet shared by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland ($30,000)—were offered from the private collection of former Universal hair and makeup head James Tumblin, who rescued the dress from disposal in the 1960s for $20 and amassed some 300,000 pieces; the sale, marking the movie’s 75th anniversary, highlights the enduring legacy of Margaret Mitchell’s novel adaptation that starred Leigh and Gable and earned Hattie McDaniel the first Academy Award won by an African-American actor.

A two-year-old boy slipped from his mother’s arms and fell 10–12 feet into the cheetah exhibit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo, was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived, suffered minor bumps, bruises and a leg injury but was not attacked by the animals and is in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center, and zoo officials—citing eyewitness accounts that he had been dangled over the railing—have closed the exhibit and plan to press child endangerment charges.

A decommissioned bright yellow gatso speed camera on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham—switched off along with some 300 outdated fixed cameras across the West Midlands in March 2013—has been mysteriously rotated to face a house’s front door despite no longer working. Birmingham City Council, aware of the incident, will send an engineer to investigate and may remove the device entirely. While mobile units, motorway cameras and patrols now handle speed enforcement regionally, a separate pilot using digital technology is being developed, although this particular camera won’t be part of it.

Six-time Olympic champion Usain Bolt will represent Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2–3, the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association announced, with Bolt stating he is fit, healthy and eager to uphold Jamaica’s long relay tradition and make his country proud; JAAA general secretary Garth Gayle praised the world’s fastest man and promised “sprint magic,” adding that the full Jamaican squad will be revealed soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves demonstrated their dedication to Barcelona by attending Thursday’s EuroLeague basketball El Clásico against Real Madrid—with Barça winning 85-80, though Real still top the group on point difference—accompanied by Neymar’s sister Rafaella. Earlier Neymar had netted the winner in Brazil’s 1-0 victory over Chile at the Emirates, enduring tough challenges, and before the international break Luis Enrique’s football side had beaten Real in their own El Clásico to move four points clear atop La Liga. They now return to league action against Celta Vigo as they pursue a treble of trophies.

Italy’s coast guard rescued 8,480 migrants from Friday to Monday, responding on Monday alone to SOS calls from 20 vessels; Save the Children fears about 400 people may be missing after survivors reported a 550-person ship capsized 80 miles off Libya, though the coast guard—after extensive sea and air searches—found no survivors, bodies or wreckage. The International Organization for Migration says over 10,000 migrants reached Italy in the first quarter of 2015 and about 2,000 were rescued in the Sicilian Channel during the first weekend of April. Most migrants originate from West Africa, Somalia and Syria and use Libya as a transit point, and at least 480 have died this year due to bad weather, overcrowded smuggler boats and crew abandonment.

Arsène Wenger says he cannot pinpoint why Alexis Sánchez opted for Arsenal instead of Liverpool when Barcelona allowed him to leave, but he’s pleased the Chilean forward—who has scored 19 goals this season—joined his side under Wenger’s guidance and made an immediate impact in English football. The Arsenal boss acknowledges that Liverpool’s interest may have bolstered their negotiating position in Barcelona’s bid for Luis Suárez last summer, praises Sánchez’s work-rate, efficiency and ability to galvanize the team, and, ahead of Saturday’s Premier League clash, downplays transfer links with Liverpool’s Raheem Sterling while commending Brendan Rodgers for maintaining high standards following Suarez’s departure and Daniel Sturridge’s injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, the four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling’s UCI Hour Record on June 7 at London’s Olympic Velodrome, aiming to better the 52.491 km set by Australia’s Rohan Dennis in February. Fresh from concluding his Team Sky career with Paris-Roubaix and lined up to ride the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire for his eponymous team, the 35-year-old hopes to inspire riders as he returns to the track. Following recent bids by Jens Voigt, Matthias Brändle and Jack Bobridge and ahead of fellow Briton Alex Dowsett’s May 2 Manchester attempt, Wiggins’s one-hour ride will be staged before up to 6,000 spectators and broadcast live on Sky Sports. General public tickets (£49/£39/£29) go on sale via Sky Tickets from April 19.

Serena Williams admitted she was underprepared for the clay season after struggling through a three-set singles win over Sara Errani in Sunday’s Fed Cup play-off—4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3—but her flawless record with the US team was blemished when she and Alison Riske were beaten 6-0, 6-3 in the decisive doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, handing Italy a 3-2 victory and relegating America to World Group II; captain Mary Joe Fernandez said the squad must work harder to regain elite status next year.

River Plate have reignited their interest in 29-year-old Radamel Falcao, who spent eight years at the club—joining as a 15-year-old in 2001, debuting four years later and scoring 34 goals in 90 Primera División appearances—before departing for Porto in 2009. Vice-president Matias Patanian admits “we dream of Falcao Garcia” and that “the doors are open,” but any move is complicated by his season-long loan at Manchester United, where he has managed just four Premier League goals and faces an uncertain future as United weigh their purchase option against a return to parent club Monaco. Despite his club struggles, Falcao has struck three times in two recent internationals, equaling Colombia’s all-time scoring record on 24 goals.

X Factor finalist Ella Henderson has been unveiled as the face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” dry shampoo campaign—her first ever brand partnership—starring in vibrant city‐scape images that showcase her long hair in styles ranging from glossy waves to a tousled half-pony. Developed with the MILES agency, the international push includes TV spots set to her single “Mirror Man,” and reflects Henderson’s genuine enthusiasm for a product she already uses regularly, a move praised by her management as a natural fit between the platinum artist and the UK’s leading dry shampoo brand.

A billboard thanking the community for its support, featuring Officer Pablo Torres and his dog, was erected in Kenosha by the local Professional Police Association after Torres fatally shot 26-year-old Aaron Siler on March 14 during a vehicle and foot pursuit in which Siler, wanted on a felony probation and parole warrant, “armed himself with a weapon”; Siler’s family and friends, including Kathy Willie, denounce the billboard as “disrespectful” and demand its removal, while Torres—who is on leave—awaits the outcome of a state Division of Criminal Investigation probe into Siler’s death; ten days earlier, Torres had also wounded 66-year-old Terry Knight in a separate shooting that a prosecutor later deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards and three militants were killed Monday near Negur in Sistan-Baluchestan province after militants crossed in from Pakistan, Iranian state media IRNA reported, citing Deputy Governor Ali Asghar Mirshekari. The Sunni group Jaish al Adal, active in Pakistani Balochistan to target Shiites and counter Iranian influence, claimed responsibility and had previously claimed a 2013 attack that killed 14 guards. Iranian authorities urged Pakistan to apprehend surviving fighters, and Pakistan condemned the incident as terrorism, said its security agencies are investigating, requested evidence from Iran, and vowed to bring any perpetrators to justice if they return to Pakistani territory.

Echoing the 1970s video game “Space Invaders,” Japan’s parliament recently tackled the prospect of real-life extraterrestrial intruders when flamboyant former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki asked Defence Minister Gen Nakatani if the Air Self-Defense Force had ever scrambled jets against UFOs; Nakatani replied that while fighters are dispatched to visually inspect unidentified objects—often birds or debris—there is no record of any extraterrestrial craft, a line of questioning that follows earlier musings by ex-Defence Minister Shigeru Ishiba on the constitutional issues of defending against a space invasion.

At Hefei Xinqiao International Airport, 35-year-old Jin Pai stood on the rim of a toilet—afraid the seat wasn’t clean—when it collapsed and shattered, cutting his leg and buttocks so badly that he needed dozens of stitches. Too embarrassed to shout, he phoned his traveling companions for help before emergency personnel rushed him to a local hospital. He initially admitted to friends that he was squatting but later told police he had been sitting, apparently to avoid paying compensation, and authorities confirmed it was an accident, warning that airport toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera under her bathroom sink, leading investigators to uncover that he allegedly molested her from ages nine to 13, filmed her and other minors over a three- to four-year period—recovering 41 videos (34 showing victims showering, some with close-up images of children’s genitalia)—and stored them on his computer; he now faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy, is being held on $500,000 bail, and has a preliminary hearing set for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s latest series, featured in a book whose title roughly translates as Daughter and Salaryman, pairs po-faced teenage daughters in casual clothes with sharply suited fathers mid-jump against various Japanese landmarks; the images capture the usually serious “salaryman” dads striking energetic, sometimes pained or playful poses—one even flashing a peace sign—as their daughters smile at the camera, and the curious, oddball portraits have already generated substantial online interest.

Paul Downton’s dismissal as England managing director has rekindled talk of Kevin Pietersen’s international future just as the county championship season begins. Pietersen, controversially dropped in 2014 and last seen in England’s whitewash Ashes tour of Australia in 2013–14, joined Surrey once more and posed for a team photo at The Kia Oval with a blend of introspection and good humour. With Surrey opening their campaign against Glamorgan on April 19 (after an MCCU match with Oxford), Pietersen aims to press his case for a sensational return to the England Test side.

Relegation-threatened Ceahlăul Piatra Neamț have dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week after a 2–0 loss to mid-table FC Botoșani left them 16th and six points from safety; the 41-year-old former Inter Milan and Parma right back—capped 25 times by Brazil—was first sacked on Wednesday following a poor run, reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone, then removed again, ending his January appointment as the club’s third coach of the season, and will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinović.

Radamel Falcao’s season-long loan to Manchester United has fallen short of expectations—he’s scored just four goals as he continues to recover from a serious knee injury, and United are unlikely to pay the £46 million needed to sign him permanently. His former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao must regret the move, arguing that despite not feeling happy in France he would have played regularly and featured in the Champions League had he stayed at Monaco.

New Zealand police are appealing for help to identify a very tall man who, wearing a distinctive oversized cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt, robbed the Union St dairy in east Christchurch on Saturday at about 12:30 pm. Security footage shows him demanding cash from the owner’s daughter, then throwing the register to the ground and fleeing with the till drawer and about $1,500 in cash. No weapons were seen, but the family said previous robberies only targeted cigarettes and were less intimidating. Anyone with information is asked to contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, 24, a math teacher at Irving’s MacArthur High School in Texas, was first arrested on March 19 after admitting in a police interview that she kissed and let a 15-year-old student touch her breasts; released on bail, she was suspended and placed on administrative leave. Investigators then questioned a second 15-year-old who alleged she had sex with him in her car on consecutive nights in January, leading to her second arrest on Monday. Booked into the Irving County Jail, Granado posted $50,000 bail and remains barred from school property as she faces the new charges.

A holidaymaker in Puerto Vallarta, New Zealander Tim Weston, filmed a large American crocodile calmly swimming through the marina with a dead black dog wearing a red collar—owned by the local bike shop proprietor—clamped in its jaws for hours; the clip, shared via the Bogged Facebook page, has been viewed over 500,000 times and elicited horror comments such as “horrible” and “I hate crocodiles now.” Weston explained the marina lies just 200 meters downstream of a crocodile sanctuary, and noted that by the next morning neither the croc nor the dog remained; such encounters are not unusual, as six-meter crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta’s mangroves and golf courses, increasingly venturing into human areas due to urbanization.

Steve Bruce insists Hull City can still avoid Premier League relegation after a 2-0 loss at Southampton left them two points above the drop zone; despite a strong start they’ve secured just six of the ten wins Bruce initially targeted and now hope eight or nine may suffice from their remaining six fixtures—including matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. Hull dominated the first half at St Mary’s but were undone by a James Ward-Prowse penalty and a late Graziano Pelle goal, and Bruce cites long-term absences of Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic and Robert Snodgrass for their struggles. Southampton climbed to fifth, though manager Ronald Koeman had to remind Sadio Mane of team rules after Mane attempted to take Prowse’s spot-kick.

Ian Guffick, a 31-year-old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after a local authority investigation found he asked pupils to alter their SATs exam answers—and made changes himself—outside exam conditions, leading the Department for Education to annul all the school’s 2014 test results. Although Guffick claimed he only sought to improve legibility, a conduct panel deemed his actions dishonest but not fraudulent; he admitted unacceptable professional conduct, expressed remorse and has the right to appeal.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United’s third-choice goalkeeper since joining from Aalesund in 2010, has made just 19 Premier League appearances over five seasons and now finds himself behind David de Gea and Víctor Valdés in the pecking order. Off the pitch, he has enjoyed happier times with his stunning Swedish model wife Misse Beqiri—whom he has dated since 2012, married in a romantic beach ceremony in Mauritius last year, and shares a son with—and has been showcasing their sunshine-filled days on Instagram, where Beqiri, of Albanian descent, regularly posts her modelling photos. Although linked with a January move to FC Midtjylland, no deal was agreed, leaving Lindegaard hopeful of brighter prospects professionally even as his personal life thrives.

Thirteen 10-foot-tall glowing blue letters that hung above Yankee Stadium from 1976 until its 2008 closing, now owned by Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, failed to sell at Sotheby’s despite estimates of $300,000–$600,000 when the only bid of $260,000 came from a Sotheby’s employee; Jackson, who bought the letters after the stadium’s final game, attended the auction and pledged to visit any U.S. buyer, while a late-1960s New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000–$30,000, realized $112,500.

Brendan Rodgers privately reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe of their professional responsibilities after pictures surfaced of Sterling inhaling nitrous oxide and both players smoking shisha, meeting them without imposing formal discipline and drawing a line under the matter. With Daniel Sturridge injured, Sterling is set to lead Liverpool’s attack in Sunday’s FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, and Steven Gerrard returns from a three-match suspension though Rodgers has not yet confirmed his lineup. Rodgers stressed that elite athletes must be mindful of how their actions are perceived and that setbacks—from title races to cup semi-final losses—are part of the journey toward future success.

After returning to London from the international break, Arsenal midfielder Mesut Özil shared a photo relaxing with his dog and is now focused on Saturday’s Premier League clash with Liverpool. He starred as Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier, and although he missed Arsenal’s win over Newcastle through illness—and denied nightclub rumours—he’s expected to start at the Emirates. Signed for £42.5 million from Real Madrid in 2013, Özil has provided four assists and scored three goals since January and says he thrives on the demands of English football’s busy schedule.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu insists the club has no plans to replace Luis Enrique, who signed a two-year deal last summer and remains six games from clinching La Liga and still in contention for three trophies; Bartomeu praised Enrique’s work preparing the team—citing his efforts after the Champions League trip to Paris—and highlighted Barcelona’s recent 2-0 victory over Valencia courtesy of goals from Luis Suárez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term Liverpool contract until the summer of 2020 worth around £100,000 a week, despite having 14 months left on his previous deal, after talks that began earlier this season. The 24-year-old England midfielder, signed from Sunderland in 2011 for £16 million, becomes the third senior player to extend under Brendan Rodgers, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, and has contributed 13 assists and seven goals this season. He is being tipped to succeed Steven Gerrard as club captain, while Raheem Sterling’s contract talks are on hold until the end of the season amid CEO Ian Ayre’s expectation that Sterling will remain at Anfield long term.

Filipe Luis, who signed a three-year deal with Chelsea last July after leaving Atletico Madrid, insists he intends to remain at Stamford Bridge until his contract ends despite Atletico’s interest in re-signing him this summer. Having struggled to secure the left-back spot, he says he’s happy at Chelsea and is now focused on the Premier League run-in after featuring for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile. Manager Jose Mourinho continues to demand full concentration and maximum effort as Chelsea face nine difficult games en route to the title.

Wasps No. 8 Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban for accidentally knocking out Wales and Lions winger George North overturned on appeal after an independent panel, led by Jeremy Summers, reviewed fresh evidence and ruled his red-card-earning knee collision on March 27 was accidental. Hughes had been sent off and suspended for “reckless” foul play as he scored for Northampton, causing North—unconscious on the pitch for the third time in two months—to be stretchered off and advised to rest for at least a month. The original sanction, which forced Hughes to miss Wasps’ Champions Cup quarter-final against Toulon, was widely condemned as a “joke” by figures such as James Haskell, Andy Goode, Austin Healey and Joe Marler; with the ban quashed, Hughes is free to return to action once selected.

A Seattle native’s photos of a fiery red sunset over the city were traced to smoke from grass fires in southeastern Siberia that farmers ignited and which, driven by strong winds on April 14, grew out of control and destroyed dozens of villages; although rescue crews eventually extinguished the blazes, lingering smoke rode atmospheric winds across the Pacific to Oregon, Washington and British Columbia, where its particles filtered out shorter-wavelength light and left only reds and oranges visible at sunrise and sunset—a phenomenon that will fade as the smoke clears and air quality improves.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis discovered her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway just over a month after purchase, then learned on April 1 that police had recovered it thanks to a tip from Mick Sexton—but not before the thieves spray-painted the rims red, added red side detailing and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of complaining, she posted on Facebook jokingly thanking the thieves for “pimping out” her ride (a post many mistook for an April Fool’s prank), and she’s now having the car professionally cleaned to remove cigarette and marijuana odors. To honor Sexton, she’s also created a “Sexton on Wheels” smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, featuring banana, pineapple, peach and coconut cream.

Manchester City’s star players—including Sergio Aguero, Yaya Touré, David Silva and Joe Hart—are on incentive-based contracts under financial fair play that award £500,000 apiece if they qualify for the Champions League group stage, with the squad set to miss out on about £12 million if they finish outside the top four. Currently fourth in the Premier League, City have slipped in form—suffering seven defeats since early 2015, including a derby loss to Manchester United and early FA Cup and Champions League exits—leading Manuel Pellegrini to admit their season has “disintegrated.” With matches against West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, QPR, Swansea and Southampton to come, City must tighten up to secure automatic top-three qualification or navigate a play-off round, all while competing in the transfer market for talents such as Paul Pogba amid interest from United, whose manager Louis van Gaal remains confident of attracting new signings.

At Altrincham’s Moss Lane, Manchester United’s Under-18s beat City 1-0 in a ‘mini-derby’ decided by Callum Gribbin’s curling free-kick after he drew a foul on the edge of the box. With 13 of 22 players English (10 Mancunians) and free entry for around 1,000 spectators, United coach Paul McGuinness mirrored the senior side’s three-at-the-back formation. City’s Marcus Wood flirted with a chip, Marcus Rashford missed two chances for United, and Cameron Borthwick-Jackson rattled the bar, while Javairo Dilrosun’s stoppage-time free-kick struck the roof of the net. The win put United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, whereas an injury-ravaged City suffered defeats in both playoff matches.

England and Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a “legend of the game” after Buffon earned his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw with England, saying he continues to learn from the 37-year-old’s example. Hart, who reached his own milestone of 50 England caps in that match at the Juventus Stadium, called it a proud moment but insisted he has “a lot more learning to do” and aims to keep playing well for club and country to increase his tally.

Chipotle is tapping into the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with Postmates to deliver online and mobile orders in 67 cities, adding a nine percent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5 based on distance and demand, after previously declining third-party delivery offers; the chain uses Postmates’ independent contractor drivers, has recently attracted high-profile patrons such as presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton, and joins rivals—including Starbucks, which will deliver coffee in Seattle and New York, Taco Bell, McDonald’s and Burger King—in rolling out or testing delivery services.

Bill and Denise Richard, whose 8-year-old son Martin was the youngest victim killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings that also claimed two others and injured more than 200, have penned a front-page Boston Globe opinion urging the Justice Department to withdraw the death penalty for convicted bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev in exchange for life in prison without parole and a waiver of appeals. They recount their family’s enduring grief, their daughter Jane’s severe injuries and surgeries, and the trauma of witnessing graphic evidence in court, acknowledging the “heinousness and brutality” of the crime. Stressing that they speak only for themselves, the Richards argue that avoiding years of appeals would spare their two surviving children from prolonging the painful memory and allow their family, Boston and the nation to turn the page.

A mystery billionaire has transformed a custom-built Boeing 747-8 into a £400 million flying luxury home, replacing its normal 600-seat layout with a multi-level interior that includes a master bedroom suite, an “aeroloft” top deck with eight full beds, multiple lounges and state rooms, a dining room adjacent to a private chef’s kitchen, a conference room for meetings, and hotel-style décor throughout, allowing the owner to entertain dozens of guests in unmatched airborne opulence.

SpaceX on Tuesday launched a two-stage Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo ship to the International Space Station, successfully sending Dragon—loaded with over 4,300 lb (1,950 kg) of supplies, research equipment and an ISSpresso coffee maker—on its sixth mission to the station, though its attempt to land the first-stage booster on a floating droneship failed when the rocket tipped over on touchdown. Elon Musk said that mastering reusable rockets could cut space access costs by up to 100-fold; SpaceX will continue sea-landing trials before aiming for ground recovery. After Dragon docks in a few days, the crew will unload it over about five weeks, then pack it with more than 3,000 lb of experiments and waste for a guided splashdown off California. This flight, the first private docking contractor to reach the ISS, was the second launch attempt after Monday’s weather scrub.

Priscilla Presley is teaming with NBC’s Today show to host a contest granting one Elvis-obsessed couple an “ultimate wedding” at the newly unveiled Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel—formerly the Las Vegas Hilton where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows. The winners, announced next Monday, will marry on April 23 with Priscilla serving as witness, enjoy a complimentary reception, a two-night hotel suite stay, airfare, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show, all in a first-class, impersonator-free ceremony that’s part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Entrants must submit a video or photos and explain why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool’s vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes they can close the four-point gap on a faltering Manchester City—fresh from a 4-2 defeat at Manchester United—after a 2-0 win over Newcastle United. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet each notched their 47th appearance of the season, equalling the top-five European leagues’ record. Raheem Sterling scored in the ninth minute and Joe Allen added his first Anfield goal late on, despite Newcastle’s strong penalty appeal, to bounce back from poor results against United and Arsenal.

Roma ended a seven‐match home win drought and a four‐month winless run by defeating Napoli 1–0 in Serie A at the Stadio Olimpico, Miralem Pjanic netting in the 25th minute after a swift counter–attack set up by Juan Iturbe and Alessandro Florenzi, while veteran goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis produced a series of second–half saves to preserve the clean sheet. The victory moved Roma provisionally into second place, four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, as Napoli extended their own winless streak to five games and remained fifth. Tight security measures, including banning Campania residents from tickets and deploying 1,000 police, accompanied the match—the first visit by Napoli since a fan’s shooting death before last season’s Coppa Italia final—while Roma coped without injured captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho, and Napoli saw the late return of Lorenzo Insigne from knee surgery.

Doncaster Rovers’ uninspiring League One season continued with a goalless draw against already eliminated Fleetwood Town at the Keepmoat Stadium, leaving both sets of fans underwhelmed. Faced with virtually no action, the club’s media team boiled the highlights down to a 27-second YouTube clip featuring just 14 seconds of footage—a kickoff, a goal kick and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux films himself reaching into his aquarium to gently cup and massage his blood parrot cichlid, which initially moves away but then swims back to relax in his hand, even circling his fingers and swimming up his arm, burying its face in his palm and following his hand to the surface when play ends; after removing two tank mates that bullied the fish, he began hand‐feeding it frozen blood worms and discovered it became sociable and frustrated if he missed daily sessions, which he now sustains for at least 15 minutes each day, and the blood parrot cichlid—a hybrid of midas and redhead cichlids first bred in Taiwan around 1986—appears to genuinely enjoy the interaction.

Ben Stokes, famed for his fiery temperament—from punching a locker after a dismissal at the Kensington Oval to clashing with Marlon Samuels—has fought back into England’s side but needs careful man-management to channel his aggression into runs and wickets. Coach Peter Moores stepped in after the Samuels incident to steer Stokes towards a more controlled response, which paid off in Barbados, and selectors are keen to balance his exuberance with occasional restraint rather than stifle it. England also aim to develop both Stokes and Chris Jordan alongside spinners like Adil Rashid, believing their natural flair and competitive edge make them exciting prospects whose highs and lows are worth nurturing.

Wales’ June 12 Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium at the 33,000-seat Cardiff City Stadium has sold out after a surge of demand following their 3-0 win over Israel—propelled by Gareth Bale’s superb free-kick—which left both Group B leaders level on 11 points (Belgium ahead on goal difference) and Wales in their best qualification position since the 1958 World Cup; despite speculation about moving to the 74,500-capacity Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules forbade a venue change within 120 days, and the team favor the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium, where they last played in March 2011.

John Peacock has named an 18-man England Under-17 squad for next month’s UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria: goalkeepers Paul Woolston and Will Huffer; defenders Danny Collinge, Reece Oxford, Easah Suliman, James Yates, Jay DaSilva and Tayo Edun; midfielders Trent Arnold, Daniel Wright, Herbie Kane, Tom Davies, Marcus Edwards, Nathan Holland and Chris Willock; and forwards Layton Ndukwu, Stephy Mavididi and Ike Ugbo. The Young Lions, who beat Holland on penalties in last year’s final and qualified with a 100 per cent record—including wins over Romania, Norway and Slovenia—have been drawn in Group D alongside Italy, Holland and the Republic of Ireland, opening their campaign against Italy in Burgas on May 7 before facing Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. Chelsea’s DaSilva and Ugbo, Arsenal’s Willock and Mavididi earn first call-ups, while Liverpool pair Kane and Arnold return after missing the Elite Round.

Manchester City are pursuing a deal for Anderlecht’s 14-year-old playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, considered one of the Belgian club’s brightest prospects and courted by Arsenal and Barcelona; having previously declined a move to Barcelona’s La Masia at 12 to focus on his education, he has continued to impress, prompting City and manager Manuel Pellegrini to open talks with chairman Roger Vanden Stock over a compensation package to secure the youngster’s signature.

A 23-year-old man has been arrested and bailed in connection with the late-March killing of 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort Vanessa Santillan, whose beaten and strangled body was found on March 28 at around 9.30 pm in her £400,000 flat in Fulham after London Ambulance Service was called; Santillan, who had moved from Mexico and advertised escort work in London, Paris and Miami, had used social media to profess her love for London and describe herself as visiting from Miami in search of “upscale gentlemen,” and Scotland Yard, led by Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves, is appealing for anyone who saw or had contact with her in the hours before her death to come forward.

Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages and buried her son Daniel James, went on The Jeremy Kyle Show after discovering that the £207 she and her partner had saved toward a £500 gravestone had vanished; she accused her housemate Jamie (and his girlfriend Carol) of taking the money, and when a lie-detector test proved Jamie was lying—and he later admitted via Facebook message—she broke down in tears, feeling betrayed at losing the funds meant to honor her child.

ISIS on Wednesday freed more than 200 Yazidi captives—most of them women and children or the ill and elderly—with Arab tribal leaders helping to coordinate the operation and Peshmerga forces receiving the 217–228 released individuals in Irbil. Last summer, ISIS overran northern Iraqi Yazidi towns such as Sinjar, killing hundreds, displacing up to half a million Yazidis (under 1% of Iraq’s population), and subjecting women to rape and enslavement. The Yazidis, a centuries-old, Kurdish-derived minority with a pre-Islamic faith drawing on Christianity, Judaism and Zoroastrianism, have long faced persecution as “devil worshipers.” In response, an international coalition airdropped supplies to stranded Yazidis, carried out rescues in the mountains, and since August has conducted U.S.-led airstrikes against ISIS in Iraq and Syria.

Tottenham and England forward Harry Kane, whose animated celebrations and goal-scoring prowess have marked a breakthrough season, has been nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards; a new Copa90 animation titled “Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?” stitches together still images of his standout moments—including his 20th Premier League goal past Tim Krul, a long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal versus Arsenal and his goal on England debut—and has been released ahead of Sunday’s ceremony, where he faces off against the likes of Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher, speaking after receiving a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, insisted Brendan Rodgers remains the right man to lead Liverpool despite a third straight trophyless season and the club looking set to finish outside the top four, arguing that one bad game shouldn’t define his future and that recent signings have not yet fully settled. With Liverpool seven points behind fourth‐placed Manchester City and knocked out of the FA Cup in the semi‐final, Carragher said Rodgers, his staff and the squad will target both a trophy and a top‐four finish next season, stressing that the right new arrivals could make all the difference. Carragher, who has coached in eight deprived schools through his 23 Foundation, added that he hopes his Beacon Award will help inspire and support underprivileged youths in Bootle and the wider Merseyside community.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his brightly coloured plastic nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after it appeared on the X-ray scanner, prompting security officers to frisk him and deem the toy a security risk. His father Phil, a software engineer, criticized the “over-zealous” checks as ludicrous but, pressed for time before their flight to Lanzarote, the family left the gun behind and went on a 10-day Easter holiday. Upon their return they bought James a replacement off eBay, while East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience, offered to post the toy back to their Doncaster home and defended its decision by citing government-set hand luggage rules that prohibit items resembling replica or model guns.

In Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, 31-year-old “Rich” posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife who loves pets, doesn’t drink or smoke, is fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house and in bed, enjoys the outdoors yet can be “a princess” when needed, and he offered accommodation, a company car, phone, laptop, gym membership and generous spending; he described himself as an athletic, heavily tattooed, brown-haired, brown-eyed, 175 cm-tall property owner—“well endowed,” abstinent from alcohol, cigarettes and drugs, financially successful and outdoors-minded—and stipulated that former partners need not apply, while Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact him.

FA chairman Greg Dyke is backed by five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Göran Eriksson and Steve McClaren—in calling for club squads to raise their home-grown quota from eight to twelve and to tighten the definition so that a player must have trained in England for three years before turning 18 rather than 21. They argue that only 36.8 percent of recent Premier League starters are eligible for England, that the top-level talent pool is shrinking, and that rejecting these reforms will hamper England’s World Cup prospects. Despite solid Euro 2016 qualifying results and the emergence of youngsters like Barkley, Sterling and Kane, the former managers insist those players lack the opportunities they need without the proposed rule changes and urge swift adoption to keep England competitive.

Tomorrow night’s Poldark sees Eleanor Tomlinson’s Demelza, only announced as pregnant last week, jump from eight months’ gestation to giving birth to her and Aidan Turner’s Ross Poldark’s daughter within minutes, a rapid timeline that has prompted viewers—who continue to swoon over the brooding Cornish hero, now happily off the market—to mock on Twitter how pregnancies in the series reach full term almost instantly, recalling a similar blink-and-you-miss-it birth of Elizabeth in an earlier episode.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his side to keep calm and concentrate solely on their own performances as they prepare to host Swansea on Saturday, three points from safety at the foot of the Barclays Premier League after back-to-back victories—most recently Jamie Vardy’s injury-time winner against West Bromwich Albion. Despite handing themselves a realistic chance of survival, Pearson warned against obsessing over rivals’ form or predictions, insisting that only by focusing on their own results in the run-in can they change perceptions and secure safety.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara swam nearly 14,000 miles from her feeding grounds off Russia’s Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico—surpassing the previous 10,190-mile humpback whale migration record—and in doing so she visited three major eastern gray whale breeding areas, suggesting she is an eastern rather than an endangered western gray whale; this finding, led by Oregon State University scientists, raises questions about gray whale population genetics and the true number of western gray whales, long thought to number around 150.

On Hokkaido’s Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, roughly 1,000–1,640 ft of seabed some 100 ft wide unexpectedly rose 30–50 ft above sea level overnight, exposing ocean floor still covered in seaweed and sea urchins. An aerial survey by local researcher Yoshinori Yajima found that melting ice and snow had triggered a nearby landslide, causing a block of land to drop and pivot the seabed skyward. Residents reported no sounds or tremors when the ridge appeared, and officials from the Hokkaido Regional Development Bureau say it’s not earthquake-related, expect no further expansion, and see no connection to last weekend’s 7.8 magnitude Nepal quake.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied he will leave Paris Saint-Germain this summer, insisting he loves the club, city and teammates and is happy to extend his stay despite a recent spat with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Champions League match against Chelsea; he told L’Equipe there’s no reason to leave, he wants a new contract and is ready to play whenever called upon, though PSG’s reported interest in Barcelona’s Dani Alves could yet force his departure.

Carlos Tevez, whose contract with Juventus runs until mid-2016, has informed the Serie A champions he wants to terminate his deal this summer to rejoin his boyhood club Boca Juniors. Boca president Daniel Angelici says the transfer is close to completion once Tevez formally ends his Juve contract. Despite being Juventus’s top scorer with 17 league goals and on course for a second Serie A title and European success, the club has accepted his desire to leave and begun identifying replacements. Tevez, who first joined Boca’s youth academy in 1996 and scored 26 goals in 76 league appearances before moving abroad in 2005, has always intended to finish his career in Argentina, and national team manager Tata Martino maintains that a move to Boca would not harm his international prospects.

Bayern Munich overturned Porto’s two-goal first-leg lead in spectacular fashion at the Allianz Arena, racing into a 5-0 halftime advantage en route to a 6-1 victory that booked their Champions League semi-final place thanks to strikes from Thiago Alcântara, Jérôme Boateng, Thomas Müller, Xabi Alonso and a brace from Robert Lewandowski, while manager Pep Guardiola, caught up in the excitement, tore the left leg of his grey trousers—briefly exposing his underwear—and joked he’d have to buy a new pair for the next match.

Ten people, including four children, were caught in a three-vehicle collision on the Brisbane Valley Highway two kilometres south of Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon; a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain were airlifted by Rescue 500 helicopter to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain, while six others—among them an infant, two young girls and a man with hand lacerations—were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment after Queensland Fire and Rescue crews used hydraulic cutting gear to free a trapped motorist, and the highway remained closed for several hours with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

Arsenal, ten points adrift of Premier League leaders Chelsea with six games remaining, will host their rivals this Sunday, and midfielder Mesut Özil—who has scored four times in 25 appearances—has marked the occasion by buying an Apple Watch (priced between £299 and £13,500) and comparing it to Michael Knight’s gadget on Instagram ahead of its launch. Meanwhile, Jack Wilshere returned from a five-month layoff to take a place on the bench in Arsenal’s FA Cup semi-final win over Reading, and club legend Ray Parlour believes the 23-year-old could become the midfield’s long-term linchpin if he can stay injury-free.

Mark Clattenburg, despite a history of controversy and accusations of favouring Manchester United, has been appointed to referee Sunday’s derby at Old Trafford; the 40-year-old has issued only two Premier League red cards this season—both to United players Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw—and also sent off City captain Vincent Kompany in an international qualifier, earning Kompany a suspension. Widely regarded alongside Michael Oliver as one of the league’s leading officials, Clattenburg will be joined by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official. The fixture, which could decide who finishes runner-up to title-bound Chelsea, sees United one point above a struggling City as they bid for a fifth consecutive league win.

Federal MP Bob Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, accused the Queensland Government of assuming Billy Gordon would resign his seat after allegations of domestic violence and the revelation of his criminal history, branding the Government’s stance a belief that Gordon was “a little black puppet on a string.” Gordon quit the Labor Party to sit as an independent, jeopardizing the Government’s slim majority, and Katter, citing his own experience with racism, questioned why no such expectation was placed on other federal MPs in similar situations. The remark sparked criticism on social media for its phrasing, prompting Katter to defend his language as a deliberate call-out of racial attitudes and to assert that Gordon, unlike past independents Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott, would not become a government puppet.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy and, despite facing bullying and stares, now creates enthusiastic dance videos—one set to Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off”—to challenge stereotypes and show that she’s “pretty much just the same as everyone else.” Having been told she might never walk, she drives, attends college and dances, and she’s begun doing motivational speaking at Chicago-area schools to turn any negativity about her disability into something positive and inspire others to look past her cerebral palsy rather than define her by it.

Orlando City have shown interest in signing Manchester United forward Javier Hernandez, whose loan spell at Real Madrid has been underwhelming, seeing him attract attention from eight European clubs—including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio and Inter Milan—and United are willing to sell the 26-year-old, who has one year left on his contract, for around £8 million; meanwhile, United have presented a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfield prospect Andreas Pereira after his rejection of their initial terms, with PSG, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven and Feyenoord all expressing interest in the teenager.

Around 12:15 a.m. on a Saturday at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles, at least three suspects tried to carjack a man pumping gas in his white Dodge Charger, then doused the vehicle in gasoline and set it ablaze while two passengers rode inside; no one was injured but the car’s front end was destroyed, and the Los Angeles County Fire Department is treating the case as arson using surveillance footage as the perpetrators remain at large.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor in Lamoni, southern Iowa, surrendered his state license after the Iowa Board of Chiropractic found he accepted sex as payment, performed exorcisms on patients and urged them to stop prescribed medications. Under a settlement he admitted these misdeeds, agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove the misconduct has ended before any return. Despite the allegations, Manuel maintains a perfect five-star patient satisfaction rating on HealthGrades.com from three surveys. His practice’s address on Yelp points to a residential street in the small agricultural town, and those contacted by the Des Moines Register declined to comment.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, prompting U.S. officials to protest what they called unsafe, unprofessional high-speed maneuvers in close proximity to their aircraft. Russia, via state news agency Sputnik and Defense Ministry spokesman Maj. Gen. Igor Konashenkov, countered that the U.S. plane—allegedly flying toward the Russian border with its transponder off—was circled to identify it and record its tail number, a claim the U.S. European Command denies. The Pentagon and State Department will lodge a diplomatic protest. Last year’s similarly hazardous close pass by a Russian jet within 100 feet of a RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk underscores the frequency of such encounters between Russian and U.S. reconnaissance aircraft in regions from Northern Europe to the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent’s hard-case sniper rifle, padlocked and chained inside his vehicle, was stolen overnight on March 27 from the Marriott SpringHill Suites parking lot in Salt Lake City—just days before President Obama’s visit to the state—when a thief smashed the rear right passenger window, tied a rope around the case, and used another vehicle’s momentum to rip it free. Investigators found skid marks, rope fragments and the broken case handle at the scene; the agent’s gear bag, backpack, clothing and tools were also taken, though some personal items were later recovered at a nearby Residence Inn. The hotel, adjacent to the city’s airport and FBI office, had no surveillance cameras. The rifle remains missing, its serial number entered into the National Crime Information Center, and while the Secret Service was informed before the presidential trip, any security changes have not been disclosed.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of brutally killing his neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 at his home on Mugga Way in Red Hill, Canberra, allegedly stomping on his head, cutting his throat and stabbing him multiple times in the dining room. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen told the jury Costa showed evidence of declining mental function from dementia compounded by alcohol both before and during the offence, citing fluctuating moods in his triple-zero calls and a trail of faeces to the toilet as signs of confusion, and argued he could not understand his actions or their long-term consequences. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa feigned memory loss during Mullen’s interview—a claim the psychiatrist denied—insisting it was more probable Costa had been suffering a dementing illness for weeks, months or even years before the attack. Costa’s mental state at the time is central to the case, as a finding of an unstable mindset could lead to a not-guilty verdict.

Everton boss Roberto Martinez defended his decision to allow Ross Barkley – rather than established spot-kick specialist Leighton Baines (15/16 in the Premier League) – to take a 10th-minute penalty against Burnley at Goodison Park, which Barkley struck well but saw saved by Tom Heaton; Martinez explained he prefers having multiple confident takers and lets the moment decide, praising Barkley’s sense of responsibility and noting Baines was happy to defer, and, despite the miss, Kevin Mirallas’s 29th-minute goal secured a 1-0 win.

Holland America Line reported that cleaning staff discovered two guests dead in their stateroom aboard the ms Ryndam at 11:30 a.m. Thursday in San Juan, Puerto Rico, in what appears to be a murder-suicide; the cabin was secured, authorities including the FBI were notified and are investigating, and the ship—having departed Tampa on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise—is cooperating fully.

Patrick Kluivert, former Netherlands forward and assistant coach, has made a winning start as coach of Curacao by steering the team into the second round of CONCACAF qualifying for the 2018 World Cup after a 2-1 home win and a 2-2 away draw with Montserrat for a 4-3 aggregate victory, capped by Charlton Vicento’s 87th-minute goal. Curacao will face Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert—whose mother is from Curacao—was a World Cup semi-finalist as a player in 1998 and as an assistant to Louis van Gaal in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, a veteran midfielder who has won 15 career honours with River Plate, Real Madrid and Inter Milan—including the Champions League and FIFA Club World Cup—has said that keeping relegation-threatened Leicester City in the Premier League would feel “like another cup.” Signed on a one-year deal after ten years at Inter, the Foxes lie seven points from safety with eight games to go and have not won since January, yet Cambiasso insists they still have a real chance to avoid the drop. Quick to establish himself as a key player in the East Midlands, he says he is happy personally and with his family and hopes to secure the crucial points needed to retain Leicester’s top-flight status, though his future beyond this season remains undecided.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two children under five by different fathers, handed her infants to her 52-year-old mother Debbie when they were four months old and now faces being banned from seeing them after Debbie—who took them in when social services threatened to remove them—accused her of prioritizing drinking, partying and the legal high MKat over motherhood, as well as stealing money and even one child’s iPad. Despite Gemma’s denials about the iPad, she admits past thefts from her mother, who says Gemma “gave up” on her babies shortly after birth and lets the children call her “mum.” Exhausted by raising her grandchildren alone and unable to trust Gemma not to pinch their possessions, Debbie has warned she will bar her daughter from the house and from contact unless she stops drinking, taking drugs and partying.

Chelsea’s opening goal against Manchester United began when captain John Terry’s strong challenge from behind on Radamel Falcao sent the United striker to the ground, allowing Cesc Fàbregas to win the loose ball and feed Oscar, whose back-heel released Eden Hazard to score; during half-time analysis, Sky Sports pundits Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry and Jamie Redknapp all agreed Terry’s forearm challenge, which elbowed Falcao in the back of the head, constituted a foul that should have stopped play.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott’s tour bus caught fire Thursday morning on Interstate 30 just northeast of Dallas after a rear tire blew out and ignited once everyone had disembarked, but all aboard—including Scott, her husband, the tour manager and the driver—were evacuated safely. Michael Barnett filmed smoke and flames pouring from the bus’s rear before traffic slowed and he stopped recording, later uploading the footage to CNN iReport. Scott shared Instagram photos showing the charred back lounge—destroyed except for her Bible—and thanked those who helped extinguish the blaze, while bandmates Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not traveling. Lady Antebellum is still set to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas, on Sunday.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing orbiting, mirror‐covered satellites that harvest sunlight and convert it via semiconductors into laser beams beamed down to Earth, boosting solar panel output to make solar power viable in Scotland and restore electricity in disaster-hit areas—initial trials in Scotland were successful and further tests are slated for Portugal. Although he concedes there might be concerns over control, his lasers are far too weak to serve as weapons, more akin to a Riken proposal to fit lasers on the ISS to nudge small debris into the atmosphere rather than destroy targets.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile described as having a “fanatical obsession” with young girls, escaped from a private psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, at around 6:15 pm on Tuesday and is now the subject of an urgent police manhunt. Detained under a hospital order after being sentenced last August for sexually touching a three-year-old toddler on a bus and admitting to possessing indecent images of children, Munden—who suffers from autism and mild learning difficulties—stands about 5 ft 8 in tall, of heavy build with dark hair, and may have shaved off his beard since his escape. Police warn he poses a serious risk and are appealing for anyone who has seen him to come forward immediately.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay more than $2.6 million in gifts—from a Ferrari, two Bentleys and a Range Rover to a $1.8 million duplex, a $391 Easter bunny costume, a $299 blender and a $12 lace thong—after Rochelle “Shelly” Sterling sued her for allegedly targeting Donald Sterling, who funded the purchases with the couple’s money; Stiviano argued she did nothing wrong, while Shelly’s lawyer hailed the ruling as a victory for injured spouses. The dispute traces back to a leaked audio recording in which Sterling made racist remarks to Stiviano about posting photos with African-Americans like Magic Johnson, leading NBA Commissioner Adam Silver to ban him, fine him $2.5 million and force the sale of the Clippers.

Thierry Henry has condemned Arsenal’s transfer policy and insisted they must recruit a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder and a top-quality striker if they are to contend for the Premier League title. Speaking as a Sky Sports pundit after Arsenal’s goalless draw with Chelsea, he argued that although Olivier Giroud has netted 14 league goals this season, he lacks the cutting edge needed to lead a title-winning side. Henry pointed to Chelsea’s turnaround after signing Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fàbregas and Diego Costa as evidence that high-calibre arrivals are crucial and warned Arsène Wenger that matching such acquisitions is vital for Arsenal—currently third in the table, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand—to regain the championship.

A young woman who was subjected to years of abuse by wealthy NSW businessman Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences including persistent sexual abuse of a child, told Sydney’s District Court she kept the abuse secret until his arrest, has suffered depression, self-harm and attempted suicide since age 14, feels her right to intimacy was stolen, fears for her future relationships and worries about his eventual release; the hearing continues.

Serge Gnabry, the 19-year-old Germany Under-21 international, is closing in on a first-team return to Arsenal more than a year after a serious knee injury ruled him out following the March 2014 Champions League last-16 tie against Bayern Munich. Having impressed for the Gunners before his setback, he has now completed two 90-minute matches for the Under-21s—including Monday’s 1-0 loss to Reading—and says he feels “better and better,” fully over his injury and looking forward to his next game.

Graduate accountant Jacob Phillips, 23, died after plunging 70 ft down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, when he and friends, short of cash after a night out, fled a taxi to avoid the fare. In darkness he jumped a fence at the disused Northern Promenade, became disoriented and fell onto the rocky beach; his body was found the next morning by a dog walker. At the inquest the coroner recorded accidental death, noting Phillips had no idea of the sheer drop ahead. A University of Birmingham graduate who worked for Pretty Green, he had returned home to Reading via Cardiff for Christmas and been staying with family in Wales.

Last summer’s massive backlog at HM Passport Office left over half a million applications stalled, forcing many travellers to pay an extra £30 for fast-track processing—or miss their trips altogether—yet ministers declined a blanket refund, citing precedent concerns. Between April and January, just 2,191 compensation claims were approved (out of unknown total submissions), averaging £92.68 each (from £1 to £5,463), while the office made a £42.3 million surplus and its managers received £1.8 million in bonuses (averaging £499, up to £3,500). Many families, including one couple who lost nearly £1,500 on a cancelled Moroccan proposal trip despite applying ten weeks ahead, went uncompensated.

A timewarp semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged since the 1930s and due to be auctioned on April 30 with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000, retains its original mint-green-and-black bathroom, period kitchen with vintage cupboards and glass-panelled door, wood-panelled hall illuminated by stained-glass windows depicting ships, living-room windows bearing coats of arms, brick open-face fire and oil-fired central heating. Even a high hallway shelf holds original tins of Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk, Tate & Lyle sugar and Colman’s Mustard; although the house has been double-glazed, auctioneers warn that renovation costs could put developers off, making it ideal for antique enthusiasts or a family seeking a unique collector’s home.

Colin Kaepernick began his NFL career as Alex Smith’s backup before taking over as the San Francisco 49ers’ starting quarterback midway through the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion; he remained the starter for the rest of that year and led the team to its first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, ultimately losing to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds and Robert Teitel, released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent much of her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn was raised in Leytonstone, East London and around Colchester, Essex, attending Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur; the group’s debut album Leisure arrived in 1991 to mixed reviews, and drawing on influences from alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae and pop they released a self-titled album in 2001 to worldwide success; Albarn’s first solo studio album, Everyday Robots—co-produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell—was released on 28 April 2014 and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir as well as samples of Lord Buckley’s rants.
Mogadishu—also known as Muqdisho in Somali, Hamar locally, and مقديشو in Arabic—is Somalia’s capital and most populous city, hosting many of its key national institutions.
“Happiness in Slavery” is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, released on their debut EP Broken in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

Both the 2007 film Shooter and the TV series of the same name center on Bob Lee Swagger: in the movie, Mark Wahlberg portrays the Force Recon veteran who is framed for murder by a rogue private military company unit, while in the series, Ryan Phillippe plays the expert marksman living in exile who is drawn back into action to thwart a plot to assassinate the president.
House, also called House, M.D., is an American medical drama series that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, running from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

In 1971 Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people—Abigail Ann Folger, Wojciech Frykowski, Steven Earl Parent, Sharon Tate Polanski, Jay Sebring and Leno and Rosemary LaBianca—all carried out by members of his group at his instruction; he also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea, and after his charges were filed recordings of songs he wrote and performed were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn (born August 17, 1960) is an American actor, filmmaker and political activist who made his screen debut in a 1974 episode of Little House on the Prairie directed by his father, Leo Penn. After his film debut in Taps (1981) and a breakout role in Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), he earned critical notice in crime dramas such as At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990) and Carlito’s Way (1993). His leading performance in Dead Man Walking (1995) brought him his first Academy Award nomination and the Berlin Film Festival Best Actor Award. Penn was Oscar-nominated again for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001) before winning Best Actor for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), nicknamed “The Don,” was an Australian cricketer universally acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time, and after retiring he spent three decades shaping the game as an administrator, selector and writer.
L.A. Reid has served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a division of Sony Music Entertainment), as president and CEO of Arista Records, and as chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is an American drummer best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07); he began his career with the band Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, he performs in Prophets of Rage alongside Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, Chuck D, B-Real and DJ Lord. Separately, Rage is also the name of a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter “Peavy” Wagner.

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, spanning 34 episodes over two seasons; it was officially canceled by CBS on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1, 1933–September 13, 2006) was a Democratic politician who served as Texas state treasurer and gained national prominence delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention before becoming the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995 (the state’s second female governor), noted for her outspoken feminism and one-liners, and was defeated for reelection by George W. Nuuk, pronounced [nuːk] and also known as Godthåb, is the capital and largest city of Greenland and serves as the principal city of the Sermersooq municipality.

How to Train Your Dragon 2, written and directed by Dean DeBlois, reunites the original voice cast—Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller and Kristen Wiig—and adds Cate Blanchett as Valka, Djimon Hounsou as Drago and Kit Harington.

Down with Love is a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed, written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, and starring Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson and David Hyde Pierce. The film is a pastiche of the late-1950s and early-1960s sex comedies, notably the Doris Day–Rock Hudson movies Pillow Talk (1959), Lover Come Back (1961) and Send Me No Flowers (1964). A Taiwanese television adaptation aired on free-to-air China Television (CTV) from 31 January to 23 May 2010 (Sundays, 22:00–23:30) and on cable channel Gala Television (GTV) Variety Show/CH 28 from 2 February to 30 May 2010 (Sundays, 20:00–21:30).
Paris is a Paris Hilton album that blends elements of reggae, soul and pop rock in its production.

Stripes is a 1981 American buddy military comedy film directed by Ivan Reitman and starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P.J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy; it also features John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold in their first significant film roles, with Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton appearing early in their careers.
Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her song “Love or Lust,” which was featured in Bill Duke’s film Deep Cover, and for performing choruses on classic West Coast rap tracks such as Snoop Dogg’s “Gin and Juice” and Dr. Dre’s “Let Me Ride.”

The University of Mississippi draws about 55 percent of its undergraduates and 60 percent of its overall enrollment from within Mississippi, has 23 percent minority students, and hosts international students from 90 nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet–Kerner Productions, and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy starred as Jenny Matrix in the web series Video Game High School from 2012 to 2014, co-starred as Anna Martin in the Lifetime dark comedy-drama series Unreal in 2015, and is currently starring as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller Quantico.

Martin Van Buren (1782–1862) was an American Democratic politician who served as Secretary of State (1829–1831), Vice President (1833–1837), and as the eighth President of the United States (1837–1841) under Andrew Jackson. He was a key organizer of Jackson’s 1828 campaign, briefly ran as New York Governor to bolster Jackson’s support, then resigned after two months to become Jackson’s Secretary of State. In 1831, having helped resolve the Petticoat affair by stepping down, Van Buren received a recess appointment as American minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey is home to Rutgers University–Camden, which began as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and to the Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the United States, ranking tenth in population and eleventh in total area—making it the largest state by area east of the Mississippi River—and is unique for consisting of two peninsulas, which contributes to its status as one of the nation’s leading states for recreational boating.

In the 1930s, Penguin Books revolutionised publishing by offering high-quality paperback fiction and non-fiction at sixpence, sold through Woolworths and other high street stores, thereby making literature affordable and accessible to the mass market.
The 2008 film Australia was produced in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor and philanthropist credited with popularizing country music globally. Excuse My French is also the title of American rapper French Montana’s debut studio album. Additionally, Excuse My French is a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, adapted from his own middle-school experiences in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia; the censorship board initially considered it too sensitive, prompting script revisions to retain its core focus on religious discrimination.
In 2013, Derek Hough starred in Make Your Move, a Romeo and Juliet–inspired South Korean–American independent dance film.

“Bad Romance” is a song by American singer Lady Gaga from her 2009 EP The Fame Monster; after an illegal demo leak, she debuted the final version at Alexander McQueen’s Paris Fashion Week show in October 2009 and released the single’s cover art, and it went on to top charts worldwide and sell 12 million copies, making it one of the best-selling singles ever; “Bad Romance” is also the title of a 2011 independent drama film (Les Mauvais Romans).

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, spanning franchises such as Shrek (and its prequel-spinoff Puss in Boots), Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon and Trolls, alongside hits like Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013) and Home (2015); it also produced Trollhunters, a computer-animated fantasy series for Netflix created by Guillermo del Toro in collaboration with Double Dare You.

Christopher Livingstone “Chris” Eubank (born 8 August 1966) is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998, and his son, Christopher Livingstone “Chris” Eubank Jr. (born 18 September 1989), is a British professional boxer who has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017 after winning the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016; as of May 2017 he is ranked fifth best super-middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

Sophia Anna Bush (born July 8, 1982) is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist, recognized for her roles in the films John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch currently serves as chairman and acting CEO of Fox News and previously held full control as chairman and CEO of News Corporation—now split into News Corp and 21st Century Fox—while his younger son, James Rupert Jacob Murdoch (born 13 December 1972), is an Australian-British-American businessman who serves as CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc.
In 2013 Gal Gadot was Israel’s second-highest-earning actress/model—behind Bar Refaeli and ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka—with the bulk of her earnings coming from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, commonly known as Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are typically detected by radiographic examination, commonly referred to as an “x-ray.”
The South Wales Coalfield, known in Welsh as Maes glo De Cymru, is a substantial area in south Wales notable for its abundant coal deposits, particularly concentrated in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League, originally known as the CONCACAF Champions’ Cup when it was first organized in 1962, is an annual continental football club competition run by CONCACAF for the top clubs in North America, Central America and the Caribbean.

Mary of Teck became queen mother in 1936 after the death of her husband, King George V, saw her eldest son Edward ascend and then abdicate that same year to marry Wallis Simpson; she then supported her second son, Albert, as King George VI until his death in 1952 and died herself in 1953 during the early reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.
The film Poseidon grossed $181,674,817 worldwide against a $160 million budget.
