The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series debuted in 1996, and since then Omar Epps and Joe Morton have each won it three times, the most of any actors.

Human trafficking is the trade of humans primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery or commercial sexual exploitation; according to the International Labour Organization, forced-labor trafficking alone generated an estimated $150 billion in annual profits as of 2014, and among those affected, 14.2 million (68 percent) were exploited for labor, 4.5 million (22 percent) for sexual exploitation, and 2.2 million (10 percent) in state-imposed forced labor.
Rio is a 2011 film whose sequel, Rio 2, was released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I refers to two historical figures: Franz Stefan (1708–1765), Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany whose wife wielded actual power; and François I (1494–1547), the first King of France of the Angoulême branch of Valois (reigned 1515–1547), nicknamed “Francis of the Large Nose,” the Grand Colas and the “Knight-King,” who battled his great rival Charles V in the Italian War of 1536–1538 and, after failing to defeat him, forged a controversial Franco-Ottoman alliance with Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent.

Peking University (PKU), also known as Běidà, is a leading Chinese research university in Beijing and a founding member of the C9 League. Established in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking to replace the ancient Taixue (Guozijian) and initially functioning as China’s highest education authority, it has since become the consistently top-ranked institution of higher learning in mainland China.
Lemmy was renowned for his appearance—particularly his friendly mutton chops—alongside his distinctive gravelly voice and unique bass playing style.
Global warming threatens human well-being by reducing crop yields and undermining food security and by forcing the abandonment of populated areas as sea levels rise.
Australia is a 2008 Australian-American-British epic historical romantic adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.
Michael Dwayne Vick, born June 26, 1980, is a former NFL quarterback who spent 13 seasons primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a wide array of oral traditions—including songs, legends, rhymes, jokes, proverbs, weather lore and superstitions—as well as hands-on practices such as traditional food-making and craft-making.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films praised for being both informative and entertaining, and it also trained combat cameramen.

James Jones the author earned the 1952 National Book Award for his debut novel From Here to Eternity, which was quickly adapted into a film and later into a television series, while James Jones the basketball player averaged 25 points per game as a high school senior—winning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State—has captured three NBA championships (two with Miami, one with Cleveland), reached the NBA Finals for a seventh straight year in 2017 alongside LeBron James, ranked third in the league in three-point shooting in 2007–08, and won the 2011 Three-Point Contest.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked by the American Film Institute in 1999 as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation is the process of generating animated images, and Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
In 2009, Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE, which took effect on January 1, 2010.

English actor Tom Baker is best known for his record-breaking portrayal of the Fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981 and for narrating the comedy series Little Britain; he has also lent his voice to commercials, video games, audiobooks and other television series.
Angelsberg is a small town situated in the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site, in addition to its ongoing cleanup project, hosts the Columbia Generating Station—a commercial nuclear power plant—and supports scientific research and development through facilities such as the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior executive branch official appointed by and serving at the pleasure of the president whose chief role is to act as spokesperson for the administration—particularly on matters concerning the president, senior officials, and policy—requiring no Senate confirmation, yet holding a highly visible non-Cabinet position due to frequent media briefings that inform the public.

Kentucky, nicknamed the Bluegrass State for the bluegrass thriving in its fertile soil, features the central Bluegrass Region home to Louisville and Lexington and is renowned for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges, released in 2006, stars Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds and Kelly Preston, who also appeared in the films The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert (born March 1, 1987), formerly stylized as Ke $ha, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper.
On May 5, 2017, two new versions of “Despacito” were released: an electronic version produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW), originally aired via closed-circuit television and, beginning in 1987—prompted by WWF’s Survivor Series exclusivity demands—becoming the first NWA event broadcast on pay-per-view; WWE Network later added the 1983–1986 closed-circuit shows to its pay-per-view catalog in 2014 (rating them TV-MA for their violent matches, notably the “I Quit” bout between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A.), and Starrcade 1997 marked the fifteenth annual pay-per-view iteration.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director working in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series created specifically for that service and marks the franchise’s return to television, being the first new Star Trek series since Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also competed in the World League of American Football with the Rhein Fire.

“Excuse My French” is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and also the title of a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama based on his post-Saudi Arabia middle-school experiences in Egypt. Additionally, Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew (born 22 October 1983), known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip-hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer.

A floppy disk, also called a floppy, diskette or just disk, is a disk storage medium consisting of a thin, flexible magnetic storage disk sealed within a rectangular plastic enclosure—often lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

Guatemala endured chronic instability and civil strife from the mid- to late 19th century and, between 1960 and 1996, suffered a bloody civil war pitting a US-backed government against leftist rebels, during which the military carried out genocidal massacres of the Maya population.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments designed for grasping and holding objects, and outside of medical contexts they are commonly called tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer premiered its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, following its sixth season which concluded as cable’s highest-rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the fictional protagonist of ABC’s drama series Lost, which aired from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, across six seasons and 121 episodes, with its first season averaging 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey (born November 4, 1969) is an American actor who since 2011 has focused on dramatic roles in films such as The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy and Mud (the latter starring McConaughey alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard and Reese Witherspoon), followed by Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees and Free State of Jones.

Robert Palmer is a writer best known for his book Deep Blues, his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone, his production of blues recordings and the Deep Blues film soundtrack, and his clarinet playing with the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (April 9, 1912 – January 27, 1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, sculptor Gutzon Borglum—who designed and led the project from 1927 until his death in March 1941—passed away, at which point Lincoln Borglum assumed leadership of the construction.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams, starring Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice performances by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a sci-fi drama that follows nine young people—Clarke Griffin (Eliza Taylor), Bellamy Blake (Bob Morley), Octavia Blake (Marie Avgeropoulos), Jasper Jordan (Devon Bostick), Monty Green (Christopher Larkin), Raven Reyes (Lindsey Morgan), Finn Collins (Thomas McDonell), John Murphy (Richard Harmon) and Wells Jaha (Eli Goree)—who are sent from the space habitat known as the Ark back to a post-nuclear-apocalypse Earth, while also featuring Ark leaders Dr. Abby Griffin (Paige Turco), council member Marcus Kane (Henry Ian Cusick) and Chancellor Thelonious Jaha (Isaiah Washington).

Despite pioneering financial problems, the Concert for Bangladesh became a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid project, generating both widespread awareness and significant funds while offering valuable lessons and inspiration for later initiatives such as Live Aid.
Recognized by the media as one of India’s most influential filmmakers, Mani Ratnam is widely credited with revolutionising the Tamil film industry and reshaping the profile of Indian cinema.

Stephen A. Douglas articulated the Freeport Doctrine during the second of the seven Lincoln–Douglas Debates on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. Those debates—between Republican challenger Abraham Lincoln and incumbent Democratic Senator Douglas—formed the “Great Debates of 1858” in the Illinois Senate race. The Freeport, Quincy and Alton sessions all attracted particularly large, multi-state audiences because the future of slavery was a matter of nationwide concern.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice (born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941) is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She launched her professional writing career in California with Interview with the Vampire in 1976 and began writing its sequels in the 1980s, a period during which she gained growing critical and popular acclaim after initially mixed reviews. Rice was married to poet and painter Stan Rice from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at age 60.

Camden, a city in Camden County, New Jersey, had a population of 77,344 at the 2010 United States Census, making it the state’s 12th most populous municipality; at the beginning of the twentieth century, its residents were predominantly European immigrants, and a city is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the original screenplay for the critically derided 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film The Canyons, which was directed by Paul Schrader.

The Lincoln–Douglas Debates, also known as the Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic candidate, held in seven towns across Illinois.

Homer is the name ascribed by the ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems central to ancient Greek literature, and The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8, 1974 – February 2, 2013) was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece band featuring Soundgarden frontman Chris Cornell alongside Rage Against the Machine alumni Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals) and Brad Wilk (drums). Wilk began his career drumming for Greta in 1990, co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991, and is best known for his work with Rage (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07); as of 2016 he performs in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, comprised rapper/vocalist Zack de la Rocha, bassist/backing vocalist Tim Commerford, guitarist Tom Morello and drummer Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress and model signed to her own imprint Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records; in 2010 she released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid—a concept-album sequel to her debut EP—through Bad Boy Records.
Winter’s Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin and published in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States, and the University of Mississippi enrolls a student body in which about 55 percent of undergraduates and 60 percent overall come from Mississippi, 23 percent are minorities, and international students represent 90 nations.
Flaked was renewed in July 2016 for a six-episode second season set to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served twice in the New York State Assembly (1784–85 and 1798–99), was New York State Attorney General from 1789 to 1791, represented New York as a U.S. senator from 1791 to 1797, and ultimately reached the apex of his career as vice president.

The Soyuz rocket, developed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s and still in service, was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program—beginning with eight unmanned test flights and followed by nineteen crewed missions—and, as the successor to Voskhod, was originally built for the Soviet manned lunar programs.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Growing tensions over the band’s direction led Zack de la Rocha to quit, causing Rage Against the Machine to break up; de la Rocha pursued a low-key solo career while the remaining members formed Audioslave with ex–Soundgarden frontman Chris Cornell, recording three albums before disbanding in 2007. That same year Rage Against the Machine reunited, performing at Coachella in April, and their fourth studio album, Renegades, had been released earlier on December 5, 2000 by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or simply the SENSEX, is a free-float, market-weighted index of 30 well-established, financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange; among its constituents is Tata Motors, which is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, making it the world’s 14th-most-populous country and the ninth-most-populous in Asia. It borders China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam’s economic growth rate has been among the highest in the world, and in 2011 it led the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. It remains one of the world’s four one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film marking John Gatins’s directorial debut, which he also wrote and directed.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose two dramatic acts of violence against British rule led to his execution at age 23 and made him a posthumous folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in Aamir Khan’s 2016 Hindi-language biographical sports drama film Dangal, which depicts a wrestling competition and was directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (19 June 1566–27 March 1625) became King of Scotland as James VI in 1567 and, upon the union of crowns on 24 March 1603, King of England and Ireland as James I until his death, ruling both realms in personal union despite their separate parliaments, judiciaries, and laws, advocating a single parliament for England and Scotland, and encountering numerous conflicts with the English Parliament.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress who began as an original core cast member of the soap opera Shortland Street and gained recognition for roles such as the Amazon Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. She appeared in the 2009 film Separation City and the Australian series Rake, portrayed Sydney underworld figure Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor, and most recently starred as Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth for four years before departing in 2016.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade has starred and co-starred in films such as Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2; Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, released in 2015, is an American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed critical reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales, marking Gaga’s second consecutive US number-one album with 757,000 copies sold domestically, and ranking as the ninth best-selling album of 2013 with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.
Stadium Arcadium, released in 2006, was John Frusciante’s fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, and he officially left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister and introduced the policies now called Thatcherism; she remains a highly influential yet controversial figure in British history, lauded by many even as debates over her legacy persist.

Michael Andrew “Duff” McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter and author who, alongside his musical career, has written weekly columns on a wide variety of topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, in addition to his acting roles, has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the Valencian Community and Spain’s third-largest city after Madrid and Barcelona, with about 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative centre and a metropolitan area population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
Make It or Break It concluded with the announcement on April 26, 2012, that its third season would be its final one, and its series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary subfield of computational linguistics—drawing on linguistics, computer science and electrical engineering—to enable computers to convert spoken language into text. Its applications include voice dialing, call routing, home-automation control, search for specific spoken words, simple data entry, structured-document preparation, speech-to-text processing and direct voice input in aircraft. The field’s progress is demonstrated by a surge of academic research and, more crucially, by global industry adoption of deep learning techniques in commercial systems developed by companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek and CDAC.

Richard Alf (January 26, 1952 – January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and comic book store owner who in 1970 co-founded the Golden State Comic Book Convention—later known as San Diego Comic-Con International—with Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and served as its chairman from its inception.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which originally starred Bruce Lee in the lead role.

Sheikh Ali Salman told the BBC that meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires the government to offer “concrete solutions” and appoint a royal-family representative—ideally reformist Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, who is at odds with hardliners led by long-serving PM Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa. He welcomed the newly agreed talks between six opposition societies and the government, arguing negotiations are necessary despite young protesters’ distrust of established parties. He recalled a seven-point plan for a constitutional monarchy struck with the Crown Prince on 14 March 2011, only to be derailed 12 hours later by the arrival of GCC troops, and urged US Secretary of State John Kerry to push harder for human rights. He also demanded that the UK speak out publicly on abuses, affirmed al-Wefaq’s commitment to peaceful demonstrations despite the rally ban, and insisted that the release of 13 imprisoned opposition leaders—convicted on torture-tainted evidence—is essential for dialogue to succeed.

Hogwood died at his Cambridge home after an illness of several months, with a private funeral and a later memorial planned. A pioneering conductor and harpsichordist, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973 and led it worldwide for around 30 years, producing over 200 recordings—among them the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments—and the celebrated 1980 Handel’s Messiah. Trained at Cambridge under Puyana and Potts and later with Ruzickova and Leonhardt, he began with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, co-founded the Early Music Consort of London, directed the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, taught at Harvard, Cambridge and Cornell, and was widely praised for his generosity, scholarly rigor and advocacy of historically informed performance.

In 2015–16 Scotland recorded 57 homicides—the lowest annual total since 1976 and about half the number from nine years earlier—with only one case unresolved; sharp instruments accounted for 51% of killings (29 cases, 26 involving knives) and 31% of accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson highlighted the role of education, enforcement and multi-agency support in driving long-term declines and stressed continued action against violence and alcohol misuse, while Scottish Labour’s Claire Baker cautioned that 2014–15 figures had been revised upward (from 59 to 62 homicides) and noted rising sexual crime and a 27% increase in attempted murder and serious assault.

Bournemouth suffered a 2-1 defeat at Sunderland, becoming the first Premier League side to fall to the Black Cats this season despite taking the lead through Dan Gosling’s first goal in three matches. Manager Eddie Howe bemoaned his team’s profligacy—having scored six against Hull before failing to find the net in their last two games—and pointed out that they squandered clear chances even after Sunderland were reduced to ten men. Sunderland’s goals came from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty, and Howe stressed that moving on from such missed opportunities is crucial.

Following the collapse of last month’s Aleppo ceasefire, the United States suspended its participation in bilateral U.S.-Russia channels intended to sustain the cessation of hostilities, accusing Moscow and the Syrian government of resuming heavy aerial bombardment that has killed hundreds—including three strikes on the main trauma hospital—blocked humanitarian aid (notably the disputed 19 September convoy attack that Russia attributes to ground fire) and left some 250,000 civilians trapped in rebel-held eastern Aleppo. State Department spokesman John Kirby said Russia had failed to uphold its own commitments or secure Syrian regime compliance, while Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova regretted Washington’s decision, blamed the U.S. for not improving humanitarian conditions or distinguishing jihadists from moderate opposition, and denied any Russian or Syrian aerial involvement in the convoy strike. Though U.S. personnel were withdrawn from planned joint implementation efforts in Geneva, both sides agreed to continue co-ordinating counter-terrorism operations to avoid unintended clashes.

Policy Exchange’s “Ending Expensive Social Tenancies” report, endorsed by Downing Street, argues that selling vacant social homes worth above regional averages (816,000 properties, 21.8% of stock) at a 3.5% annual vacancy rate could raise £5.5 billion gross (£4.5 billion net) to build 80,000–170,000 new social homes and reduce the 1.8 million waiting list by about 500,000. Backed by 73% of respondents, it claims to fund the largest social housing programme since the 1970s, while the prime minister’s spokesman urges councils to use this power. Labour and the National Housing Federation warn the policy would displace low-income families from mixed neighbourhoods, advocating a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes instead. Housing Minister Grant Shapps supports this approach alongside reforms like fixed-term tenancies and £19.5 billion in housing investment.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, a Swansea resident at the centre of a measles outbreak that has reached 942 cases and led to 83 hospitalisations since November, died at home after developing a rash following recent treatment for asthma; although laboratory tests confirmed measles, an inquest opened on Tuesday has been adjourned pending further tests to determine whether the virus was the primary cause of his death, and his family—none of whom, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have had measles—remain unsure how he contracted it.

Cumbria Police have charged 54-year-old Vincent Hudson of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, with a historical offence against a boy under 16 alleged to have taken place in 2001, and he is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates’ Court.

Neil Aspin’s Gateshead side extended their National League unbeaten run to nine games, while Adam Lockwood’s Guiseley were on a five-match unbeaten streak as the teams drew 1–1; Guiseley went ahead on 15 minutes when a throw-in found James Hurst, whose square ball released Jake Lawlor into an empty net, and after Guiseley keeper Jonny Maxted saved Wesley York’s shot before the break and Liam Hogan blocked Jordan Preston’s effort, the hosts levelled on 62 when a slip by half-time substitute Derek Asamoah let York curl sweetly into the top-right corner.

Bristol Sport Ltd, owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands at its current stadium to increase capacity as an alternative to the long-delayed Ashton Vale stadium proposal, which has been held up by a town green application. The redevelopment, approved by Bristol City Council in November, was confirmed by majority shareholder Steve Lansdown at a Tuesday shareholder meeting. He said the club will sign the Section 106 agreement imminently, then wait six weeks for any judicial review; if nothing arises by March, work will begin in May.

Cuadrilla suspended fracking operations as a precaution following a 1.5-magnitude tremor—the second in two months—to allow the British Geological Survey (BGS) to analyse data before any resumption; the BGS has determined that this April event and a magnitude-2.3 tremor on April 1 share a similar location and mechanism, occurring roughly 2 km deep near the Preese Hall site, and notes that injecting pressurised fluid into deep rocks can trigger small earthquakes. Cuadrilla’s chief executive Mark Miller said they have halted work to share information and consult authorities, a process expected to take weeks, while the Commons energy select committee recently urged UK ministers to back shale gas under tight regulation despite US environmental concerns over groundwater contamination. The BGS continues to monitor seismic activity, having installed temporary instruments near the drilling site.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool bagpiper who has played in the city centre for more than 30 years, was found guilty of one count of fraud at Liverpool Crown Court for performing in April 2015 with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes—he was cleared of two other counts. Sgt Chris Gaynor said Carpenter gave the impression he was collecting cash for the campaign, but Carpenter insisted he was simply busking and had piped for the charity before. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, confirmed he allowed Carpenter to display a banner featuring the eternal flame and the word “justice,” but made clear it was not to be used for fundraising. Carpenter told the court the banner was a tribute to the victims and noted he is a familiar face on match days at Anfield; he will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town secured a 3-0 Championship victory over Queens Park Rangers thanks to Grant Ward’s initial strike, a miscued clearance by QPR keeper Alex Smithies that allowed Luke Varney to double the lead, and Tom Lawrence’s composed finish from Cole Skuse’s long-range effort. After failing to score in seven of their previous ten league games, Ipswich dominated chances—Christophe Berra and Skuse both went close—and rarely looked troubled as sub Sandro’s late header was the only real threat for Rangers. The win lifted Mick McCarthy’s side to 14th in the table, leapfrogging Ian Holloway’s team, who have won just once in six away matches. McCarthy praised Varney’s work rate and welcomed the confidence boost, while Holloway blamed defensive lapses for the second goal, criticized his team’s mental toughness, and lamented a missed opportunity to stem their poor away form.

Wells, 23, impressed in last season’s T20 Blast with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66, and praised the club’s positive direction and the coaches’ elite-performance environment for inspiring the squad.

The fifth-placed Reds secured their second straight win by beating third-placed Chinnor 29-12, with Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams leading a front-row effort that made over 70 tackles, according to coach Churcher. Facing eight upcoming games—including seven teams below them and leaders Old Elthamians—Churcher said the Chinnor match, while emotionally dogged, was far from a complete performance and must be built on or risk rendering the victory meaningless.

Police allege that 28-year-old Bangladeshi national Nazrul raped a 74-year-old nun during a March 14 break-in at a convent in Ranaghat town—where money was stolen and the building ransacked—and after being identified on CCTV he fled to Bangladesh but was arrested at a Kolkata railway station following a tip-off; he is the sixth person detained in the case, one of eight suspects (two still untraced), with the five earlier arrestees naming him as the rapist, and in May police also arrested Milon Sarkar, described as the gang leader though his exact role remains unclear, in an incident that provoked nationwide outrage and street protests.

Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, presents an interactive video explaining how innovations like the domestic freezer, washing powder and cheaper imports have reshaped UK consumer choices and examines shifting ownership and rankings of major UK brands, with links to non-interactive resources for further information.

Two women in Scotland fell victim to BT-themed phone scams in mid-September: a 71-year-old in Sandyhills on September 15, and a Stranraer resident seven days later, both tricked by callers posing as BT technical support who gained remote access to their computers and stole cash; PC Siobhan Pellett warned that such scams are alarmingly easy and urged anyone receiving unsolicited remote-access calls never to disclose banking or account details, since legitimate banks and businesses never ask for this information by phone.

Duffy, 37, a Scotland assistant coach and former Leigh, Widnes and Salford player, has signed a one-year contract to lead third-placed Championship side Featherstone, taking charge of Saturday’s final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers; chairman Mark Campbell praised his remarkable work in difficult circumstances at Swinton Lions, where he has been replaced by former assistant Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded at 12:50 GMT on Sunday to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve, where a rider with head injuries had been lying unconscious on wet sand and was very cold; she was treated on scene before being flown to Cardiff’s University Hospital of Wales.

At the World Radiocommunication Conference in Geneva, over 160 countries agreed to reserve a radio frequency for satellite reception of automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) signals—previously only transmitted to ground stations and other aircraft—to enable real-time global flight tracking. This move, driven by the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in March 2014 (which revealed that just 30% of world airspace is covered by ground-based radars), was hailed by ITU officials Francois Rancy and Secretary-General Houlin Zhao as a rapid response to global concerns. It follows calls from Malaysia’s communication minister for improved real-time data transmission and sets the stage for ICAO’s November 2016 mandate that aircraft report their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who vanished at age five, has been found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland at age 18; Bobby, 53, was arrested in Ohio and is held on $250,000 bail at Cuyahoga County Jail after being charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver’s licence in 2012, and the FBI, acting on an October 30 tip related to the teenager’s college application issues, worked with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity, while authorities note Bobby was long suspected after he claimed to be taking Julian to preschool in August 2002 before fleeing and Julian’s mother has now been notified.

Firefighters spent several days at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site after a 2 March blaze that disrupted train services and travel, prompting the Environment Agency to suspend the firm from taking waste and later revoke its environmental permit effective 7 August (pending appeal). Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service, which judged the site “broadly compliant” with fire safety law after nine visits in 12 months, had raised concerns with the EA in February about risks to residents, transport and the environment. Asset and Land Group, which runs the site, could not be reached for comment, and the fire’s cause remains undetermined.

A Just Russia has introduced two bills in the Duma tied to the Ukraine crisis: one would let regions like Crimea join Russia if a local referendum or leaders’ appeal approves—sidestepping the existing treaty requirement and invoking the Abkhazia and South Ossetia precedents—and the other would fast-track Russian passports for Ukrainians by waiving state fees, residency and financial proof and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship, granting citizenship in two months under a preamble of protecting Russian-speakers from a “brown threat”; both measures, backed by pro-Kremlin MPs and announced in Sevastopol, aim to solidify pro-Russian sentiment in Crimea, where many already hold Russian passports.

Thomas “Tommy” Baker, 44, from Everton, was found shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Old Swan, Liverpool, on 27 January and later died in hospital. Merseyside Police have three local men, two aged 29 and one aged 32, in custody and believe Baker was shot while getting into his car after leaving the Phoenix Gym, where the gunmen had waited for about an hour. Detectives are searching for a silver VW Polo seen fleeing the scene along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road and Queens Road, and are urging anyone captured on nearby CCTV—who may not realize the significance of what they saw—to come forward with information.
MODEL FAILED TO RETURN ANY OUTPUT

An eight-day inquiry in Ebbw Vale is assessing a proposal to convert over 250 ha of common land, with backers (including Blaenau Gwent council) offering about 320 ha of replacement land. Experts disagree on habitat impacts—Natural Resources Wales questions the replacement land’s equal value but isn’t opposing the scheme, while developers claim a “net gain” in biodiversity via nearby habitat enhancements, a point contested by Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend next steps, after which Welsh government ministers will make the final decision.

Novaya Gazeta’s 1 April report alleged that more than 100 people, mainly homosexual men—including prominent clerics and TV presenters—were detained, tortured with electric shocks and beatings, and that at least three were killed in Chechnya, a claim the Russian LGBT Network confirmed and said it was helping victims flee. On 3 April, Chechen Muslim clerics condemned the article as an insult to their faith and men, issuing a resolution warning of “retribution” against its instigators, prompting the paper to urge Russian authorities to curb hostility toward journalists. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesman denied the allegations and insisted there are no gay people in the republic. Novaya Gazeta’s editor pledged to continue probing human rights abuses amid unresolved murders of its reporters, while the LGBT Network warned it will file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute those responsible.

Investing Solutions and the linked charity Fresh Start Housing, both founded by Samir Patel and run from a south London storage unit, place single homeless men (mostly over 35) into shared private-sector homes, billing housing benefit per occupant rather than per property so that they pass most rent to landlords but pocket the excess. Over two years they’ve become one of the UK’s largest benefit claimants—Wandsworth Council alone paid them more than £2.1 million—while tenants like Nigel McCann describe rat-infested, unheated, damp houses. Although the arrangement is legal and Fresh Start says it has housed hundreds of people, homeless charity Crisis calls the charity-agency partnership “a new low,” Wandsworth stresses its regulatory oversight, Patel insists Fresh Start is independent and rents mostly go to landlords, and the Department for Communities and Local Government points to local authorities’ duty to safeguard taxpayers’ money.

Great Britain’s basketball team fell to the Netherlands in their final warm-up before Eurobasket qualifying, despite Andrew Lawrence’s 14 points and Ben Gordon’s 13; GB led for much of the first three quarters—at 35-24 after a Lawrence three—but the Dutch, sparked by Worthy De Jong’s 18 points and a 10-0 run to open the fourth, pulled away to win. Coach Joe Prunty, who will cut the roster ahead of a midweek qualifier in Hungary, praised Gordon’s third-quarter shooting streak and stressed the need for consistent effort on both ends of the floor.

Conor McGregor filed a last-minute waiver with the Nevada Athletic Commission to use 8oz gloves at 154 lbs—a departure from the 10oz rule for fighters above 135 lbs—after Floyd Mayweather had already announced on Instagram his intent to wear 8oz gloves without yet submitting paperwork; the NAC, which will publicly debate the unprecedented request on August 16, stressed that lighter gloves offer less cushioning while increasing punch impact and cited fighter safety as its top concern. Executive director Bob Bennett, who reviewed McGregor’s sparring footage, Virgil Hunter’s praise for Nate Diaz sessions, McGregor’s three knockdowns of Diaz, his youth, reach and “granite-like” chin, concluded there were “several reasons to approve the fight,” despite criticism from boxing figures like Oscar De La Hoya and Gennady Golovkin for the UFC champion’s crossover into what could become the richest bout in boxing history. After viewing more training videos and advising on officiating, the NAC supported hiring Hall of Famer Joe Cortez as referee, even as Paulie Malignaggi exited McGregor’s camp following a contentious sparring session.

Reporters Darryl Smith and Gavin Sherriff’s redundancy from the Sunday Post’s London office marks the final chapter in Fleet Street’s 300-year reign as Britain’s newspaper heartland, launched by the Daily Courant in 1702 and once hosting nearly every national title within a half-mile. They recall smoky newsrooms, clattering typewriters, creaking phones, paper-laden lorries and bars like El Vino, while ex-Sunday Express editor Robin Esser stresses that before TV and social media, up to 85% of public information flowed through these presses. Liz Hodgkinson’s 1970s–80s memoirs reveal a male-dominated, drink-fuelled culture. After Rupert Murdoch’s 1986 move to Wapping and the advent of computerized printing, titles migrated by 1988 and former offices became supermarkets and sandwich shops, closing the storied era.

JK Rowling said that supportive Twitter messages remind her of the many decent people in the world, after enduring abusive comments she felt crossed her personal line as a famous woman online. She previously faced a flood of criticism for donating £1 million to the Scottish independence “No” campaign (matching a 2008 gift to Labour), was called “a traitor” by some SNP supporters whom she later blocked, and refused to silence such abuse to protect any party’s image. At the same time she engaged positively with other SNP supporters over shared political views and even joked about bringing marshmallows when a user suggested burning her books. In the same election, the SNP won 56 of Scotland’s 59 seats to become the UK’s third-largest party.

University of Edinburgh researchers tracking 4,300 young people since 1998 found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same offences, about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision and more prone to violence and to becoming NEET by age 18, even after accounting for other risk factors; extreme poverty also increases both victimization and offending. Gender was a key predictor of violence, with boys three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts and poor girls twice as likely as affluent girls. A related AQMeN study showed that recent crime reductions have not reached the most deprived communities, which remain high in crime, health problems and unemployment. A Scottish government spokesperson countered that overall crime is at a 41-year low, homicide at a 39-year low and that initiatives, including a £296 m investment, are tackling poverty and inequality.

Mr Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee shortly after 1 a.m. on Sunday during an alleged confrontation in which Robbie Walsh of Island View, Kilrush, and two other men—who were later released without charge—went to the estate looking for Mr Haugh. Det Sgt Padraig Frawley told Ennis District Court that Walsh and the others encountered Mr Haugh and another man, a fight broke out involving knives and golf clubs, and Mr Haugh sustained a stab wound to the back. Gardaí recovered a blood-stained blade and knife handle at the scene, and Mr Haugh was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital at 6 a.m. Walsh has been charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody until 14 August, while files on the other two men are being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions.

After Tom Elliott’s May 2014 BBC radio interview, Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted an unsubstantiated claim that Elliott, who served in the UDR from 1982 to 1992 and now represents Fermanagh and South Tyrone as an MP with a clear MoD record, had “harassed and shot” people. Alerted by victims’ campaigner Ann Travers and DUP assembly member Arlene Foster, Elliott brought a defamation case; Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and has agreed to post a Twitter apology by Friday admitting the allegation was “untrue and wholly without foundation.” Mr Justice Stevens has reserved judgment on compensation, while the insurance firm that indemnifies MLAs has refused to cover Flanagan’s costs—a decision he is challenging—and Elliott said he feels vindicated despite the 19-month delay.

Hawick Knitwear, founded in 1874 and employing over 230 staff, has raised weekly sweater output from 7,500 to 9,500 to meet a surge in orders for both its new Hawick Knitwear–branded range (launched in January) and its established private-label business; acquired by managing director Benny Hartop last November, the company now exports to markets across Europe (including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy and Spain) as well as the USA, Canada, Mexico and Japan, and attributes its strong performance and outlook to dedicated staff and rising demand at home and abroad.

Seventy-two-year-old lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December when 55-year-old Brian Wright drove his VW Golf through a red light and struck her; Wright, who says he was blinded by the setting sun, admits hitting Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, has apologised in Luton Crown Court for turning her “world upside down,” and the trial continues while she remains in residential care.

Nato’s recent exercise “Dynamic Mongoose” pits ten warships—including the USS Vicksburg and Britain’s HMS Portland—against German U-boat U33 and its 28-strong crew, simulating the hunt for an “unseen” enemy in response to stepped-up Russian submarine patrols off Sweden, Finland and the UK. Ships’ bridges scan the horizon for periscopes while sonar operators and anti-submarine helicopters listen for undersea contacts, supplemented for the first time by underwater drones “Harpo” and “Groucho” from Nato’s research vessel. Russia now fields around 60 advanced submarines, including what it claims is the world’s quietest, prompting warnings from RUSI that Britain—having dispensed with its Nimrod maritime patrol aircraft—has a critical ASW gap. The exercise underlines both Nato’s collective reliance on multi-platform ASW capabilities and the urgent need for the UK to restore its long-range patrol aircraft.

Since July violence in Juba and the southern Equatoria states of South Sudan has sparked ethnic killings, rape and looting—reportedly by Dinka-aligned forces targeting Equatorians and Nuer amid the Kiir–Machar feud—forcing 340,000 people to flee into Uganda (an average of 2,500 daily), more than any other crisis this year. Refugees recount murders, rapes and knife attacks on children and civilians. Uganda, assisted by aid agencies, allocates plots and tarpaulins within 36 hours, enabling farming in camps such as Bidi Bidi—now spanning 250 km² with over 250,000 inhabitants—but hosting nearly one million refugees is straining resources like water and schools, even as children exhibit resilience despite deep trauma.

McKenzie, 38, a former Norwich and Peterborough footballer who turned professional boxer in 2013 after quitting football in 2011, holds an 8-0-1 record from nine fights and will face Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship; he is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The new £33 million Bridgwater Community Hospital—part of the coalition’s £330 million investment in NHS facilities across England—will replace the cramped 1813 building with a modern facility featuring 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injuries unit, X-ray services and space for mobile scanners. NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust will cover the remaining cost. Staff highlight the old hospital’s poor temperature control and high maintenance, noting that a new build would boost patient well-being. In the past five years three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals have been replaced and work is under way on Taunton’s Jubilee Building; the Bridgwater site at Bowers Lane awaits planning permission and is due for completion by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre, after being in or close to the black Mercedes he had been driving; armed officers sealed off the scene at about 13:35 GMT, and the victim was taken to Northern General hospital where he later died. Neighbours said he was part of a locally based family holding a celebration, and relatives rushed out to help after hearing the shot. The incident adds to a spate of recent shootings in Sheffield, including a 25-year-old seriously injured in Shiregreen, shots fired through a Southey Green couple’s living room window believed to be mistaken identity, and gunfire at houses on a High Green street in January.

Independent hacker collectives have played a prominent role in the Ukraine–Russia conflict: the pro-Ukrainian Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, have exfiltrated Russian interior-ministry and regional police data (35 GB of which Inform Napalm uncovered evidence of wounded Russian soldiers evacuated from Ukraine), launched DDoS attacks on separatist websites, targeted rebel funding via PayPal and WebMoney, hijacked CCTV systems for troop-movement surveillance and even network printers to display pro-Ukrainian slogans; the anti-Western Cyber Berkut has defaced Ukrainian government sites (notably during Joe Biden’s visit), claimed to leak US military-aid documents, disrupted vote-counting, hijacked Kiev billboards with “war-criminal” imagery and promoted unverified MH17 allegations; and Anonymous International (aka b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay) has published leaked Kremlin documents—ranging from a Russian fighter’s letter about Eastern-Ukraine locals to emails of ex-FSB colonel Igor Girkin—though its hacking methods and state links remain unclear.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly moved to tears as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, retiring after 15 years, used his farewell to warn Holyrood to learn from Westminster’s committee system to ensure proper accountability, scrutiny and opposition. She was again emotional when former first minister Alex Salmond, also standing down ahead of the 5 May election, reiterated that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” welcomed the Scotland Bill’s power transfers while lamenting broken referendum pledges, and quipped about competing with the Chancellor’s budget and the Cheltenham races before extolling the honor of parliamentary service. Former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie likewise bowed out with a joke about missing Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “huge outbursts of faux indignation.”

Sarah Rochira, the Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, is gathering testimony from pensioners, their families and friends, care providers, social care staff and public bodies as part of her review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential homes across Wales. Having witnessed both excellent care and unacceptable variations, she will use evidence on physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment to shape recommendations for providers and public bodies. Care Forum Wales supports the review’s aims but regrets that no provider expert sits on its advisory panel.

Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group posted a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m for the year to June 2016 despite turnover slipping by £1m to just over £100m, driven by growth in international sales across Europe and new overseas markets. The Turriff-based firm manufactures and supplies feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors and runs 19 Country Store shops across Scotland offering farming and rural products such as fireside supplies, country clothing and footwear. In its Companies House filings, Harbro cautioned that agriculture remains unpredictable and has faced challenges over the past 12–18 months, but described the industry as robust and expressed confidence that it is well positioned to handle potential impacts from Brexit.

Police found the body of a man in his 70s at a house on Nettleden Road in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday and an elderly man in his 80s was taken to hospital; detectives from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire major crime unit are treating the death as murder and urgently want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), warning the public not to approach him. He is described as a white male about 6 ft tall with straight greying collar-length hair, of average build, and believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter-length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt. Officers are conducting extra patrols in the area and anyone with information is urged to contact police or Crimestoppers.

David Lipton, the IMF’s deputy managing director, warned in a Washington speech that the global economy is weakening and at a “delicate juncture,” citing China’s recent trade data showing a 25% year-on-year drop in exports, and signaled that the Fund will likely cut its 3.4% growth forecast when it issues new projections in April, a development with significant implications for businesses and industries tied to China’s growth.

At a council scrutiny meeting over the new chain ferry’s troubled launch since 14 May—including breakdowns, groundings, a Coastguard suspension over training issues, and vehicle damage—leader Dave Stewart announced free Cowes crossings until 2 July and an auditor-led project review. Local businesses like Angie Booth’s Valu-4-U reported nearly six months of lost trade and demanded compensation, which transport councillor Ian Ward said was under discussion, while noting prototype teething issues (now rectified electrical faults), approved ramp extensions to prevent scraping, and resolved seamanship shortcomings.

A multi-vehicle collision occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man at the scene; a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by careless driving, and the road between Thursley and Liphook remained closed until early evening while officers conducted their investigation.

Matching Models in London bills itself as an “international temp agency for beautiful and talented people,” advertising roles such as a personal assistant with a “classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup” and a “sexy female driver” earning £40,000–£50,000, prompting the Equality and Human Rights Commission and the Fawcett Society to condemn the ads as unlawful under the 2010 Equality Act and demeaning to women. Employment lawyer James Lynas warned phrases like “attractive” could mask age discrimination and expose employers to unlimited compensation claims, while founder Nathalie Jansen defended clients’ aesthetic demands—citing a “Jackie O” Dior outfit and a Greek blonde requirement—and highlighted over 5,000 placements worldwide for clients including MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, Renault F1 and Harrods.

The shooting took place at a hostel attached to Bangalore’s private Pragati Residential School when alleged gunman Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, allegedly barged into 18-year-old student Gautami’s room Tuesday evening and shot her in the head before shooting another student, Sirisha, who suffered severe but non-life-threatening injuries; Mahesh was arrested the next day after a manhunt and has been remanded until April 12. Such gun violence in Indian schools is extremely rare, the motive remains unclear, and while India enforces strict firearm controls, many local feuds are nonetheless settled with guns—echoed by a 2007 campus shooting near Delhi that killed a 14-year-old boy.

GLAAD’s Where We Are on TV study of scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series airing or cast-confirmed between June 2016 and May 2017 found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender representation more than doubling from seven to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters—among them Poussey Washington in Orange Is the New Black and Bea Smith in Wentworth—were killed off. The report also noted a record-high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, driven by shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. GLAAD president Sarah Kate Ellis called the increased representation “heartening” but cautioned that numbers alone don’t tell the whole story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South since 2015, announced he will not seek re-election after a BBC report revealed that about £10.25 million of public money loaned by the borough council—when he was council leader—to Northampton Town FC for rebuilding Sixfields stadium has gone missing and is now the subject of a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities; facing expected deselection by his local party and with the stadium project only half completed, he has denied any wrongdoing but said it is time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, 37, a former Balch Springs police officer, was charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault after he fired into a car leaving an underage-drinking party in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards and wounding four other teens. Oliver, who was dismissed days later for policy violations, remains free on bail; no trial date has been set and his lawyer has not commented. Officers had responded to reports of underage drinking and, upon hearing what they thought were gunshots, confronted the vehicle, but body-camera footage later showed the car was driving away, not reversing aggressively as initially claimed. Facing five to 99 years in prison, his conviction would be the first Dallas County police officer murder conviction since 1973, according to the Dallas Observer. District Attorney Faith Johnson said the case is being handled thoroughly, while family lawyer Lee Merritt noted it has been over 40 years since a Texas officer was convicted of murder. Edwards was remembered by his coach as “a checklist of everything you would want in a player, a son, a teammate, a friend.”

The president-elect says Melania Trump and their son Barron will move to Washington “after he’s finished with school,” a no-date timeline that has drawn criticism over the First Family’s delayed arrival at the White House—an absence otherwise seen only under Martha Washington and Anna Harrison—though supporters applaud prioritizing Barron’s education. Historically, some first families have lived off-site or postponed moves: Frances Cleveland resided at her “Red Top” home, Dolley Madison sent her son to boarding school, and John Tyler’s children stayed behind, while Chelsea Clinton and the Obamas relocated promptly (the latter moving early to avoid mid-term school changes). Melania, who remained in New York during the campaign to focus on Barron and has signaled interest in combating cyber-bullying, appears likely to adopt a more private, child-centered first lady role—possibly sharing duties with relatives such as Ivanka Trump—continuing recent precedents of balancing ceremonial and advocacy responsibilities with family privacy and routines.

The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service has asked the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner to examine Police Scotland’s initial response to a call from a 72-year-old man who was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October, and Police Scotland says it is fully engaging with the inquiry, after which the commissioner’s report will be submitted to COPFS.

A yellow wind warning has been issued for Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys, with gusts locally reaching up to 75 mph (120 km/h), particularly west of the mountains, and an unusual easterly direction expected to intensify impacts. Forecasters warn of likely disruptions to road and sea travel, and overnight winds downed a tree in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, blocking Telford Road, which will remain closed for most of Monday while debris is cleared.

Derrick Walser’s short-handed opener for the Giants was quickly cancelled out by Jeff Dimmen, and after Mike Forney’s second-period power-play breakaway put the Panthers ahead 2-1, Andy Bohmbach made it 2-2. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then pushed the Giants to a 4-2 lead before Nottingham’s David Ling replied, and the teams will meet again Saturday in the second game of their double-header. Nottingham tops the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers on 27 and Belfast on 25.

In an interview with Die Zeit, former Germany midfielder Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly revealed his homosexuality to spark debate in a sport that has long ignored the issue, becoming the most prominent footballer to come out; he was immediately praised by former teammates Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, Premier League figures like Gary Lineker and Joey Barton, Bayern Munich, and German FA leaders Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball. His announcement—seen as a watershed moment against homophobia—was further supported by Chancellor Merkel’s spokesman Steffen Seibert and openly gay MP Volker Beck, who hope it will embolden active players, overcome the silence deplored by Marcus Urban’s 2007 coming-out and counter earlier cautionary remarks by Philipp Lahm, ultimately paving the way for greater openness in German football.

Sidwell, 34, has featured 32 times this season to help Chris Hughton’s Brighton earn promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years and, with his contract expiring, is keen to sign a new deal, confident he can help the club stay up; he initially joined on loan in 2015–16 before signing a one-year deal in June 2016, has previously played in the Premier League with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke, and believes his performances—capped by Brighton’s win over Wigan that confirmed promotion and left them four points clear of Newcastle with two games remaining—justify another contract.

Blackpool and Colchester United played out a 1-1 draw in a match defined by fine finishes, crucial saves and a late red card: Nathan Delfouneso’s chipped pass set up Jamille Matt to open the scoring before Kurtis Guthrie bundled home from a corner after Sam Slocombe had denied Matthew Briggs, and Slocombe later thwarted George Elokobi while Guthrie struck the bar. Blackpool nearly won when Tom Aldred headed wide from close range, and Colchester were reduced to ten men when substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

Reid, 29, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One and has also had spells with Charlton, Bradford and Preston; he could make his Colchester United debut in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa after the U’s began the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington, and all the latest transfer news is on our dedicated page.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March prompted the UK Police Memorial Trust to appeal for £1.5 million towards a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, which will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff killed over the past 250 years. Sir Hugh Orde, the trust’s chairman, said the tribute—featuring a brass screen with leaf-shaped cut-outs to be given to families—must become part of national life, and Home Secretary Amber Rudd confirmed a £1 million government pledge towards the £4 million cost. The memorial is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United extended their lead at the top of the Premier League to 15 points with eight games remaining by defeating Sunderland 1-0, marking a club record 25 wins in their first 30 matches. Sir Alex Ferguson insisted the team will focus solely on forthcoming fixtures—most immediately the derby against Manchester City—after collecting 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 league games and eyeing Chelsea’s 95-point benchmark. He plans to rotate the squad for Monday’s FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson and goalkeeper David de Gea, and rested returning England players Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck and Tom Cleverley at Sunderland, while Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernández and Rio Ferdinand are available, and praised his side’s first-half performance and resolute defending against a determined Sunderland.

Google chairman Mr Schmidt told the BBC that Google paid the legally required £10 m in UK corporate tax from 2006 to 2011 and would comply with any changes in British tax law, arguing that taxes aren’t optional and should be set by politicians. Noting that most UK sales are routed through Ireland, he called for international tax reform so companies are taxed where they conduct economic activity and urged clearer, simpler rules. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed a secret committee to scrutinise major firms’ tax arrangements, and EU leaders agreed on automatic information exchange between tax authorities to curb avoidance.

NHS Improvement, alarmed that last year’s £3.6 bn spend on agency staff was slipping behind reduction targets, introduced an October cap limiting agency pay to no more than 55% above normal shift rates (excluding senior managers), which has saved £600 m so far toward its £1 bn reduction goal by the end of this financial year. The cap aims to curb reliance on costly agency staff—whose higher fees include agency charges and employer costs—yet trusts remain about 10% off target and it’s unclear if spending on other pay elements has risen. Current data exclude in-house “bank” staff and overtime; later this year NHS Improvement will publish league tables of agency-spending performance and details on each trust’s 20 highest-earning agency workers amid evidence of some quoting rates far above the cap, such as £130 an hour for a surgeon versus the £76 limit. NHS Improvement chief executive Jim Mackey warned that further action is needed.

Longford Town Centre, once hailed as a “cathedral of commerce,” now stands as a symbol of the Celtic Tiger’s collapse, but traders report cautious revival: Matt O’Brien’s men’s clothing shop, which suffered a 30% downturn and a layoff, has seen year-on-year improvement by adding childrenswear and a dress-hire service. Fianna Fáil’s Robert Troy criticises the Fine Gael-Labour coalition for investing €500 million in delayed water meters instead of boosting broadband and accuses the IDA of failing to attract investors for four years, while the government points to a planned €200 million Center Parcs resort in Ballymahon—projected to employ around 1,000 people by 2019 pending planning approval—as proof of its commitment. Local Fine Gael TD James Bannon highlights the region’s waterways and scenery to draw tourists, but merchants like O’Brien insist further support—such as free street parking—remains vital to cementing the early signs of economic recovery.

The tournament runs from 25 April to the final on 29 May at the same stadium, with eight teams playing each other twice in a double round-robin (mostly 15:30 BST, some 10:30) through 22 May before the top four contest Qualifier 1 (24 May), the Eliminator (25 May), Qualifier 2 (27 May) and the Final (29 May); BBC Sport provides full coverage, while leading performers include run-scorers Warner (294), Kohli (267) and de Villiers (249), six-hitters Warner and de Villiers (12), highest innings de Kock (108), wicket-takers McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8) and Rahman (7), and England internationals Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Billings (Delhi Daredevils) and Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants) all feature.

Since 2013 the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reports plastic carrier bag use has risen by 200 million, with many non-recyclable bags ending up in landfills and rivers and harming the environment. From October people in England will pay 5p per bag to encourage reuse, following Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland where similar charges have cut bag use, and campaigners hope the English charge will reduce waste and benefit the environment.

Friday, one of the busiest days of the festive-season Christmas getaway, coincided with a yellow wind warning across Wales until midnight, bringing gusts peaking at Mona on Anglesey that ripped off part of a school roof in Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, knocked out power to hundreds of homes, delayed trains with speed restrictions between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead, imposed lane and speed limits on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge, forced Irish Ferries to cancel six Holyhead–Dublin fast sailings (switching passengers to cruise ferries), and led the National Trust to close Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle; by Friday evening bridge restrictions had been lifted, but a blustery Christmas weekend forecast pushed Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip back to 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan said he’s “super excited” about his as-yet-undisclosed role in Black Panther, where he’ll reunite with Creed director Ryan Coogler and co-star alongside Oscar-winner Lupita Nyong’o (who also voiced Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens) and Chadwick Boseman (currently appearing as Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War). Jordan, who previously played the Human Torch in last year’s Fantastic Four reboot, looks forward to putting “a different spin” on his new character, and Black Panther is slated for release in February 2018.

Alexandra Palace’s 1875 theatre and adjoining BBC studios are set to be repaired and refurbished as part of a £26.6 m east wing restoration transforming the site into a cultural destination, with the glazed east court becoming public and exhibition space. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8 m and Haringey Council £6.8 m, while the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust aims to raise the final £1 m by summer 2017, targeting a 2018 reopening. The long-unused theatre, still featuring original decor and machinery, is intended for live performance, comedy, film screenings and music, continuing its historic role showcasing opera, plays, early cinema and other entertainments.

Former Manchester City midfielder Milner, aged 30, won 61 England caps after his 2009 debut and featured in two World Cups and two European Championships—albeit playing just three minutes at Euro 2016—and has announced his departure as “common sense,” wishing Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters success; he also holds the England Under-21 appearance record with 46 caps since 2004 and scored his only international goal in the 5-0 win over Moldova during 2014 World Cup qualifying.

Marcy Smith’s home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was rapidly consumed by flames one night after rubbish she burned in the wood stove ignited unexpectedly; her son David, who spotted the fire while on FaceTime with his father, woke the family in time for everyone to escape in their pajamas, though their dog and cats perished and the house was destroyed. The fire alarm never sounded, but neighbors have since donated clothing, shoes and even a bike for David, whose quick actions saved his mother and sister, earning his mother’s deep pride in his bravery.

An energy drinks firm reportedly considered a £200m offer for Premier League side West Ham United, whose majority stake was bought by Sullivan and Gold in 2010 for £105m and now account for over 85% ownership; since the team’s August move to the London Stadium, potential takeover interest has arisen from Qatari and Chinese groups, and last year Sullivan said selling a minority share to clear debts was possible while he and Gold planned to hand the club to their children.

At a fan-voted ceremony that doubled as a promotional platform for this summer’s blockbusters, The Fault in Our Stars swept the night—winning best movie—with Shailene Woodley also earning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award and best kiss, dedicating her speech to author John Green. Other winners included Bradley Cooper (best male performance for American Sniper), Channing Tatum (best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street), Meryl Streep (best villain for Into the Woods), plus Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his children, while Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award alongside his fellow Avengers, and clips were shown of the Pitch Perfect sequel, Judd Apatow’s Trainwreck and Marvel’s Ultron.

Northumberland County Council said the weather is now warm enough for its Jetpatcher machines to tackle potholes, aiming to fill about 145 holes each day over the next four months, while extra staff repair rain-damaged drainage systems and clear gutter debris.

Last December on EnQuest’s Thistle platform off Shetland, six Wood Group contractors—including rigging supervisor Steve Innes—were exposed to low levels of alpha radiation (NORM) while removing pipework during a shutdown; they lacked proper PPE because readings taken the night before had cleared the area, only learning of contamination two-thirds through the job, and now face ongoing blood tests and cancer fears. EnQuest says exposure was under 1% of the reportable threshold, that it notified the HSE, and has since strengthened control measures; Wood Group emphasizes its commitment to safety, medical assessments and a joint investigation; Unite calls for transparency on safety incidents, while the HSE, deeming the event non-reportable under RIDDOR, has not conducted a formal probe.

The Asian Civilisation Museum bought in 2007 for $650,000 a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari from New York dealer Art of the Past, but after manager Aaron Freedman admitted in a 2012 court case to dealing in looted Indian antiquities—including this piece believed stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu—the museum agreed, following a May request from the Archaeological Survey of India and talks with Singapore’s National Heritage Board, to return the item; although there’s no conclusive proof of its temple origin, it was one of 30 objects acquired from the dealer (none of the others are thought stolen), and the museum intends to pursue legal action for compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck at 15.5 km depth 35 km north of Lucca in Garfagnana at 15:48 local time, rattling Milan, Florence, Bologna and Modena, cutting power and phone lines, prompting school evacuations and producing several aftershocks, though no injuries or damage were reported. Italy, prone to seismic activity, has suffered almost 300 deaths in the 2009 L’Aquila quake and more than 20 fatalities in two magnitude-6 tremors last May, and the L’Aquila disaster led to the manslaughter convictions of six scientists and one official for underestimating pre-quake risk.

On 8 September 2016 (updated at 15:33 BST), gardener Austin Grant of Sheffield, aged 62, finally saw proof that South Yorkshire’s climate could produce fruit—still unripe and attached to the plant—and was “literally jumping for joy” at this long-awaited success.

Rockstar has pushed back the open-world title’s release from 27 January to 24 March to allow extra testing and polish, assuring fans the delay will be worthwhile; meanwhile, the eagerly awaited online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC launch. New PC screenshots showcase enhanced detail—1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution and support for triple monitors—and minimum system requirements have been published. Originally released on 17 September 2013, Grand Theft Auto V became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, earning $1 billion in just three days.

At 76, the artist won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery for Squint (19), a roughly 7ft-high portrayal of a medieval church’s leper squint that judge Ansel Krut deemed “quite extraordinary” and “technically…very subtle” despite its challenging appearance. Previously shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted on three other occasions, he intends to spend the prize money on canvases, stretcher bars and high-quality paints for his ongoing series, which includes larger works. Established in 1957, the biennial award is one of Britain’s oldest art prizes, with past winners such as David Hockney and Peter Doig and Sir Peter Blake now serving as patron.

Early Thursday, four masked assailants attacked Istanbul’s Yeni Safak building—setting a fire that firefighters swiftly extinguished—and almost simultaneously opened fire on the Yeni Akit offices 20 km away, shattering windows at both sites; no casualties were reported, police cordoned off the areas, recovered numerous spent casings and launched a manhunt, though no group has claimed responsibility, echoing last September’s pro-government assault on Hurriyet.

A 24-year-old ex-Burton player, previously under contract with the Stags and loaned to Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, will join Marcus Bignot’s Mariners on a free transfer on 1 January as Bignot’s first signing.

Arsène Wenger, whose Arsenal contract runs until summer, downplays speculation linking him to the England manager’s job and praises interim boss Gareth Southgate’s experience and chance to earn the permanent post via upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain, stressing that competency matters more than big names.
