Speaking before facing Swansea, Wenger also revealed plans to extend right-back Héctor Bellerín’s deal amid transfer interest and confirmed midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games with a hamstring injury.

A man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker at around 13:45 GMT on Thursday, and Lincolnshire Police, in collaboration with the Health and Safety Executive, are conducting a joint inquiry with the company’s full cooperation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced that from next month two freight vessels serving the Northern Isles, Hellier and Hildasay, will move from Seatruck’s charter to Serco Northlink under a new arrangement designed to end a dispute over seafarers’ pay after the RMT union claimed some crew were earning below £4 an hour. Seatruck had argued the UK national minimum wage did not apply to many non-UK resident crew, while Serco Northlink said it had repeatedly offered to bridge and backdate any pay shortfall, offers Seatruck declined. Subject to final financial and regulatory details, the new charter basis will guarantee all crew at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink, which has held a six-year, £243 million subsidised contract since 2012, operates three ferries and two cargo boats on the route.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an alcohol-fuelled incident at Rockley Park in Poole involving his long-term partner Samantha Mitchell, 57, and her son Jamie, 35, who intervened in an argument outside the holiday park bar; Jamie pleaded guilty at Winchester Crown Court to common assault and, along with his mother, admitted perverting the course of justice by initially lying to police about the confrontation, and both will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the British songwriter behind Heatwave’s Boogie Nights, Always & Forever and Groove Line, as well as Michael Jackson hits such as Off the Wall, Rock With You, Thriller, Baby Be Mine and The Lady in My Life, died in London last week at 66 after “a brief aggressive battle with cancer.” Nicknamed “The Invisible Man” for his low public profile, he credited early radio listening for his musical instincts, joined Heatwave in the 1970s after answering a Melody Maker advert, and was later recruited by Quincy Jones to write for Jackson’s breakthrough albums. He won a Grammy for Birdland in 1990 and earned two Oscar nominations for The Color Purple soundtrack. Colleagues including Nile Rodgers, Chaka Khan and Mark Ronson paid tribute, while his family has requested privacy following his private funeral.

Researchers including Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott of Swansea University, alongside teams from Exeter, Reading and Brazilian universities, have identified over 450 large, possibly 2,000-year-old ditched geoglyph enclosures in Acre, western Brazilian Amazon, previously hidden by bamboo until modern deforestation. These geometrical earthworks yielded few artefacts and don’t align with defensive or residential layouts, suggesting they were used sporadically as ritual gathering places, though unlike Maya pyramids they lay beneath a tall forest canopy. Soil analyses of phytoliths, charcoal and carbon isotopes also reveal 6,000 years of human-directed agroforestry—concentrating economically valuable trees in a “prehistoric supermarket”—whose legacy still shapes the region’s biodiversity.

Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian ranked a career-high world No. 12, defeated world No. 29 Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round, fresh off his Japan Open victory that’s pushing him toward the top 10; he admitted to feeling bored and tired—blaming late arrival, poor sleep and the long commute to Qi Zhong Stadium—and last year he was fined $1,500 for describing the Shanghai Masters as a “circus.”

Scientists and charities including Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru and Cardiff University’s HPV research team are calling on the Welsh government to extend its school‐based HPV vaccination programme—which has achieved 85% uptake among 12‐ and 13-year-old girls since its 2008 launch—to boys in order to curb rising head and neck cancer cases, particularly among younger non-smoking men (average age 55), and the government says it will await recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before deciding.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil diagnosed last August with a rare blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, documented his treatment and personal moments—playing tuba, visits with classmates and rugby players, meetings with Rangers stars and others—on a Facebook page called Jak’s Journey, which garnered over 28,000 Likes. In January doctors confirmed his cancer had spread and ceased further treatment, but he fought on, attending his prom for ten minutes and receiving his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. His story inspired widespread support, fundraisers for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research and visits from sports and theatre figures, and he died on Saturday, prompting heartfelt tributes from his family.

Egypt edged Uganda 1-0 in Port-Gentil thanks to Abdallah El Said’s 89th-minute finish from a Mohamed Salah reverse pass after a largely chance-starved contest on a deteriorating pitch. Uganda had seen Joseph Ochaya’s early strike correctly disallowed for offside and keeper Denis Onyango kept them in the game alongside veteran Egypt stopper Essam El Hadary, but neither side managed a shot on target until El Said’s winner. The victory keeps Egypt in the hunt for top spot in Group D ahead of Wednesday’s meeting with already-qualified Ghana, while Uganda, playing their first tournament since 1978, are eliminated and must beat Mali under specific conditions in their final match to stay alive.

Lancashire County Council has earmarked land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College’s unused Westbank campus for a new railway station after Network Rail compared these sites with one near the Concourse shopping centre. Under plans drawn up with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, Skelmersdale—whose original station closed to passengers in 1956—could see two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. Cabinet member John Fillis called the proposal an “exciting step forward,” noting the preferred site’s capacity for future expansion, strong highway access and good connectivity. The council, which owns the Glenburn site, will now begin acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, remains one of the largest towns in northwest England without its own railway station.
Police discovered an elaborate grow house filled with plants during a Saturday morning search of a warehouse near Ashbourne, and they arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

Police in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, say a 28-year-old German citizen of Kurdish origin was found late on Sunday lying on a pavement with serious injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets; she underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner from nearby Bad Münder, also a German citizen of Kurdish origin, later handed himself in and is now in custody. Prosecutors say the motive remains unclear, and police have cordoned off the area where the attack occurred and urged witnesses to come forward.

A study of 4,600 Australian workers from the 2013–14 workplace relations survey by Cass Business School, Warwick, and Wisconsin universities found that women ask for pay rises as often as men but, when compared like-for-like on full-time and part-time contracts and controlling for employer size, industry, parental status and qualifications, men are 25% more likely to receive them, offering no support for the “reticent female” theory; researchers also found no evidence women refrain from negotiating to avoid upsetting bosses, observed that under-40 men and women negotiate and win raises at the same rate, and concluded that some pure discrimination against women likely remains.

Oxford City Council has spent funds primarily on ground investigations for potential new burial sites but has not found any suitable land, with all council-owned sites dismissed due to size constraints, poor ground conditions, high water tables or restrictive covenants. Only two cemeteries—Wolvercote and Botley—still have space but are projected to be full by 2018 and 2021, after which only the reopening of family plots, a few reserved plots and ash interments will be possible. The council insists it is still exploring options, but, as board member Linda Smith notes, it has effectively run out of suitable land within Oxford, and the last expansion of burial space there occurred in 1932.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19 to 22 can use an augmented reality app to scan site signage and posters for videos, band interviews and other content on phones and tablets. Festival director Caroline Maclennan says the feature enhances onsite enjoyment and enables people worldwide to interact with the event, access updated information, buy tickets and capture its atmosphere. This year’s lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred gelding owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day. Although he had previously shown signs of post-race ataxia and overheating—issues for which he received treatment and close welfare monitoring—he displayed no such symptoms on Saturday, and investigators concluded his death was not linked to those conditions but to a rare racing haemorrhage. The British Horseracing Authority’s acting chief veterinary officer, Tony Welsh, noted these episodes are uncommon in horses without underlying health issues and pledged further research into their causes and prevention. Trained by Oliver Sherwood, Many Clouds had earlier won the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup and was lauded as a “horse of a lifetime.”

Davina Ayrton, 34—formerly known as David Ayrton and diagnosed with learning difficulties who changed her name in 2012—denies raping a 15-year-old girl she met in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004 but faces sentencing on March 4 after Judge Ian Pearson remanded her to a male prison in Winchester, citing substantial risks if bailed; during the trial Ayrton spoke about her sexuality, insisted she’d made no physical or medical transitions, and had attempted suicide last summer (prompting special detention protocols), while the victim—who had consumed only one and a half cans of Foster’s and clearly recalled shouting at Ayrton to stop as two friends slept—later heard Ayrton confess to the attack in 2014 to a care-home worker in Fordingbridge, Hampshire.

Serbian players fell 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, a day after world number one Novak Djokovic was beaten in the singles by Argentina’s Juan Martín del Potro; Djokovic, who had earlier suffered a surprise third-round Wimbledon loss to American Sam Querrey, rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 chainsaw carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US will compete this Saturday in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms, using only chainsaws to sculpt logs into animals and people, with last year’s winner Pete Bowsher of Moffat returning to defend the Claymore Trophy.

Since suffering a serious foot injury in a World Cup warm-up against Italy in September, 27-year-old Webb has been in a pre-season training phase and is close to returning after physios agreed to bring his comeback forward into early February. Wales begin their Six Nations campaign away to Ireland in Dublin on 7 February, giving the 16-cap fly-half time to regain full fitness, and he has renewed his national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union—having turned down other offers to stay with his home region, where he debuted in 2007—and remains determined to reestablish himself on the international stage.

US border agents patrolling five miles east of Sumas, Washington, on Tuesday morning intercepted two men—Jeffrey Laviolette and Nathan Hall—carrying backpacks containing 58 lb (26 kg) of MDMA smuggled from Canada to San Francisco; when ordered to stop one man dropped his pack, fired at agents and fled while Laviolette was arrested, and Hall was later captured by the Abbotsford, BC, police.  A false California driver’s license in the name of William Nickerson but bearing Hall’s photo was found in one backpack.  Investigators then arrested Bellingham residents Kali Henifin, who planned to pick up the couriers, and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, allegedly hired for $11,000 to drive the drugs south; both admitted they monitored police radio and fled after hearing of the shooting.  All three now face conspiracy, possession and distribution charges in a well-known smuggling corridor targeted by the US Attorney’s Office for the Western District of Washington.

The NSPCC’s Childline reported counselling over 4,500 children on online abuse last year—up from about 2,400 in 2011-12—and warns real numbers are higher; children as young as seven describe torment, fear of school and persistent online trolls. President Dame Esther Rantzen says cyber-bullying follows victims home, necessitating adult, parental and school intervention to prevent worsening abuse. Published for Anti-Bullying Week by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, the report outlines collaboration with parents, schools and other organisations, features a child’s testimony about suicide encouragement and shares young people’s advice on handling bullying.

Prince William, in a BBC interview on the eve of Queen Elizabeth II’s 90th birthday, celebrated her duty, tolerance and service as a guiding example while acknowledging press criticism of his own royal commitments. To mark her milestone, ten stamps—including a sheet depicting four generations of the Royal Family and designs highlighting her family life and official role—were released, and the Queen, with the Duke of Edinburgh, toured Windsor’s Royal Mail delivery office for the postal service’s 500th anniversary and officially inaugurated a new bandstand amid children’s birthday songs. On her actual birthday she will unveil a plaque for the 6.3 km Queen’s Walkway record trail, light the first of more than 900 beacons globally, and host President Barack Obama for lunch; republican campaigners decried the BBC’s celebratory coverage as unbalanced and disproportionate.

West Ham United defeated League Two Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup as Diafra Sakho opened the scoring from Sam Byram’s pass—his first goal since November—before Andre Ayew struck into the same corner moments later. Cheltenham, unchanged from a 3-0 league loss at Carlisle, enjoyed early chances through Harry Pell’s volley and Jordon Forster’s header but failed to seriously trouble keeper Adrian, while West Ham, making seven changes after Premier League defeats, saw further opportunities by James Collins and Byram, Angelo Ogbonna’s header cleared off the line and Sakho denied by Jonathan Flatt. The result ended League Two’s representation in the competition and marked a repeat of a narrow fourth-round win by Hammers four years earlier.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, was killed when 46-year-old Andreas Werner of Leipzig failed to spot his motorcycle as he turned his VW Transporter right on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates’ Court, was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. Prosecutor Sarah Marsh said the victim’s family, aware Werner was staying with his family near Bala, saw no value in a jail sentence, viewing the crash as a momentary lapse, and defence counsel Craig Hutchinson noted Werner’s remorse and lack of explanation for the collision.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall known online as Abu Daigham al-Britani, left the UK in January to join IS-affiliated Rayat al Tawheed in Syria, where he posted video diaries, appeals for donations and gruesome propaganda—including images of battlefield casualties and a severed head—before MI5 monitored him and last June, aided by his cousin Tahir Bhatti, he faked his own death online and attempted to re-enter Britain via Bulgaria; he was arrested at Dover, is held at Belmarsh in the high-risk unit and faces trial at the Old Bailey with up to a life sentence after admitting four offences, while Bhatti has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season as Wrexham finished eighth, but has turned down the club’s contract offer to become Barnsley’s third signing for next season ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley; caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom said Jackson “has pace to burn, likes to get at defenders and will fit in nicely to the way we play.”

Bottles of sealed—but reportedly leaking—detergent have washed up at Poldhu Cove on the Lizard and other nearby coves such as Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove and Marazion, prompting National Trust volunteers to clear them amid fears for wildlife. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirms that the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of Vanish detergent near Land’s End in May, but says there’s no conclusive proof the stranded bottles are from that incident. Cornwall Wildlife Trust has warned of the impact on sensitive marine life, and Cornwall Council, together with the National Trust, the MCA and Natural England, is monitoring the beaches, arranging removals and advising the public to keep children and dogs at a safe distance and not to recover any bottles.

A crash on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00 left several people with minor injuries, led to the closure of the road with diversions via the A897 between Helmsdale and Melvich, and is under investigation by Police Scotland.

Twenty-eight-year-old French centre-back Dorian Dervite made 14 appearances last season to help Bolton Wanderers finish second in League One and earn promotion; since joining from Charlton in 2014 he has featured 83 times in all competitions, and manager Phil Parkinson praised his excellent late-season contribution. Dervite has now signed a new contract with Bolton, following defenders David Wheater, Gary Madine and midfielder Jem Karacan in securing deals after the club’s promotion to the Championship.

Liberal Democrat and Labour peers, who had previously joined forces to block government proposals on EU citizens’ rights and parliamentary approval of a Brexit deal, fell out after MPs rejected their amendments; the Lib Dems pressed on while Labour deferred to the Commons, prompting Lib Dem Lord Oates to accuse Labour of conceding everything and Labour’s Baroness Smith to accuse the Lib Dems of offering false hope. A Labour source in the Lords called the Lib Dems’ stance grandstanding for campaign material, while Lib Dem Europe spokesperson Baroness Ludford retorted that Labour was effectively supporting a hard Brexit alongside the Conservatives. Although the two parties have historically allied on issues from higher education to housing, both sides now anticipate residual tensions even as they agree to maintain a business-like working relationship.

FC Barcelona has maintained it committed no offence in the Neymar transfer, insisting its original €57m (£48.6m) payment last summer covered all fiscal obligations but making a supplementary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to guard against alternative interpretations. The club’s total outlay on the 22-year-old Santos striker—including signing-on fee, wages over five years, agents’ fees and this extra payment—reaches £106.8m, with Neymar’s parents having received £34m of the initial fee. A Spanish judge has ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigating possible tax irregularities, and former president Sandro Rosell, who denies misappropriation claims, resigned amid the probe. This season Neymar has scored seven league goals and three in the Champions League.

Michael Luciw, 27, was killed and colleague Andy Harrington seriously injured when Albert Kenneth Newman, driving a Mazda Premacy the wrong way on the southbound carriageway near Kegworth on 12 October, collided head-on with their van; Newman also died. Luciw’s family—who remember him as a generous, kind-hearted new father—along with Harrington, are calling for mandatory medical examinations and practical driving tests for retired motorists, arguing slower reactions in older drivers pose serious risks. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must renew licences every three years via a self-assessment form without medical or on-road testing. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency insists it sees no evidence older drivers cause more accidents and has no plans to introduce age-based restrictions, while Age UK emphasizes the need to support older people to continue driving safely.

Over the past two decades, more than 20,000 Scottish women have received transvaginal mesh or tape implants to treat incontinence and prolapse, but hundreds have endured debilitating complications and over 400 have launched legal actions; in response, an independent review—criticized as “watered-down” by two patient representatives who resigned alongside a consultant—found these procedures should not be offered routinely, recommended that patients be given a range of treatment options with full information to make informed choices, and called for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Health Secretary Humza Yousaf confirmed the recommendations will be implemented despite campaigners’ calls for an outright ban, noting that prohibition lies with the UK Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. Meanwhile, review chair Tracey Gillies—who took over late in the process without consulting predecessor Lesley Wilkie—apologized for failing to secure panel consensus, and Professor Alison Britton has been appointed to examine how the review was conducted and identify lessons for future processes.

At 23, Laura Muir shattered Liz McColgan’s 25-year-old British indoor 5K record at Glasgow’s Emirates Arena in 14 minutes 49.12 seconds, prompting McColgan to express excitement but also question whether the solo, mixed‐distance event and absence of on-site drug testing met UK Athletics’ ratification criteria—concerns laid to rest by British Athletics, which confirmed the mark is expected to be ratified and noted no doping control is required for a British record. McColgan, who herself ran solo to break the record in 1988, praised Muir’s world-class potential, predicting she could lower her time towards 14 minutes 30 seconds and challenge the global elite, and pointed to Muir’s recent British 1500 m record in Paris and her appearance in the 1500 m final at Rio 2016 as evidence of her rising talent.

Michael Jung clinched the Olympic eventing gold aboard Sam, a late replacement for the ailing Fischertakinou, with France’s Astier Nicolas taking silver and America’s Phillip Dutton bronze; Britain’s 47-year-old William Fox-Pitt, riding Chilli Morning just ten months after an induced coma, delivered a flawless final show-jump yet slipped from his dressage lead into 12th following cross-country time penalties, and Ireland’s Jonty Evans finished ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray reached his 11th Wimbledon last-16 appearance by beating 29th seed Fabio Fognini in four sets (6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5) after 2h39m under fading light, saving five set points in the fourth to clinch victory at 20:57 BST; he will face Benoît Paire next while Fognini, hampered by an ankle issue and penalized for obscenity, showed flashes of brilliance but faltered. Earlier, Briton Johanna Konta also progressed to the second week for the first time with a 6-4, 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari. Murray described the tense, up-and-down match and, despite feeling off his best, welcomed the upcoming break to work on his movement and prepare for Monday.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, and police arriving shortly after found patrons still inside, with till receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49 BST. Limavady Magistrates Court ordered the bar’s closure for three months and charged licensee Colleen O’Neill, 43, with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours and James Thomas, 44, with one count. The defence admitted the premises had run into the early morning in breach of licensing laws. The judge condemned O’Neill’s “appalling record,” lamented his inability to impose a custodial sentence, and fined her £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt closed his party’s manifesto launch by declaring “domination doesn’t work, partnership does,” and sought to frame the election as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle, only for attention to shift onto his own comments about preferring to enter Stormont with the SDLP over Sinn Féin. When challenged about colleague Danny Kennedy’s public distancing, he joked that it proved Kennedy had been listening, insisted he had no regrets and would not withdraw a word, and said he was already thinking about post-election alliances. He reported positive feedback from door-knocking in unionist areas, expressed confidence in his candidates’ varied transfer strategies, and outlined the “Real Partnership” manifesto’s calls to tackle waiting lists, boost PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritize the York Street interchange, support the LGBT community and protect every group from Brexit impacts, while vowing to “clean up Stormont” and paint the vote as a choice against incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and corruption.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has secured executive agreement to table a legislative consent motion in the Northern Ireland Assembly that would replicate England and Wales’s “Turing’s Law,” granting automatic posthumous pardons and enabling living gay and bisexual men convicted of abolished sexual offences to apply for pardons. Aiming to align treatment of convictions in Northern Ireland with that in England and Wales and to correct past injustices more swiftly than through an assembly bill, the motion will now be considered by the assembly.

23-year-old Kinross native Laura Muir ran 4:19.12 to finish second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon, erasing Yvonne Murray’s 1994 Scottish 1500m record of 4:22.60 and moving to second on Britain’s all-time list behind Zola Budd (4:17.57). Already holder of the Scottish 1500m and mile records and fifth at last year’s World Championships, Muir opened her season with an 800m win in France, will run a 1500m in Stockholm next, and aims to secure Great Britain’s Olympic spot at June’s trials in Birmingham, all while completing her veterinary studies. Yvonne Murray sent her congratulations via Facebook.
The passage presents photographs from the 26 Scottish beaches that have been rated as “most excellent” for water quality.

Richard Horwell QC told the inquiry that although Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, the fact that he drank polonium-210–laced tea during their 2006 London meeting and died three weeks later “indicates” Russian state sponsorship, with plenty of reasons to wish him dead; he stressed this did not mean President Putin personally ordered the murder but suggested Litvinenko’s 2000 defection after accusing the FSB of corruption and his public attacks on Putin could be viewed as treachery, warned that the wider public health risk from polonium will never be known, noted Litvinenko was poisoned twice before his death, and said the suspects left a “trail of polonium” yet have offered no credible scientific explanation, though extradition has failed, they remain in Russia, Kovtun refused to testify, and the inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Following Michael Clarke’s retirement after Australia’s 3-1 Ashes defeat, 26-year-old Steve Smith—already the one-day captain and having led three Tests during Clarke’s injury layoff with 32 Tests for 2,952 runs at 54.66—has been named the ongoing limited-overs captain, with 28-year-old David Warner appointed vice-captain; national selector Rod Marsh praised Smith’s talent and Warner’s maturity despite past disciplinary issues, and the pair will lead Australia in the T20 and one-day matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval starting 20 August.

Farron repeatedly refused to say whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead asserting “we are all sinners,” while stressing his commitment to LGBT-plus rights, with defending equal marriage and extending transgender marital rights—specifically removing the spousal veto—“at the top of my agenda.” He insisted he’s “absolutely in favour of equal access under law for all people whatever their sexuality,” and explained his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill arose from concerns over individual liberties and a failed Lib Dem amendment.

Accord Healthcare is set to revive the former Sanofi drug‐manufacturing plant in Fawdon—closed in 2015 with the loss of 450 jobs—hoping to reemploy many ex-Sanofi staff; its investment, a spokesman says, will have an “extremely positive” impact on the area, a view echoed by Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes, who hailed the move as a major boost to the city’s and region’s science and healthcare profile; Accord, a global pharmaceutical company, develops, manufactures and distributes over 130 products to roughly 60 countries, and anticipates that bringing highly skilled jobs and long-term investment will strengthen the local economy.

Richard Ellis will depart on Friday at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are taking voluntary redundancy and early retirement, prompting SNP opposition leader Stephen Flynn to warn of broader staff retention issues and predict further exits. Ellis, formerly interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, Monaghan, head of the chief executive’s office, and Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, were thanked by council chief executive Angela Scott for their dedication and professionalism.

Four Islamic State militants stormed Kabul’s 400-bed Sardar Daud hospital at dawn by detonating explosives at the gate and opening fire on staff and patients, wounding over 50, before Afghan commandos landed on the roof and killed all four attackers after a six-hour battle. The attack, claimed by IS and denied by the Taliban, marked the first direct clash between IS fighters and security forces in the capital and prompted President Ghani and de-facto deputy leader Abdullah Abdullah to condemn the violation of a protected medical site. Observers say the operation—reminiscent of Taliban tactics—signals IS’s growing resources and training since declaring its Khorasan Province in 2015, despite remaining largely confined to eastern mountainous regions.

English rider Martin endured a crash at this year’s TT and ongoing mechanical woes with the Fireblade, prompting him to tell MCN he was quitting road racing—though he later clarified on Facebook that he still plans to race but won’t ride Hondas this year. He skipped the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness’s practice crash and won’t contest next month’s Ulster Grand Prix, telling the team after Cadwell testing that the bike wouldn’t be competitive and being quietly withdrawn. Having found the TT “a bloody disaster” apart from walking his dog and racing the Mugen, he says there’s no unfinished business and he now intends to focus on classics and oddball events.

The APC won 19 of 28 governorships in Saturday’s elections—its biggest gains since military rule ended in 1999 and following its first-ever presidential victory by Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May—while the PDP was reduced to a regional force, holding only eight states in the south-east and Rivers in the oil hub; Taraba remains outstanding and Imo was inconclusive amid spoiled ballots, and no polls were held in seven states. The APC swept key northern states (including Katsina and Kaduna) and regained Lagos for the president’s party for the first time since 1999, yet surprisingly failed to capture any of the five oil‐producing states, raising concerns about militant disruption to oil revenues. Although 66 violent incidents were reported, mostly in southern regions like Rivers, overall polls were calmer than in past elections, suggesting Nigeria’s democracy is maturing. The PDP, plagued by defections, corruption allegations and perceived failure to quell the Islamist insurgency, now faces a period of introspection and rebuilding under new leadership.

On 27 August 2016 (updated at 12:34 BST), after a new law permitted dogs to dine in outdoor restaurant areas, one eatery responded by introducing “puppy platters” for its canine customers, a concept showcased in a video clip depicting what looks like an elaborate dog-friendly meal.

Derby County forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful after a knee issue limited him to substitute appearances in the last two games, striker David Nugent could return from a groin injury after missing Monday’s draw with Huddersfield, and midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after coming off the bench to score a late leveller against the Terriers.

Pakistan lifted its Supreme Court–imposed YouTube ban after Google introduced a Pakistan-specific site and set up an online process for the PTA to request blocking of offending material, though YouTube says it removes content only if it breaches its community guidelines or is judged illegal after review and logs all government requests in its Transparency Report. The PTA directed ISPs to restore access, prompting operators to post “Welcome Back YouTube,” while activists demand transparency on the Google-government agreement. The ban originated in 2012 after the film Innocence of Muslims sparked deadly protests, and blasphemy remains punishable by death in Pakistan. Google has also launched local YouTube versions for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

FIFA’s Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee chairman Domenico Scala—a dual Swiss-Italian national like candidate Gianni Infantino—is under pressure from Liberian FA president Musa Bility to resign by Thursday under Article 7.4’s nationality-conflict clause, echoing Scala and Claudio Sulser’s 2015 recusal when Sepp Blatter stood, with Bility threatening a Court of Arbitration for Sport challenge if he refuses. Scala’s spokesman denies any conflict exists in a five-candidate race without an incumbent, while Bility—barred from contesting last year and now backing Prince Ali—insists on election integrity ahead of the 26 February presidential vote in Zurich between Infantino, Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman and Tokyo Sexwale.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area at Harford Attachments in Spar Road; their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon, and a forensic search at the digger-bucket manufacturer has yielded evidence suggesting a flashover explosion caused by a buildup of toxic fumes plus an ignition that produced a fire-ball effect. Det Ch Insp Paul Durham reports “significant progress” in forensic inquiries and witness statements, and the Health and Safety Executive has deployed inspectors and electrical safety experts to gather additional evidence.

Tunisia narrowly avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to CAF for its post-match protest over a disputed penalty that cost them a 2015 quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, while Morocco gained entry into the qualifying draw only after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned its ban and reduced a $1 million fine—both teams have since patched up relations with CAF leadership and, following last week’s Cairo draw, Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia and Djibouti in Group A and Morocco will meet Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé in Group F as they look ahead to the finals in Gabon.

Following Chelsea’s 3-1 victory at the Etihad, Manchester City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were charged after a 95th-minute brawl—Aguero received a four-match ban for a high challenge on David Luiz and Fernandinho a three-match ban for clashing with Cesc Fabregas, who faces no further action—Pep Guardiola apologized, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on December 8 to respond.

Wales and parts of the UK face some of the poorest cancer survival rates in the developed world, so a six-month pilot in Cwm Cynon—and a parallel clinic soon at Port Talbot—will allow 40 GPs to fast-track within seven days any patient they suspect of cancer despite lacking urgent symptoms to a diagnostic hub at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant. Inspired by Danish centres that proved successful after a study visit to Aarhus, the scheme aims to see about six such patients weekly and complete all relevant tests in a single day, addressing the current situation in Cwm Taf where only 35 percent of patients with “alarm” symptoms receive a diagnosis and nonspecific cases can be passed between specialists over weeks. Dr Gareth Davies of the Welsh Cancer Network and GP Gareth Jordan believe this streamlined approach will reassure patients, speed up diagnosis and, if effective, be rolled out across other health boards.

England levelled the series 1–1 with a dominant four-day victory at Old Trafford, declaring on 589-8 and 173-1 to record their second-biggest run win over Pakistan; Joe Root’s 254 and unbeaten 71, plus four catches and a wicket, earned him man-of-the-match plaudits from Vaughan, Cook and coach Bayliss, while Alastair Cook contributed 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan were skittled twice on a flat pitch, their “spirit broken” as only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq have passed fifty in the series so far, and captain Misbah bemoaned poor confidence and shot selection. Pakistan will face Worcestershire in a tour game before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August, as Vaughan cautions that the contest may yet remain very tight.

Warren Gatland will lead the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with interim coach Rob Howley and forwards coach Robin McBryde taking on head-coach duties for the third time after his 2009 and 2013 tours. The Welsh Rugby Union is finalizing assistant-coach appointments for the summer tour, with WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips expecting to confirm the full management team next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies says involving Welsh coaches on a New Zealand tour offers a rare development opportunity that will invigorate coaches and players, providing both the ultimate test and fresh inspiration for Welsh rugby.

Charlie Austin’s sixth-minute penalty gave Southampton the lead at the KCOM Stadium, but Hull City—despite losing strikers Abel Hernández and Will Keane to first-half injuries—were transformed by substitute Robert Snodgrass, who scored in the 61st minute and provided the cross for Michael Dawson’s headed winner moments later. Goalkeeper David Marshall made several key saves and Sam Clucas cleared a stoppage-time corner off the line as Hull secured a 2–1 victory, ending a six-game league losing streak though remaining in the bottom three. Manager Mike Phelan praised his players’ resilience and Marshall’s form, while Claude Puel blamed his side’s lapse in concentration after midweek Europa League action. After the international break, Hull visit Sunderland and Southampton host Liverpool.

A collision at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, killed a local motorcyclist while leaving the tractor driver uninjured; Lincolnshire Police have released no further details, appealed for witnesses, and closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction.

President Ivanov’s decision to halt an investigation into alleged abuses of power exposed by covert recordings—intended, he said, to “end the agony” before June’s early elections—has been denounced by both opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who called the move illegal and rallied hundreds in Skopje, and EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who warned it undermines the rule of law and jeopardizes Macedonia’s EU prospects. The crisis began in February 2015 when Zaev released tapes suggesting ministers discussed vote-rigging, murder cover-ups and the wiretapping of some 20,000 individuals; the government rejects these allegations and accuses Zaev of seeking to destabilize the country, a claim he denies.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Saturday’s match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley’s sacking, as Swansea pursue ex-Derby boss Paul Clement to steer them clear of relegation amid warnings that a return from the strengthened Championship would be tough. Promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after narrowly avoiding bankruptcy, Swansea built a reputation for possession-based football but, Curtis argues, have lost their way since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 exit and the golden eras under Roberto Martínez, Brendan Rodgers and Laudrup. Believing the current squad capable of survival, he ensures new signings—many of whom have seen the Jack to a King documentary—understand the club’s rise and the importance of maintaining its identity for the team and the local community.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after falling 3-2 to Leyton Orient despite Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona overturning Jay Simpson’s 2-0 lead, Armand Gnanduillet’s winner sealing their drop to the National League under John Still, who had previously guided them from the Conference to League One. The Daggers finish with League Two’s worst goal difference, 20 more conceded than last season, and have struggled offensively—40-year-old Cureton has nine goals compared to 20 in 2014-15—yet Still, in his third spell since December, insists he’ll push for immediate promotion. Orient, two points shy of the play-offs, moved closer under interim boss Andy Hessenthaler—who, after Kevin Nolan’s recent dismissal, stressed professionalism and fan importance—while Still lamented his side’s lack of organisation and discipline.

Steven Gerrard will return to Liverpool in February as a youth coach, his first role since retiring in November after a 19-year playing career that began with his 1998 debut and included Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup and three League Cup triumphs before leaving Anfield in 2015 for LA Galaxy. Manager Jürgen Klopp, who held a “good long chat” with the ex-England skipper, hailed the appointment as “wonderful news,” noting Gerrard’s ambition to become a manager and his readiness to learn. Gerrard—who had been linked with the MK Dons job but felt it came “too soon”—is currently working toward his UEFA A coaching licence, a requirement for managing in the Premier League.

Morton raced into a 2–0 lead when McManus scored on 15 minutes and Ross Forbes added a deflected second, Alloa’s Kyle McAusland pulled one back before half-time, but a second McManus goal and a late strike from Denny Johnstone sealed a comfortable home win.

Ofsted has found squalid conditions in three unregulated Birmingham schools that were closed amid an investigation of 18 mainly Muslim community centres in the Midlands, warning these are likely the tip of the iceberg and that children may face abuse or radicalisation. Any institution teaching over 20 hours weekly must register as a school, yet some exploit home-education provisions by operating illegal “flexi schools.” Running unregistered schools carries up to 51 weeks’ imprisonment, and ministers are consulting until mid-January on tougher oversight for providers teaching more than six to eight hours a week. A government-funded six-inspector team will pursue illegal schools across all religious groups, and the Education Secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases, with her consent required to proceed.

Lilliard Gin, housed at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, employs one of the UK’s smallest stills in a cowshed to produce a locally sourced, terroir-driven spirit using wild botanicals from the Teviot Valley. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes sees it as a springboard toward establishing the Scottish Borders as a distilling region, while John Henderson of Born in the Borders highlights its role as the first new distillery in nearly two centuries and a natural complement to the adjacent brewery. Named for the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor heroine Lilliard to evoke local heritage and its female-led team, the project underscores a commitment to local sourcing and regional flavor.

In August 2013 at Swithens Farm near Leeds, 51-year-old Gary Green—who had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints and was more than twice over the legal alcohol limit—reversed a tractor into farm worker Harry Whitlam, killing him. Prosecuted under health and safety law because the accident occurred on private land, Green admitted failing to ensure others’ safety and was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in prison. Whitlam’s mother, Pam, who worked at the farm café, said the tragedy had irrevocably changed their close-knit family and left her with only the day of the accident as a memory of her youngest son. HSE inspector Julian Franklin described the incident as “extremely tragic” and Green’s conduct as “reckless.”

An independent CAS ruling has lifted FIFA’s blanket ban on Uruguayan striker Luis Suarez—imposed after he bit Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini at the 2014 World Cup—allowing him to train with Barcelona and play in friendlies while he serves the remaining eight of a nine-game suspension in competitive internationals; his competitive club debut is expected against Real Madrid on 26 October. Barcelona will present Suarez at Camp Nou on Monday, and although it’s unclear if he’ll feature in that match, he’ll be available for Uruguay’s friendlies against Japan, South Korea and Saudi Arabia. CAS judged that barring all football activity was excessive, generally upholding the sanctions but permitting training, match attendance and promotional duties—rulings criticized by players’ union Fifpro for not reducing the ban in exchange for treatment—while Suarez’s lawyers and football lawyer Hannah Clipston argued FIFA’s punishment was disproportionate and misapplied. Suarez, who previously bit PSV’s Otman Bakkal and Chelsea’s Branislav Ivanovic and was banned for racially abusing Manchester United’s Patrice Evra, apologized nearly a week after the Chiellini incident.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won the wife-carrying race on 18 March 2014, beating Lithuanian Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa after a week of training on a nearby athletics track. Competitors must complete a 380-metre course that includes hurdling over haystacks, climbing a steep slope and dodging water pistols, and teams can consist of any gender or marital status. Rich and Anna will now represent at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Following George Osborne’s Autumn Statement that the paper tax disc will be replaced by an electronic monthly direct-debit system in October 2014, minister Stephen Hammond wrote to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges to reassure the DVLA’s roughly 5,000 employees that although reduced refunds and the withdrawal of tax discs will alter job roles and require retraining, any necessary staffing reductions will be handled through redeployment into growth areas rather than redundancies. Hedges, while disappointed by the prospect of fewer job opportunities, welcomed the benefits of direct debits and no longer displaying a tax disc and said Hammond’s commitment to redeployment would give comfort to worried DVLA staff.

Hungary’s foreign minister Péter Szijjártó told Reuters that EU institutions should not interfere with Budapest’s domestic measures on asylum controls, NGOs and higher education, rejecting any backtracking on the laws while citing Poland’s pledge to veto attempts to strip Hungary of its voting rights; the measures—including the forcible housing of asylum seekers in locked shipping containers, a higher education law that could force the Central European University’s closure and proposed NGO legislation stigmatising “foreign-backed” groups—have drawn EU objections, spurred mass protests and prompted warnings from Commission vice-president Frans Timmermans of pending sanctions under the bloc’s unanimous-voting rule.

A live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, directed by Bill Condon (Dreamgirls, the last two Twilight films), is due in US cinemas on 17 March 2017 and begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May; Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens the Beast, Luke Evans the villainous Gaston, Josh Gad Gaston’s sidekick LeFou, Oscar-winner Kevin Kline Belle’s father Maurice, and a star will play Mrs Potts, the housekeeper-turned-teapot originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film.

Adrian Gill, born in Edinburgh in 1954, overcame dyslexia to forge a journalism career beginning with art reviews in the 1980s and joining the Sunday Times in 1993, where his fearless wit and dazzling prose—often courting controversy, from disparaging the Welsh to recounting shooting a baboon—made him a leading columnist. Diagnosed in November with widespread cancers, he continued chemotherapy and wrote a final column on coming to terms with his illness before dying suddenly, prompting tributes from editor Martin Ivens—who called him the paper’s “heart and soul”—and colleagues such as Jay Rayner, Tim Shipman, Stig Abell, John Witherow and Andrew Neil, all praising his unique style, intelligence and compassion. Gill’s personal life included marriages to author Cressida Connolly and later Amber Rudd, with whom he had two children, and a 23-year partnership with Nicola Formby, to whom he became engaged and with whom he had twins.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, known as Amraa and lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly struck over the head with a bottle and kicked in the face during a performance in Ulan Bator, leaving him in a coma for about ten days; he had worn a red deel embroidered with a traditional Mongolian swastika—an ancient symbol of eternity predating Hitler—which his father and lawyer emphasized is not a hate emblem and denied reports he shouted “Heil Hitler.” The Russian embassy says it is investigating press and social media accounts of the assault, calling them distorted regarding date, participants and circumstances, while Mongolian police confirm the suspect—a Russian diplomatic officer—was not detained because the injury was not deemed serious but insists he must be investigated under Mongolian law. Tens of millions of Soviet citizens died fighting Nazi Germany, yet the swastika remains a part of Mongolia’s cultural heritage, even as it is sometimes adopted by far-right groups.

Campaigners from action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration opposing the airport’s expansion on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday, and have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted aerodrome area; they are due to appear in court on 19 August, and the Metropolitan Police said airport security will be reviewed.

Nick Selman’s patient 101 off 144 anchored Glamorgan’s total—his second first-class century after a run of low scores—while seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles exploited cloudy Cardiff conditions to make regular breakthroughs, Gloucestershire’s only notable reply being Aneurin Donald’s 36 off 30. Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten then scraped a consolation bonus point, leaving Gloucestershire’s second innings evenly poised at close. Leading in Jacques Rudolph’s absence, Michael Hogan saw Selman praise the slow, short-ball wicket for aiding his return to form, and Taylor applaud the bowler-friendly conditions and his off-stump strategy.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police after chatting with Tennessee’s Hope Line Crisis Centre and planning to file a false report to lure officers to the Dee Estuary so he could ambush and shoot them. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week, having made the threats on two drunken nights. Judge Niclas Parry, noting Hughes’s 2009 firearms conviction, remanded him in custody despite defense claims he never intended to kill himself or actually carry out the attack. Police concerns were heightened because he was on bail for firearms offences—charges of which he was later cleared. Hope Line provides confidential support and counselling.

Surrey recovered from 8-2 to post 255-7 thanks largely to a 130-run stand between Ollie Pope’s replacement Ben Foakes (90) and Tom Davies, then fast bowler Stuart Meaker’s three-wicket burst in nine balls turned Yorkshire’s chase as they were bowled out for 236 despite a fighting 68 from Tim Bresnan and 38 from Matthew Waite; Surrey skipper Gareth Batty praised everyone stepping up and the Davies-Foakes partnership for blowing the game open, while Yorkshire captain Alex Lees rued a lack of contributions in the top five when it mattered.

A 56 ft converted trawler, taking on water six miles west of South Stack, radioed Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST when its onboard pump failed; the RNLI lifeboat crew then fitted a pump and towed the vessel back to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old Scottish middle-distance runner and veterinary medicine student, has confirmed she will miss next April’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her final-year exams fall in May, making preparation impossible. Despite finishing fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the World Athletics Championships—where she set a 5000m outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 behind Hellen Obiri’s gold—she’s prioritising her degree, returning to university next week after a brief break. While disappointed to miss one of her few chances to compete for Scotland, Muir remains optimistic about targeting the World Indoor Championships in March, believes she still has scope for two or three more Olympic Games, and is pleased with her recent string of performances under a demanding schedule.

Robbie Savage argues that six months after Steven Gerrard’s slip costly loss to Chelsea, Liverpool are a long way from challenging for the title and must settle for fighting for a top-four spot, which would count as success. He blames Brendan Rodgers’s failure in the transfer market for replacing the 52 goals lost with Luis Suarez’s sale and Daniel Sturridge’s injuries—Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert and Fabio Borini lack the work-rate, finishing and high pressing that produced 59 first-half goals in 2013-14. Defensively they remain as vulnerable despite big-money signings, and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet does not assert himself enough. Savage outlines a balanced XI to face Chelsea but doubts Liverpool can match Mourinho’s champions, and he highlights Gerrard’s physical and mental battle at 34 to prove he still deserves a long-term future at Anfield.

The proposed £45 million campus at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock will combine primary, secondary and Gaelic schools with a childcare centre, and East Ayrshire Council plans to seek the McIlvanney family’s permission to name it after local-born writer William McIlvanney. Born and educated in Kilmarnock, McIlvanney became an English teacher after graduating from Glasgow University before leaving teaching in 1975 to write full time; he gained immediate acclaim with his first novel, Remedy Is None, and earned the title “Godfather of Tartan Noir” through works such as the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty and The Big Man, while also contributing as a poet, journalist, broadcaster and commentator on politics and sport before his death on 5 December.

An area of Gourock near the swimming pool was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon and residents within 500 m were advised to stay indoors with windows open while a river exclusion zone and a half-mile sea exclusion were enforced after a British sea mine dating from the 1940s or 1950s was spotted on Monday; the three-street evacuation and small-boat sailing ban disrupted Caledonian MacBrayne ferry sailings from Gourock and Rothesay, but Ch Insp Elliot Brown stressed it was precautionary with no immediate danger, and Lt Cdr Tim Castrinoyannakis said the mine’s deterioration and unknown explosive content meant it had to be moved to a safer location before disposal, prompting Inverclyde Council to thank residents and businesses for their patience.

UK Sport has allocated £345m across 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020—£2m less than for Rio—setting targets of 51–85 Olympic and 115–162 Paralympic medals after Team GB won 67 and 147 respectively in Rio. Cuts affect archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby and cycling (down £4m to £25.98m), while badminton lost all £5.74m despite a Rio bronze, drawing complaints of a “catastrophic impact”; judo received a slight increase. Seven new events—baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sport climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo and Para-badminton—await allocation from £9m still unspent. UK Sport chair Rod Carr and CEO Liz Nicholl defended the prioritisation to protect medal potential, sports minister Tracey Crouch endorsed the approach and team sports such as basketball, handball and volleyball continue to press for developmental funding.

Three Victorian hotels at East Cliff in Bournemouth—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood and the Ocean View—will be demolished by The East Cliff Project LLP to make way for a six-storey, four-star 90-room hotel and two assisted-living blocks (nine and seven storeys) with 122 apartments; English Heritage and 49 residents plus the Ancient Monuments Society objected, citing “severe harm” to the conservation area’s character, but the council’s planning board voted seven to three in favour, arguing it would boost tourism and improve living for older people.

Private Matthew Boyd, 20, of the Royal Gibraltar Regiment and originally from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was fatally beaten by 24-year-old Jake Vallely outside The Cellar bar in Brecon on May 8, after a seven-hour drinking binge during his infantry battle school training. CCTV footage showed Vallely punching and beating Boyd until he lost consciousness and then dragging his body away. Vallely’s friend Aaeron Evans, who left before the violence began, was cleared of manslaughter, and Vallely will be sentenced on December 8. Det Supt David Guiney called the attack “despicable,” while Boyd’s family described him as loving, loyal and full of potential and praised the community’s support.

Andrew Travers left Barnet Council by “mutual agreement” after an error saw voters turned away from all 155 polling stations because their names were missing from the poll list, prompting an independent investigation and a council review—due by the end of May and to be presented to the General Functions Committee—to assess the appropriateness of arrangements for the upcoming EU referendum. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will serve as interim chief executive, while the council apologised, offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents who questioned the fairness of the ballot, and Travers, praised for his three-and-a-half years in post, blamed electoral registration lists for the problems.

Gateshead opened the scoring when Josh Gillies fired a first-half free-kick past Cameron Belford, only for Wrexham’s Sean Newton to level shortly before the break with his own set-piece; early in the second half Ryan Bowman headed Jamie Chandler’s cross home for a 2-1 win. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his side’s improved passing and resilience after a disappointing first half, while Wrexham boss Gary Mills lamented his team’s second-half dip and missed chances.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014, updated on 1 October 2014, evaluates the social and economic welfare of those aged over 60 in 96 countries, ranking Norway first and placing Afghanistan last, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb venture aims to deliver global broadband—particularly to every school—via an initial 600-satellite constellation expandable to over 2,000, achieved through Airbus’s new high-volume, low-cost production lines in Toulouse and planned Florida factories, targeting three sub-$1 million satellites per shift using robotic trolleys and scaled supply chains. First launches of ten satellites are due next April, with further batches by November and more than 20 Soyuz rockets booked to deploy clusters at 1,200 km altitude, yielding about 300 satellites by early 2021, over 600 by 2022 and 800+ by mid-decade. With $1.7 billion equity raised and loan talks underway amidst competitors like SpaceX and Boeing, UK-registered OneWeb—licensed by the UK Space Agency—expects to boost the domestic space ecosystem and economic revenues. To mitigate debris risks highlighted by an ESA study, it commits to two-year de-orbiting via added hardware and chase-vehicle adapters, while acknowledging bespoke, gold-plated platforms will still be required for specialized deep-space missions.

Scottish Finance Secretary John Swinney warns that the UK government's spending review has placed unprecedented pressure on Scotland’s public finances, claiming cuts since 2010 and a further 4.2% reduction will leave its discretionary budget 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20, and pledges to protect schools, hospitals and policing despite what he calls the chancellor’s austerity obsession. The UK government responds that Scotland will receive £390 m more in spending next year (rising to £750 m including underspend) under a nearly £30 bn block grant, arguing this is a superior deal to independence, while Labour’s Jackie Baillie urges a long-term budget with real anti-austerity measures and alternative tax policies to the SNP and Tories.

Many people with severe disabilities who require two carers or a hoist find standard accessible toilets inadequate, so campaigners are calling for “Changing Places” facilities—12 m² spaces equipped with benches, hoists, toilets and sinks—to be made compulsory in large new complexes. Although BS 8300:2009 recommends them for venues like shopping centres, cinemas and stadiums, only 893 exist in the UK despite an estimated 250,000 people needing them. Families such as Lorna Fillingham’s and Alison Beevers’s recount the stress and social isolation of resorting to dirty floors or cars, prompting petitions and parliamentary evidence, while architect Vaila Morrison warns that non-mandatory guidelines are often ignored. Advocates aim to overcome financial and logistical barriers through building-regulation changes, and positive examples—like Arsenal FC’s retrofitted facility and ad hoc “pop-up” Changing Places at community events—highlight the benefits of inclusive design.

Italian consumer groups have lodged a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald’s of abusing its dominant market position by compelling franchisees to sign lengthy contracts and pay above-market rents and high fees, which they say limits competition, reduces consumer choice and drives up prices in franchised outlets; McDonald’s, whose franchisees operate 73% of its European restaurants and generated $9.27 billion in global franchised revenues in 2014, defended its risk-and-reward sharing model and support for franchisees, while the Service Employees International Union and European trade unions back the complaint and the Commission has said it will study the submission and may launch an investigation.

A billboard reading #prayforjosh was erected near the A2 in Holywood last week as part of a viral social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin of Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when doctors operating on his appendix at Belfast’s Royal Victoria Hospital discovered and removed a large primary tumour and five smaller growths. What began as a simple hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church—where Josh’s father serves on the pastoral staff—to encourage prayer and share family updates was shared 948 times, seen by over 79,000 people worldwide, and even prompted a mystery donor to fund the massive sign. Classmates, church members and strangers around the globe have since rallied behind Josh and his family as he continues his recovery.

The passage details a planned shake-up of the UK military estate that includes closing Brecon Barracks—home to troops since 1805 and the site where soldiers fought at Rorke’s Drift—which local MP Chris Davies denounces as disrespectful to its history and harmful to a region already facing high unemployment and reliant on military tourism. He has launched a petition against the closure, though no civilian or military jobs are thought to be at risk, and nearby Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school will remain open. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced that Wales will gain a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, while Cawdor Barracks will close in 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot in 2025. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supports the need to restructure but warns that base closures will bring prolonged uncertainty for those affected.

The House of Lords EU Committee warns that although Brexit offers UK fishers the chance to regain control over their waters—an idea that helped swing many coastal communities to vote Leave—the industry’s small economic footprint (0.5% of GDP, 12,000 jobs) risks marginalisation in wider negotiations and may force Britain to grant EU vessels continued access in return for zero-tariff market entry; because most commercial stocks lie in shared waters and the vast majority of UK catches are exported while much of Britain’s seafood is imported, scientifically based total allowable catches and co-operation with neighbouring states remain essential, and exiting the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy could fragment management across England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. Nonetheless, recent quota increases for plaice, haddock and prawns under the CFP and industry statements—including from the Scottish Fishermen’s Federation—signal optimism that full control of the 200-mile exclusive economic zone could deliver fairer catch shares and more sustainable fisheries management for coastal communities.

Edward Snowden, a 29-year-old ex-CIA contractor, revealed that the NSA collects massive amounts of individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, social networking data and millions of Verizon phone records, and that its Prism program allegedly provides “backdoor” access to servers of nine major tech companies—Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube and Apple—though those firms deny involvement. NSA officials and President Obama defend these measures as essential to national security, while experts question their true scope and transparency, citing FISA and the Patriot Act’s broad authority over both domestic and foreign cloud data. UK and EU officials have expressed support or concern, there is no legal opt-out for users, and privacy groups warn that participation in global tech services exposes everyone to US surveillance, a reality Snowden said compelled his disclosures.

OpenAI—backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys and Amazon Web Services—plans to conduct AI research free from financial obligations with a focus on positive human impact. While Musk and Stephen Hawking have warned that unchecked AI could pose an existential threat by redesigning itself and outpacing biological evolution, other experts consider such risks remote. OpenAI’s mission is to advance digital intelligence in a way that benefits all of humanity, distributing it broadly and safely as an extension of individual human wills, and it will use only a small fraction of its $1 billion pledge in the next few years.

Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, seriously wounded in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack that cost him his speech, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June with crutches and an assistant. Since then he’s received over 5,000 Facebook friend requests—hitting the site’s limit—and been urged to switch to a public page or subscriber feature. Now speaking unaided, he devotes 12 hours a day to gym and rehab, raises funds as patron of Pilgrim Bandits, and has been buoyed by phenomenal public support via messages, mail, website visits and torch-relay invitations during the 8,000-mile, 70-day journey to London’s opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate held at 15%, leaving 46.2 million Americans in poverty after three consecutive years of increases, while real median household income fell by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a four‐person family was $23,021 (Â£14,300). Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, rose 1.6%—its first annual increase since 1993—and the share of Americans without health insurance fell to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty had peaked at 15.1% in 2010.

Lancashire have extended wicketkeeper-batsman Jos Buttler’s contract until 2019 after he joined the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013; the 25-year-old short-format specialist, who holds England’s three fastest ODI centuries—including a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan—has been lauded by cricket director Ashley Giles for his match-winning role in last year’s T20 Blast final and his positive dressing-room influence. Buttler, currently playing for Mumbai Indians in the IPL, will return for Lancashire’s upcoming T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, Campbeltown, Chatham and Cornwall—are moored in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting bids (registration closed on 23 January), with viewings in late February and March and a decision due in spring. The government’s Disposal Services Authority wants at least one sold to a UK ship recycler to assess domestic dismantling capacity, while Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt supports recycling but hopes one vessel can be preserved as a tourist reef and diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to secure the best financial return but declines to comment on bid details for commercial reasons. Originally designed for anti-submarine warfare, the Type 22 evolved into powerful multi-role combatants with advanced command, control and communications systems and crews of around 280; last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap for £3 million.

Since 1987 Fiji has endured racial and political strife that triggered coups in 1987 by indigenous Fijians, 2000 by George Speight, and 2006, severely damaging its economy—particularly tourism—and prompting international isolation and a 2009 suspension from the Commonwealth until free elections in 2014 restored ties. Its population, concentrated on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, comprises indigenous Fijians—now a slight majority—and Indo-Fijians, descendants of Indian indentured laborers, who maintain deep social segregation alongside small minorities such as Chinese and Rotumans. Economically, Fiji relies on sugar and tourism alongside mining of gold, silver, and limestone, a robust services sector, and light manufacturing, yet persistent trade and budget deficits make it one of the world’s largest per capita aid recipients.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad told the BBC that Syria, while missing the deadline to hand over its 1,300-tonne declared chemical arsenal, is “committed” to destroying it on schedule despite two shipments being fired on en route to Latakia and “war conditions,” and has rebuffed US Secretary of State John Kerry’s criticism of barrel-bomb attacks in Aleppo, where activists report hundreds of civilian casualties; state media also denied rebel claims of capturing Aleppo’s central prison amid continuing fighting. Only about 4% (30 tonnes) of its chemical stockpile has left the country, prompting US and Russian concern that the UN-OPCW disarmament plan is behind schedule.

Mukherjee’s The Lives of Others is the 5/2 favourite to win this year’s Booker Prize—the first time the award is open to any author writing in English—when the winner is announced at London’s Guildhall on Tuesday. The six-strong shortlist features former winner Howard Jacobson (J), which imagines a future where society bans discussion of its past; Mukherjee’s Calcutta‐set family drama in 1967; Inverness-born Ali Smith’s How to Be Both, a dual narrative spanning Renaissance Italy and the 1960s; Joshua Ferris’s New York dentist satire To Rise Again at a Decent Hour; Karen Joy Fowler’s college-aged narrator in We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves (the best-seller with over 55,000 copies sold); and Australian Richard Flanagan’s WWII love story The Narrow Road to the Deep North. Fowler and Ferris have sold markedly more since the shortlist announcement—Mukherjee’s weekly sales jumped from 97 to 507—prompting debate, voiced by professor David Brauner, over literary merit versus “readable” fiction. Now in its 46th year and judged by a panel chaired by AC Grayling, the prize shortlisted authors each receive £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book.

PJS, whose spouse and children are in the public eye, is appealing to the UK Supreme Court after the Court of Appeal lifted a media anonymity order in England and Wales; the Supreme Court has imposed an interim injunction preserving his privacy until it decides whether to hear and dispose of his appeal. The Sun on Sunday seeks to publish allegations that PJS had occasional sexual encounters dating back to 2009, including a three-way in December 2011 with parties AB and CD, which they offered to the paper in January. A High Court judge initially refused an injunction, the Court of Appeal then granted anonymity but later removed the ban, ruling that widespread publication in the US, Scotland and online meant confidentiality was “probably lost” and that securing a permanent injunction was “a hopeless task.”

Fosse Park, which opened in 1989 near junction 21 of the M1, was bought in August for £345.5 million, and its new owners are working with Blaby District Council to resolve planning issues and tackle parking, traffic congestion and the tired appearance of units; council leader Ernie White stressed the park’s role as the city gateway and the need to improve views of “backs of sheds,” while Crown Estates director Paul Clarke said they aim to upgrade common areas, parking facilities and overall quality.

The live-action Beauty and the Beast remake’s scheduled Malaysian release was delayed by Disney for a content review after it emerged the film features an “exclusively gay moment” in which LeFou grapples with romantic feelings for Gaston; the Malaysian Censorship Board has since granted it a P13 rating and approved the film with a minor edit to that scene but no new release date has been set, prompting cinemas to offer refunds for advance tickets, while critics—including the tourism minister and social media users—have condemned the review and potential cut as unnecessary or hypocritical given the country’s strict laws against homosexuality.

Landlords in Southampton letting properties to more than three unrelated people must hold a House of Multiple Occupation licence—a regime rolled out in 2013 (Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling) and 2015 (Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, Bassett)—but many avoid the roughly £1,000 fee despite fines up to £20,000, resulting in an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs. Shelter’s Nadeem Khan says tenants frequently report eviction worries and poor maintenance amid a shortage of affordable regulated housing, generating about five to six calls to the helpline each day. The council reports that while most landlords comply, a small minority resist, and it has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil leader Micheál Martin are negotiating to avoid a second election, with Fianna Fáil offering to facilitate a minority government but refusing to endorse its programme; water charges remain the chief obstacle—Fianna Fáil demands immediate abolition while Fine Gael insists on retaining them, leading to a proposal for a commission on Irish Water’s future—and nearly two months after the election, the Dáil’s composition (50 Fine Gael, 44 Fianna Fáil, 23 Sinn Féin and seven Labour) still falls short of a majority and no taoiseach has been elected.

The Sorrento, owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione and en route to Valencia, caught fire on a car deck about 27 km off Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon, prompting distress signals at 13:50 local time. Despite initial hopes to contain the blaze, the fire quickly intensified, forcing a full evacuation onto lifeboats; several ships, including the ferry Puglia, rescued all passengers and crew. Three people were injured—with one seriously hurt—and airlifted to hospital. Rescued travelers are being returned to Palma de Mallorca, where psychologists are awaiting to provide counselling, while Spanish authorities warn that the badly damaged ferry may sink and the cause of the fire remains unknown.

The Electoral Commission said 38 MPs had highlighted alleged double voting, including students, and warned that the 381 fragmented local registers and the separate online registration database—between them processing 4.9 million applications from 1 December to the 22 May deadline but yielding only a 1.4 million net increase—allowed an estimated 30–70% of duplicate entries, placing significant burdens on officials. Record registration reached 46.8 million for the 8 June election (up half a million on 2015 and exceeding the 46.4 million for the EU referendum), with a 68.7% turnout, highest since 1997, spurred by 2.9 million applications in the six weeks after the snap-poll announcement. Several student-dense seats saw electorates climb by more than 10%. The watchdog urged clearer online guidance, a verification feature (as used in Australia, New Zealand and Ireland), cross-checking of registers, and advance voting-venue choice for dual registrants, while Labour’s Cat Smith cautioned against measures that might disenfranchise young or student voters and called for adequate police resources to prosecute any offences.

Officials believe 40-year-old Lawrence Phillips, once a star University of Nebraska running back and NFL player for the Rams, Dolphins and 49ers in the 1990s, killed himself early Wednesday while serving over 30 years in prison for assault convictions—including driving his car into a group of teenagers and attacking a former girlfriend—and held alone after being accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward, a case a judge recently ruled had enough evidence to go to trial; his former coach Tom Osborne noted that despite Phillips’s intelligence and talent, he struggled with anger issues.

Private Derby XXX, the Mercian Regiment’s official Swaledale ram mascot, was promoted to lance corporal for “good behaviour” by Brigadier Andrew Williams at a Chester event marking the regiment’s eighth anniversary.
