He is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the first Private Derby acquired by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot in 1858 and adopted by the Mercian Regiment in 2007; Derby XXX joined in February 2014, holds his own army number, receives pay for his rations, takes holidays on Derbyshire’s Chatsworth Estate during mating season, and has helped switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William at a memorial unveiling for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool overturned a 2-0 home deficit to beat Borussia Dortmund 4-3 on aggregate in the Europa League quarter-final at Anfield, with goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho and a last‐minute Dejan Lovren header. Manager Jürgen Klopp, invoking the spirit of the 2005 Champions League comeback, galvanized players and fans with his passionate touchline leadership, turning doubt into belief in the face of a high‐class Dortmund side led by Thomas Tuchel. The win propelled Liverpool into the semi‐finals and closer to Champions League qualification, showcasing attacking strengths while exposing defensive weaknesses at left‐back, and underscored Klopp’s identity-driven era, including his ban on touching the “This Is Anfield” sign until a trophy is won.

Mr Davis said that after the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee meeting in London the UK government will hold monthly “two-way” meetings with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland to share analysis and allow the devolved administrations to voice their views as Westminster prepares talks with Brussels, and described the first session as constructive and amicable; Mr Russell welcomed the process but insisted the UK government still must clarify its strategic intentions—particularly whether it will remain in the single market or customs union, which he called essential for Scotland’s prosperity—and while ministers hope to overturn the High Court ruling on triggering Article 50 in the Supreme Court next month, the Scottish government, led by Lord Advocate James Wolffe, intends to oppose the appeal.

At the University of Nottingham’s Sutton Bonington Campus, veterinary surgeon Dr Sandra Corr and developmental biologist Prof Kevin Sinclair are conducting hands-on joint exams, X-rays and full-body fMRI scans on 13 cloned sheep—including Daisy, Debbie, Denise and Diane, the identical twin sisters of Dolly—to detect crepitus, lameness or osteoarthritis and determine whether cellular “age-memory” from an adult donor accelerates aging. Prompted by Dolly’s death at six-and-a-half from lung lesions and osteoarthritis, the study focuses on cardiovascular disease, diabetes and osteoarthritis as key age-related co-morbidities; now nearing nine and ten years old, the Dolly clones appear in robust health, with full results due next week.

John Gosden’s unbeaten favourite Shutter Speed, eased over the soft course after he walked it, won the Musidora Stakes by 1¾ lengths from Vintage Folly, giving Gosden and Frankie Dettori their fifth success in the race; Dettori praised her class but expects her to improve on firmer ground, and she will head to Chantilly for France’s Oaks over 1¼ miles rather than the Epsom Oaks—where stablemates Enable and Coronet are leading contenders—allowing a month’s preparation. Meanwhile, William Haggas’s outsider Tasleet (14-1) claimed the Duke of York Stakes for Jim Crowley, beating Magical Memory and Comicas, and Gosden is weighing whether to run his colt Cracksman in Thursday’s Dante Stakes—just 16 days before the Derby—due to concerns over the going and tight schedule, planning another course walk before deciding on the Derby trial.

The pound wavered in volatile trading, initially slipping before mid-afternoon recovery and later falling again, with the volatility index reaching heights last seen during the 2008 financial crisis. With ten days to the EU referendum, weakening polls for Remain (Betfair’s implied Remain probability falling from near 80% to 68.5%) and global economic jitters spooked investors: sterling dropped 0.2% to $1.4226, 0.6% to €1.2605 and 1% versus the yen, while hedge funds short-sold anticipating further declines. Analysts warn that close polls will heighten currency swings. Asian markets fell sharply (Japan’s Nikkei down 3.5%, Hong Kong’s Hang Seng down 2.5%), and London’s FTSE 100 ended 1.1% lower at 6,044.9, with Lloyds Banking Group down 4.2%. Leave campaigners highlighted that sterling has risen since March and argued a weaker pound aids exporters, and April’s trade figures showed a narrower UK deficit thanks to a jump in exports.

Braintree Town sit sixth in the National League, one point and place shy of the play-off positions, after falling to Barrow—who extended their unbeaten league run to nine—following a six- to seven-hour journey and conceding inside five minutes; despite this third consecutive defeat, manager Cowley praised his part-time squad’s remarkable campaign so far, acknowledged the difficulty of their challenge and vowed to embrace and enjoy the remainder of their season.

From April 2015, Northern Irish councils will assume expanded responsibilities—from off-street parking to tourism—and, most controversially, final decision-making on local planning applications, a role currently held by the Stormont Planning Service; supporters such as PLACE director Michael Corr argue this democratises planning by allowing locally tailored community and development plans, while critics warn of repeating 1960s housing-allocation discrimination and fostering favoritism due to close developer-politician ties. Friends of the Earth’s James Orr urges a rigorous code of conduct and full transparency in political donations to safeguard fairness, amid debate over donor-declaration thresholds and awaiting the Northern Ireland Secretary’s timetable for new disclosure rules.

One-year-old Teenie was found on 14 March in Winchburgh with two shoulder shots and one through her left back leg, which vets amputated, leaving her learning to hop around her home; her owner, Sarah Nisbett, and the Scottish SPCA called the three shots “crazy” given the housing-estate setting. Scottish SPCA chief superintendent Mike Flynn said the incident underlines the urgent need for airgun licensing, echoing the Scottish government’s recent consultation—rejected by 87% of respondents as too “draconian”—which would require prospective owners to prove a legitimate reason to possess an air weapon and help police trace irresponsible users, and urged anyone with information to come forward.

A study of 671 state and independent schools commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablets, with 9% operating a one-to-one pupil–device ratio and projections for device numbers to grow from 430,000 in 2014 to almost 900,000 by 2016 as 45% of non-users plan to introduce them; despite head teachers reporting that tablets motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement, researchers found no clear evidence that tablet use improves academic attainment or can be isolated as a cause of better results. A separate National Literacy Trust and Pearson study highlighted that touchscreens particularly help boys and poorer pupils learn to read, and Ofcom data show that around 70% of five- to 15-year-olds have home tablets, two-thirds of pupils take internet-connected devices to bed for social media or videos, and, in fully tablet-equipped schools, a quarter of secondary pupils consider themselves internet “addicts.” At Honywood Community School in Essex, head Simon Mason argues that providing each pupil with an iPad—portable, always on and school-owned—reflects modern life, fosters a sense of empowerment and trust, and aligns education with the real-world use of technology.

The Museum of Liverpool’s Growing Up in the City exhibition presents 25 photographs spanning the 1880s to the 1990s that trace a century of childhood and social history in Liverpool, from the 1887 portrait of Florence, George and Gertie Rollo in fancy dress at Stone House for the Mayor of Bootle’s ball to an early-1900s image of a young maid at work, illustrating both play and hardship. Curator Kay Jones sifted through hundreds of postcards, photographs and glass-plate negatives in the National Museums Liverpool collections to choose images that resonate with universal childhood experiences while highlighting how life on the city’s streets has changed; the show runs until 25 September.

The Gulls have strengthened their National League squad by signing 27-year-old centre-back Myles Anderson—an ex-Aldershot, Exeter and Italy veteran who left Barrow by mutual consent and could face his former club on February 18—and 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating—formerly of Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps—whose move, recommended by Micky Adams, awaits international clearance; manager Kevin Nicholson hailed Anderson’s leadership and Keating’s hunger as his side, currently four points above the relegation zone, seeks to improve on just one win in their last six games.

The new Bolivian law, passed by Congress and signed by Vice-President Álvaro García Linera in President Evo Morales’s absence, permits 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, toughens child-protection penalties—setting a 30-year maximum sentence for child homicide—and is designed to reflect Bolivia’s poverty-driven reality. More than 500,000 children already work in roles from shoe cleaning and street vending to hazardous mining and agriculture, and the socialist government hopes the measure will balance domestic needs with international treaties and help eradicate extreme poverty. While the International Labour Organisation recommends a minimum working age of 15 (or 14 in developing countries), it is currently reviewing Bolivia’s legislation for compliance with global child-labour standards.

O'Donnell, 50, said she began experiencing chest aches, nausea and fever at her Nyack Village home after helping a woman from a car, then Googled “women’s heart attack symptoms,” took aspirin and the next day had a cardiologist insert a stent into an artery that was 99 percent blocked in what she called a “widow maker” attack. In a blog entry titled “my heart attack,” she revealed she hadn’t called 911 immediately and urged women to recognize heart-attack warning signs, and she noted that her daily talk-and-gameshow, The Rosie Show on OWN, was recently cancelled due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a 16-year-old from Harrow, was fatally stabbed around 00:30 GMT in an alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate after attending a well-run party in Kenton where he had not been involved in an earlier fight with youths denied entry; he died about an hour later. A second 16-year-old was also stabbed and remains in stable condition. Police have arrested a 21-year-old man on suspicion of murder, two boys aged 15 and 16 on suspicion of murder (both bailed until mid-December) and a 14-year-old on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon, and are appealing for witnesses.

Denmark overhauled its cancer-diagnosis pathways after survival rates lagged behind other European countries by introducing three routes—a fast-track for “alarm” symptoms with strict time targets and a 30-day legal referral deadline, multidisciplinary diagnostic centres for patients with vague or hard-to-diagnose symptoms, and “yes-no” centres for minor‐symptom cases requiring quick tests or scans. This model, studied by a Welsh team in Aarhus, has streamlined cooperation between GPs and specialists, slashed wait times from months to hours for some, caught the 25% of cancers that present atypically and led to improved survival without overwhelming existing resources, offering lessons for similarly structured systems like Wales.

On 31 March 2014, following the UK government’s decision to disband the OFT, Powys council won a competitive bid to take over enforcement under the Estate Agents Act for £170,000 a year, gaining powers to issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest agents; members of the public will continue to complain to their local trading standards department, which will prosecute offenders if necessary or refer suspected breaches to Powys, where James Munro will lead the new team and hopes to demonstrate the council’s capacity to secure further external contracts.

NHS Employers has approved a plan, based on a Nuffield Trust review, to train and deploy its wider workforce—such as nurses stepping in for hospital doctors and pharmacists assisting GPs—to help fill junior doctor rota gaps and cope with rising patient numbers, while aligning with a shift towards long-term condition management. The Nuffield Trust highlights existing pilots and urges investment to implement changes, with author Candace Imison and NHS Employers’ Danny Mortimer citing improved care and staff roles as benefits. However, the BMA’s Dr Mark Porter insists enhanced support must not undermine doctors’ lengthy training or expertise, and Unison’s Christina McAnea warns against using workforce development as a low-cost shortcut to address chronic staffing shortages.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot after a crash at 03:00 GMT, and the ensuing A36 closure—lifted at 14:00 GMT—caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services; investigations are under way into how the collision happened, and First has resumed parts of its network but expects it will take a few hours to restore full service by the evening commute, thanking staff and the public for their support and understanding.

Natural Resources Wales estimated that the proposed £1.3 billion Swansea tidal lagoon would kill 21 percent of salmon and 25 percent of sea trout each year based on its best available evidence, a figure Tidal Lagoon Power has challenged for lacking a clear scientific basis and for which it says NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP’s own computer modelling suggests a worst-case scenario of just 2 percent fish mortality and views the project as a pilot for larger lagoons at Cardiff, Newport and Colwyn Bay. The UK government is reviewing the scheme’s viability, while Wales’s Environment Secretary, Lesley Griffiths, has expressed strong support but sought prompt clarity on Whitehall’s decision. NRW, surprised and disappointed by TLP’s criticism, maintains it has shared extensive data and methodology over 18 months, had its analyses vetted by independent and in-house experts, and stands by its figures to fulfill its legal duty to protect Wales’s environment.

Stormont’s Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster announced that the Agri-Food Strategy Board will develop a new industry-led marketing body for Northern Ireland’s agri-food sector—employing nearly 100,000 people across farming, fishing, retail and distribution—and modelled on Scotland Food & Drink to give strategic leadership to both public and private sector marketing. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the move as key to export-led growth and better coordination of current marketing activities, while noting it could affect other organisations, including her own department, and saying she looks forward to discussing it with the AFSB.

Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley will host a public tree-planting session this Saturday, organised by the Woodland Trust as part of its four-year campaign to create four new UK woods and plant millions of native trees in memory of WWI casualties. At Brackfield, 40,000 trees will honour the 40,000 people from Ireland who died in the conflict, with saplings supplied by the charity and volunteers asked to wear stout footwear. Situated seven miles from Derry city off the Glenshane Road (limited parking available), the site will eventually feature carpets of wildflowers—including poppies—alongside thriving wildlife habitats and paths for visitors to walk, relax and reflect.

At Harrogate’s annual crime writing festival Hilary’s debut thriller Someone Else’s Skin, introducing DI Marnie Rome in a tightly written, emotionally powerful narrative tackling domestic violence and honour crimes, won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award, praised by judge Alison Graham and programming chair Ann Cleeves for its atmospheric storytelling. US author Sara Paretsky, creator of female PI V.I. Warshawski—portrayed by Kathleen Turner in film and radio—and a pioneer of strong female protagonists, received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career and for founding Sisters In Crime to support women in the genre.

Mitchell Santner, 24, suffered a broken finger in only his second game for Worcestershire in 2016—a setback director Steve Rhodes described as a huge blow to their qualification hopes—and the left-arm batsman and spinner who made his Test debut in 2015 will rejoin the Rapids after June’s ICC Trophy in England, hoping to make up for lost time, while in August Worcestershire also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

Barry Pring, 47, was fatally struck by a speeding car with stolen licence plates that failed to stop as he tried to hail a taxi on a Kiev dual carriageway in 2008. Exeter coroner Dr Elizabeth Earland recorded an unlawful killing verdict, finding overwhelming circumstantial evidence despite investigative challenges abroad. His wife, 28-year-old Ganna “Anna” Ziuzina—who had returned for a missing glove before the crash—soon claimed his assets, sold his Range Rover, emptied his bank accounts, lied about her occupation and was revealed to be having an affair, prompting family and friends to allege a staged hit-and-run for inheritance. Ukrainian police closed then in 2011 reopened the case as a murder inquiry; it remains active but not actively pursued.

Sophie and Rob Fearns’s son Charlie from Litherland, Merseyside—who has been ill since age three and suffered a third relapse in April after an initial T-cell transplant failed—urgently needs further experimental T-Cell Therapy available only at Seattle Children’s Hospital. With all UK treatment options exhausted, the family was left heartbroken until an anonymous donor specifically offered to cover the full cost of his treatment. They received financial clearance via email on Wednesday and expect to begin the therapy as soon as next week.

Following reports that hackers used third-party tools like Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker to steal celebrities’ iCloud photos, Apple has extended its opt-in two-step verification to cover iCloud backups, requiring unfamiliar devices to supply a username, password and a four-digit code sent via SMS or the Find My iPhone app; without the code, users are blocked from iCloud and store purchases, though they can regain access with a 14-character recovery key. Elcomsoft’s owner now admits his software can no longer enumerate linked devices or download backups and praises Apple’s new email notifications for backup downloads, but warns that recovery keys are hard to remember and could be stolen. Security experts argue that two-factor authentication should be enabled by default across major platforms, and Apple says it will more aggressively encourage users to adopt two-factor authentication and stronger passwords, with CEO Tim Cook stressing the need to raise awareness.

Dan Groves said the finer points of a deal that could see 30-year-old Wright buy 20% of Billericay and become a director are yet to be released; currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points off a play-off place, the club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who invests £10,000 a week, and in March signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Following a BBC investigation into Sports Direct’s Derbyshire warehouse working practices, the BIS select committee chair, Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, has given owner Mr Ashley until 21 March to agree to public evidence at Westminster on low-paid worker treatment and national minimum wage enforcement; despite initially inviting the committee to his Shirebrook base, he has declined a series of offered Westminster dates, prompting a warning of potential contempt proceedings. Sports Direct has not commented, and the company had previously pledged a worker-rights review under Ashley’s oversight.

After Boris Nemtsov’s assassination, his allies led by Ilya Yashin completed the Russian-language dossier “Putin. War,” which compiles facts published since the 2014 annexation of Crimea to argue that President Putin secretly wages war in eastern Ukraine for personal gain. Though Russia denies sending regular troops—calling any fighters “volunteers”—the report cites volunteer testimonies and documented unit names, photos of weaponry and Russia’s 53 billion–rouble expenditure to show that Russian army units under generals’ orders secured all major separatist victories and that volunteers earn $2,000–3,000 a month. With families of fallen soldiers too frightened to go public and publishers too wary to print more than 2,000 copies, the opposition is seeking donations to expand distribution, even as many Russians who know of their country’s involvement still view it as justified. They accuse Putin of masterminding the conflict to shore up his flagging popularity, though previous Nemtsov exposés likewise failed to galvanize mass protests.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday; a post-mortem determined the 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearne died from head injuries, and South Yorkshire Police have arrested a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman in Sheffield, both of whom remain in custody.

Wales’s first minister, Carwyn Jones, has protested that he and the other devolved administrations were neither shown nor asked to help draft Theresa May’s Article 50 letter, calling it “unacceptable” and symptomatic of a “deeply frustrating” lack of respect, while Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered that ministers have been briefed repeatedly and that the UK government must act for the whole UK—hence Wales’s specific mention in the letter. In that letter to Donald Tusk, May pledges to consult fully on which repatriated powers should reside in Westminster versus Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland and says she expects a “significant increase in the decision-making power” of each devolved administration. However, key questions—exactly which powers will be devolved, whether funding will follow and what the timetable is—remain unanswered, though a white paper on the Great Repeal Bill due soon may shed light.

Two cars were damaged on Friday night in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry when PSNI officers carrying out duties were attacked; Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the “mindless attacks” on officers and the community, and the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page urged parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

American Apparel’s board, in a San Francisco court filing responding to founder and ex-CEO Dov Charney’s defamation suit, said he was ousted last year amid employee complaints and accusations of fund misuse and will never return; they presented evidence of illicit emails to female staff, racially derogatory taunts and repeated breaches of the company’s sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies, arguing any board would find him too risky, while Charney’s lawyer denounced the disclosures as false and a shameful privacy invasion.

BBC Sport will stream Great Britain’s home game against Greece at London’s Copper Box on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app from 17:30-19:30 BST, offering GB a chance for revenge after a 92-64 defeat in Patras earlier this month and with three Greek players unavailable. Stratford-born guard Teddy Okereafor said playing in London will boost the team’s EuroBasket 2017 preparations, and several players will debut in front of a home crowd. This match is Britain’s only home warm-up before beginning EuroBasket qualifiers in Istanbul in September, after which coach Joe Prunty’s squad will head to a four-team tournament in Poland as their final tune-up.

A BBC reporter recalls scrambling to borrow Phil Schiller’s iPhone prototype at the 2007 Moscone Centre so he could film it for a news segment, defending its prominence on air by likening its impact to the Model T Ford, and later realizing that comparison was apt as the iPhone’s intuitive interface sparked the smartphone revolution—putting powerful cameras and computers into billions of hands, transforming photography and mobile activities through instant sharing, and ushering in today’s mobile-connected era.

The RSPCA confirmed that at least five cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire—including seven-month-old Meereen, who returned home shivering, was found foaming at the mouth behind the sofa, and died three days after vets diagnosed antifreeze poisoning—have ingested a toxic substance over the past two weeks, though it remains unclear whether the incidents are accidental or deliberate; inspector Andy Bostock has urged residents to store antifreeze and other chemicals safely, check for leaks, and clean up any spills.

Despite gearing up to embrace more austerity and liberalisation measures under a third €86 billion bailout from the eurozone (and possibly the IMF), Greeks have not protested and tourism is surging—with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals—suggesting a lull before the full terms of the deal become public. Alexis Tsipras, who once decried such measures, has apparently bowed to creditors after July’s bank closures forced Syriza into a “there is no alternative” stance, yet he retains popularity despite failing to end fiscal cuts. Meanwhile, partial bank shutdowns have created a credit squeeze that threatens Christmas orders and deepens the economic vice tightening around ordinary Greeks. For this bailout to deliver true recovery rather than mere capitulation, Berlin and Brussels must couple relief from painful austerity with meaningful debt forgiveness.

Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell in a brief EastEnders return to reunite with his on-screen mother, Peggy Mitchell, after Dame Barbara’s character announced her cancer has returned and will be killed off in emotional spring scenes. Kemp, who first played Grant from 1990-99 and again in 2005-06, said he could not refuse the chance to bring the Mitchell brothers together, while executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins described the storyline as an opportunity to show Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best.

Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon stalked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles before fatally attacking her last October, and at his trial in Newcastle Crown Court he was convicted of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. When officers informed her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, of Alice’s death, they immediately recognized Dhillon’s involvement. Dr Hills later expressed guilt for reassuring Alice two days earlier that the police would handle the situation and for dismissing her sister Emma’s warning that Dhillon posed a deadly threat, while Prof Ruggles said none of them had realized how serious the stalking had become. In Alice’s memory, her parents have founded the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking dangers and celebrate her vibrant, cheeky personality.

The new England and Wales online divorce form prominently requests the name of any person with whom a spouse is alleged to have committed adultery—a feature family lawyers warn will add unnecessary conflict and complexity despite guidance clarifying there is no obligation to supply such details. Previously, naming a “co-respondent” was optional, but the updated form’s presentation makes petitioners likely to fill in the box, which turns the third party into a formal co-respondent who receives court paperwork, can respond, and may delay proceedings and increase costs. In 2015 there were just over 100,000 divorces—12,148 for adultery and 46,815 for unreasonable behaviour—and lawyers report that although many clients initially want to involve the new partner, judges generally view attempts to embroil third parties unfavourably.

British ministers, concerned that environmental policies have overshadowed commercial timber production and given the UK’s status as the world’s third-largest wood importer, are urging woodland creation investments, particularly in Wales where conifer forests—once the backbone of a £450 m-a-year industry—have lost 16,000 hectares since 2001. With forests split evenly between Natural Resources Wales and private owners, tensions arise over ministers’ push for native broadleaf species, public access for walkers and cyclists, and conservationists’ view that commercial forests harm wildlife, while remote locations and timber transport through rural communities create further conflicts. The Welsh government’s Glastir scheme and Woodlands for Wales strategy seek to balance environmental, economic and social goals, but industry body Confor argues that bureaucratic hurdles have limited new planting to just 90 hectares last year against a 20,000-hectare annual target, despite strong market demand.

A boy was badly injured after being struck on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School in Coatbridge at about 16:40; emergency crews took him to Glasgow’s Queen Elizabeth University Hospital, where he is believed to be in serious condition.

After initially blocking them under its foreign‐medal rules, the British Foreign Office granted an exception in 2013 so that Defence Attaché Capt. Oleg Kornienko could present Russia’s Ushakov medals—normally awarded for naval courage—to Arctic convoy veterans during President Putin’s London visit; among the honorees was 91-year-old Able Seaman Charles Lewis, who said he and his fallen comrades were merely “doing our bit” on what Winston Churchill called “the worst journey on earth” as they braved U-boats, aircraft, storms and ice floes to resupply the Soviet Union, a campaign that sank 104 merchant and 16 naval vessels, cost over 3,000 Allied lives, and was later also commemorated by Britain’s own Arctic Star in 2012.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found widespread delays and inconsistency in enforcing unpaid work orders—ranging from 40 to 300 hours of “community payback” for offences such as theft or criminal damage—with some offenders let off attendance requirements (one completed only 16 hours in 17 months); its review of 100 cases and interviews with 86 offenders highlighted organisational failings in managing chaotic lives, despite examples of high-quality work and offenders’ positive attitudes, leading to 15 recommendations (including reducing turn-aways, tailoring objectives to individual circumstances and improving enforcement), all of which the Ministry of Justice has accepted and is acting on to ensure timelier attendance and consequences for non-compliance.

The passage describes how The Sun criticized comedian Russell Brand as a hypocrite for advocating economic and political revolution on behalf of the poor while living in a spacious, luxury London home. During a protest at Downing Street in support of threatened east London estate tenants, a reporter questioned Brand about his own rent, prompting him to call the journalist “a snide” and walk off. Although Brand did not respond to Newsbeat’s inquiries, he has tweeted about the paper’s accusations under #TheSunLogic. He has previously acknowledged that his wealth and fame attract charges of hypocrisy, accepting the need for personal change and wealth-sharing but arguing that only systemic reform can truly address rising inequality and ecological crisis.

Dr. J. Craig Venter transformed genome research into a high‐stakes race—first by automating and then by shifting focus from entire DNA blueprints to RNA transcripts—to accelerate gene sequencing, which led him to leave the NIH in 1992 and found the private Institute for Genomic Research (TIGR), where he published the first complete genome of a free‐living organism, Haemophilus influenzae, in 1995. In 1998 he launched Celera Genomics to map the human genome in three years alongside a slower public effort, and when both published in 2001 his businesslike approach and closed data practices drew sharp criticism even as they reshaped the field and enriched him. Born in 1946, Venter’s Vietnam service instilled in him a sense of urgency that fueled his subsequent molecular‐biology breakthroughs, and in 2006 he established the J. Craig Venter Institute to pursue creation of a synthetic life form—Synthia—published in Science, while also leading the Sorcerer II ocean expedition to catalogue marine microbial genomes and explore industrial and environmental applications of engineered microbes.

An online survey of about 1,000 parents, including 628 whose children eat school lunches, found that four in five English schoolchildren tried foods at school they hadn’t at home and half of parents said their children later asked for those foods to be cooked at home; carrots, sweetcorn and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were the least. Commissioned by the School Food Trust after a Mumsnet poll suggesting parents saw their children as too fussy for school meals, the study supports Trust chairman Rob Rees’s view that school meals help broaden children’s diets and Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton’s observation of positive peer pressure and healthier options. School lunches in England now adhere to strict nutritional guidelines, with about 40% of primary pupils (slightly fewer in secondary) and 46% of Scottish pupils eating them.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old, 6ft 3in striker who rose through Real Madrid’s ranks—debuting at 18 and scoring 10 La Liga goals over four seasons—joined Juventus in 2014 under a deal granting Real a buy-back option worth up to €30 m; over two years in Turin he scored 27 goals, won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, appeared in consecutive Champions League finals (as a substitute in Real’s 2014 win and scoring in Juventus’ 2015 loss), and has netted three times for Spain at Euro 2016 amid reported interest from Arsenal and Chelsea.

Wilson, 30, rejoined Championship side Nottingham Forest from Celtic in August 2013 for £2.5 million, making 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground after having spent four seasons there before his move to Celtic; he has also played for Preston North End and Notts County and has been without a club since his release in May.

Tesco has agreed to sell its loss-making US food chain Fresh & Easy to private equity firm Yucaipa, transferring about 4,000 of its 5,000 employees to the new business and closing the remaining 50 of Fresh & Easy’s 200 stores; as part of an “orderly and efficient exit” from the US market Tesco will extend an £80 million loan, absorb a £150 million disposal cost (part of which may be repaid), and retain an option to reacquire a stake should Yucaipa, led by Ron Burkle, return the business to profitability, following a year in which Tesco reported its first annual profit decline in two decades.

He initially faced racial abuse but overcame it and, after briefly considering representing France, is now aiming to win a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics; those interested in starting martial arts can consult the special guide.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s French Alps glaciers covered about 375 sq km, falling to roughly 340 sq km by 1985–86 and to 275 sq km in the late 2000s—a 26 percent loss over 40 years—according to a new inventory by Marie Gardent et al. presented at the AGU Fall Meeting. Assessing some 600 glaciers across the Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, Grande Rousse Arves and Mont Blanc massifs with map archives, satellite and aerial imagery plus manual checks for debris and shadows, the study finds southern massifs (Belledonne, Ecrins) have retreated far more than northern ones. La Mer de Glace now measures just over 30 sq km (versus 31.5), and similar accelerated losses are reported in Swiss Alps research.

Scotland’s women’s team, unbeaten in five Euro qualifiers, host fellow unbeaten Iceland at Falkirk on Friday—where a win would virtually secure automatic qualification—aiming to avoid the play-off defeats of Euro 2013 and last year’s World Cup bid; 24-year-old Bayern Munich forward Evans, alongside veteran goalkeeper Gemma Fay and a 20-strong squad featuring 12 players plying their trade abroad (including BBC Women’s Footballer of the Year Kim Little), highlights the emotional stakes and the competitive edge gained from overseas experience, with a return fixture in Reykjavik on September 20 set to decide who tops a group in which the six best runners-up also auto-qualify for the Netherlands finals.

Stuart Campbell, the Bath-based blogger behind Wings Over Scotland and former computer games reviewer, was arrested in western England after a south London woman complained of two years’ worth of online harassment via tweets; he was released on bail until mid-September. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating allegations of non-threatening tweets made public over the past two years. Campbell insists the tweets were neither serious nor threatening, accuses the media of “innuendo” and “wildest speculations,” notes all posts remain publicly visible, and has warned he’ll be posting less frequently for reasons “totally outwith my control.”

Peta has proposed replacing Skegness’s long-standing Jolly Fisherman mascot—with roots in a 1908 Great Northern Railway poster advertising seaside breaks under the slogan “Skegness is so bracing”—with a fish bearing the slogan “Skegness – A Happy Plaice,” arguing that the cheerful fisherman nonetheless evokes animal cruelty through images of fish being hooked and crushed in nets; Skegness mayor Carl Macey, while open to suggestions, says the mascot is beloved by adults and children alike, does not appear cruel, and “if it isn’t broken we won’t try and fix it.”

Scotland recovered from an early Vasil Lobzhanidze try to dominate Georgia, posting six tries—by Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (twice) and Hamish Watson—backed by Greig Laidlaw’s conversions and a penalty, and maintaining 91% first-half possession; Georgia’s only further scores were two Merab Kvirikashvili penalties and a second Lobzhanidze try generated by a powerful scrum that also earned Kote Mikautadze a sin-bin and saw Scotland’s Moray Low yellow-carded, while coach Vern Cotter praised his side’s pragmatic game management and continued improvement.

Widnes took a 14-6 half-time lead over Castleford through first-half tries by Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van and Chris Bridge (Paddy Flynn replying for Cas on loan), and although Flynn scored again early in the second half to narrow it, further efforts from Ah Van, two from Lloyd White and one from Joe Mellor pushed Widnes into a 38-12 lead; three late Castleford tries by Larne Patrick, Luke Gale and Flynn’s hat-trick made for a nervy finish but the Vikings held on for a fourth successive away win, moving above Wakefield into seventh in the league as Castleford suffered their fourth straight home defeat to remain sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti held at Guantanamo since his 2002 arrest in Pakistan on alleged al-Qaeda and Taliban ties—which he denies—was released after a US Periodic Review Board found he no longer posed a significant threat; he boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and, under the terms of his release, will spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center. Having challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court, al-Odah said he had gone to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. His release—the first since May’s exchange of five Taliban detainees for US Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl—reduces Guantanamo’s inmate population to 148, as President Obama renews his pledge to close the facility opened after the 9/11 attacks.

Infectiously catchy earworm “PPAP” was performed by animal print–clad DJ Piko-Taro (fictional character of Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka) and features childish lyrics fusing a pen with an apple and a pineapple set to an addictive beat and simple dance; Kosaka says he came up with it spontaneously while playing with the music. After debuting on his YouTube channel it amassed over 4 million views and a 9GAG Facebook repost drew more than 44 million, sparking amused, baffled and annoyed reactions—some likening his look to an anime character—yet it has seen little coverage in Japan. Dubbed the “next Psy,” it has inspired hundreds of fan tributes and covers ranging from vines by Japanese duo Riko and Rika to a heavy-metal version and a take by Thai star Happy Polla.

Thousands gathered for dawn services at Hyde Park Corner and Westminster Abbey and around 400 marched in a parade before wreath-laying at the Cenotaph to mark Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle of Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One. First observed in London in 1916 when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service a year after the Gallipoli landings, the ceremonies now draw expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders to honour their countrymen’s sacrifices. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer reflected on the troops’ courage at dawn on the Gallipoli peninsula, and the event ended with prayers by schoolchildren and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand and the UK.

Clarkson, 30, rejoined St Mirren in July for a second spell and may debut against Alloa in Saturday’s Championship match. Having scored nine goals for Dundee last season, he has featured mainly as a substitute this term but says he’s at peak fitness after playing U20 games and training hard. A two-time Scotland international with one goal and nearly 400 senior club appearances for Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers, he aims to help his eighth-placed side build confidence through wins and climb the table.

Food tycoon Ranjit Boparan has bought the turkey firm Bernard Matthews and, after talks with Unite’s regional officer Steve Harley, guaranteed that all existing pension agreements—including the alternative scheme replacing the closed 2004 final-salary plan—will be honoured; Boparan’s private office confirmed current pension arrangements will continue, and the new owner plans to restore profitability through fresh investment, cost savings and by using spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkeys.

At a council scrutiny meeting, leader Dave Stewart announced that Cowes ferry crossings will be free until 2 July and an auditor review launched after the new chain ferry’s "frustrating and disappointing" launch—marked by breakdowns, groundings, an MCA suspension over training issues and vehicle damage; local businesses report lost trade and seek compensation, which transport councillor Ian Ward says is under discussion, while noting prototype teething problems have been addressed through electrical fixes, ramp extensions and improved seamanship.

The House of Lords EU Committee warns that Britain’s small fishing sector—just 0.5% of GDP and 12,000 jobs—which overwhelmingly backed Brexit to escape the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), risks being sidelined in negotiations, as shared stocks and dependence on exports to and imports from the EU mean tariff-free market access may require allowing EU boats into UK waters. The report urges retaining science-based total allowable catches and cross-border cooperation to avoid four separate UK regimes, while many fishers, encouraged by new EU quotas and control of a 200-mile EEZ, believe Brexit offers a chance for sustainable growth and fairer quota shares.

Timothy Geaney admitted taking or permitting images of partially clothed young boys in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014, received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register and ordered to attend a special programme for sex offenders. At a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, his conduct was deemed fundamentally incompatible with teaching, reflecting a lengthy pattern of behaviour likely to recur given the volume of images and lack of remedial action. The panel found him unfit to teach, removed him from the professional register and barred him from reapplying for two years; Geaney, who was 69 at sentencing, was not present at the hearing.

After a blaze on 2 March at the Duncan Street site run by Asset and Land Group through Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, firefighters spent several days tackling the fire, which disrupted train services and caused travel delays. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service—having visited the premises nine times in the past year and found the operators “broadly compliant” with fire-safety legislation—had alerted the Environment Agency to potential risks to residents, transport and the environment. As a result, the EA revoked the company’s environmental permit effective 7 August (subject to appeal), prohibiting further operations and requiring removal of all waste. The fire’s cause remains undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad insisted that Syria “is doing its best” to meet UN- and OPCW-mandated deadlines to destroy its roughly 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons—even though it missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile and only about 4% (30 tonnes) has so far left the country—while blaming “terrorist groups” for twice intercepting a weapons shipment en route from Damascus to Latakia. He rejected US criticism of barrel‐bomb attacks in Aleppo, despite UK-based and local observatories reporting scores of civilian casualties and footage of bombs dropped on Masaken Hanano, and accused Washington of supporting terrorists. Damascus also denied rebel claims of seizing Aleppo’s central prison—still contested according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights—where up to 3,000 detainees were held. Russia has urged Syria to finish moving its chemical arsenal to the coast by 1 March, with all weapons to be destroyed by end-June, a timetable that US Defence Secretary Chuck Hagel warned was already slipping.

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is gathering accounts from pensioners, their families and friends to inform her review of older people’s quality of life and care in Welsh residential homes, using the evidence to shape recommendations for care providers and public bodies.  Having toured Wales and noted both excellent and unacceptable care standards, Rochira will assess factors such as residents’ physical and psychological health, social relationships and living environments, and will consult care providers, staff and public bodies to ensure decision-makers understand daily realities and necessary improvements.  Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, welcomed the review’s goals but criticised the omission of anyone with direct care-home experience from its main advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, 39, has been appointed to Aberdeen’s staff by manager Derek McInnes—replacing Neil Cooper at Pittodrie—after a thorough recruitment process, leaving his post as player-manager of Arbroath’s Red Lichties which he had led since 2010. Under Sheerin’s guidance Arbroath captured their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division in 2011 and secured promotion, though they were relegated to League Two after the 2013-14 season. A former Dons midfielder and Scotland Under-21 international in the mid-1990s, Sheerin enjoyed spells with several Scottish clubs and Sweden’s Östersunds before transitioning into coaching, and Arbroath chairman John Christison willingly accepted his move back to Aberdeen.

After sacking Bob Bradley, Swansea have tasked Alan Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams with preparing for Saturday’s match against Bournemouth and are targeting ex-Derby boss Paul Clement as permanent manager to help avoid relegation, warning that a drop into an increasingly strong Championship would make an immediate return far from certain. The club—promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after rising from near bankruptcy in 2003—earned a reputation for well-run, possession-based football but, according to Curtis, has lost the “Swansea Way” amid frequent managerial changes since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 departure and the loss of key players. A former one-club player who has witnessed their ascent, Curtis believes the current squad is capable of staying up and is ensuring new signings understand the club’s journey through the “Jack to a King” documentary.

J. Craig Venter, born in 1946, parlayed a Vietnam-flavored sense of urgency into groundbreaking genomic research by automating sequencing machines and targeting RNA at the NIH, then left in 1992 to found the Institute for Genomic Research, where he published the first free-living organism genome in 1995. In 1998 he launched Celera Genomics to race the public human genome project—both published in 2001—earning criticism for his competitive, proprietary approach but enough wealth to fund his own science. In 2006 he established the J. Craig Venter Institute, culminating in Synthia, the first published synthetic life form, while also circumnavigating the globe aboard his yacht Sorcerer II to sequence marine microbes, all toward a synthetic-biology-driven industrial revolution and environmental restoration.

The Sutton Trust’s Boston Consulting Group–backed report finds that England’s 520,000 annual apprenticeship starts are often too short and low-level compared with vocational systems in Germany and Switzerland, with fewer than 200,000 at level 3 (A-level equivalent), 58% below level 3, and three-quarters aimed at those over 25 rather than young people (only 61,000 new starts versus Germany’s 570,000, 90% at A-level standard). It highlights that just one in five English employers offer apprenticeships versus 51% in Germany, England’s system has 18,000 qualifications compared with Germany’s 330, and 11 young people compete for each place. Sir Peter Lampl calls for 300,000 new annual starts prioritizing three-year level 3 courses and some four-year level 4 routes, limiting two-year level 2 places to 10%, while preserving respected lower-level schemes; the Department for Education says it is already reforming apprenticeships to raise standards and extend their length, rigor and employer relevance.

Storey won the Nottwil, Switzerland time trial by more than two minutes over Poland’s Anna Harkowska, putting her on the brink of a 17th world title ahead of Saturday’s road race; the 37-year-old is targeting further Paralympic success at Rio 2016 and already stands as Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, eight silver, three bronze) across six Games in cycling and swimming—including four golds at London 2012—and has amassed 21 world titles since switching from a swimming career (six medals at the 1992 Paralympics) to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United were expelled from the Conference Premier on 10 June after repeatedly missing deadlines—extended from 5 to 12 June—to settle roughly £148,000 of football-creditor debts out of total liabilities of about £225,000 (including PAYE arrears). A £1 rescue bid by the Supporters’ Trust and a takeover by Tommy Agombar failed to satisfy the board, which reinstated reformed Chester FC in their place while leaving Hayes & Yeading in Conference South. The club’s collapse—marked by a winding-up petition from ex-manager Martin Foyle, player exits such as Kingsley James and Dan Lloyd-Weston, and a steep attendance slump since their 2012 relegation—rendered their heroic final-day escape inconsequential.

James Milner, the 30-year-old former Manchester City midfielder, earned 61 England caps after debuting in 2009, featured in two World Cups and two European Championships—though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016—and announced his retirement citing “common sense,” wishing Sam Allardyce and the team well; he also holds the England Under-21 cap record with 46 appearances since 2004 and scored his lone international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood died at his Cambridge home after a months-long illness, with a private funeral and a later memorial; he was a pioneering conductor in the early-music movement, founding and directing the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) from 1973 across six continents for about 30 years and overseeing more than 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments and a celebrated 1980 Handel’s Messiah with Emma Kirkby. Trained in keyboard at Cambridge under Rafael Puyana and Mary Potts and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt, he began his career with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and as a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London, and went on to lead the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society while teaching at Harvard, Cambridge (honorary), and Cornell. Colleagues praised his generosity, scholarly insight, and enduring legacy in historically informed performance.

A Northern Irish mother, who gave up her job to care for her son with special needs, withdrew him from mainstream school in June after he struggled and has since been unable to secure a place at any of the South Eastern Education Board’s full special schools; as a result he feels isolated while his siblings attend classes. The family has been promised that an extra classroom assistant at a local special school may allow him to start in the coming weeks, but the mother fears other parents will face similar delays in an over-subscribed system. The Education Authority, citing the child’s privacy, declined to comment on the individual case but says it is reviewing demand for special school places across Northern Ireland and aims to improve local provision from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union has launched a takeover bid for Newport Gwent Dragons and views Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue, despite Newport County holding a lease to the ground until 2023 with primacy of fixtures in the Football League. County chairman Robin Foxall insists that their existing contract, agreed in 2013 after promotion, must be honored, while Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey confirms that both County and the on-site squash club are protected under current agreements, which the WRU acknowledges. The WRU’s vote on the takeover is scheduled for May 9, amid plans to install an artificial playing surface that would contravene Football League regulations. On the field, County sit two points clear of relegation in League Two with two games remaining under caretaker manager Mike Flynn, and can secure survival this weekend if they win and Hartlepool lose; Foxall warns that dropping out of the Football League would be devastating for the club and city.

A former Sierra Leonean child soldier who was abducted at 15 by RUF rebels—branded, drugged and forced to kill—escaped to Freetown, fell into petty crime, then found purpose in Lifeline Nehemiah under preacher Richard Cole, who urged him to rebuild his country. When Ebola struck in 2014, he and his team, though not medical professionals, educated over 10,000 people in local languages, delivered food and supplies to 11,000 affected households, and helped establish a treatment unit, saving many lives. Today declared free of the virus that killed nearly 4,000 in Sierra Leone (part of an 11,314 global toll), he now works to invest in youth as future nation-builders.

A public fundraising campaign reached its target in a month to save about 80,000 works from the Wedgwood Museum—art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs—from being auctioned to cover the firm’s pension debt. Administrators Begbies Traynor confirmed the collection will stay on display at Barlaston, Staffordshire, after the Art Fund gifts it to the Victoria and Albert Museum and arranges its loan back to the Wedgwood Museum. The museum’s collection, inherited when Waterford Wedgwood plc collapsed in 2009 and placed in administration with a 2011 court ruling allowing its sale, was rescued from being scattered worldwide. Administrators, Alison Wedgwood and MP Tristram Hunt all praised the goodwill, determination and cultural importance of retaining these items that chart Britain’s national identity.

Billericay Town, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points off a play-off spot, were taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin—who’s “comfortable” investing £10,000 a week—and in March signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35; Dan Groves says finer details of a deal that could see 30-year-old Malachy Wright (2011 I’m A Celebrity runner-up and ex-non-league player for Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds) buy a 20% stake and become a director are yet to be released.

Amid speculation that he might stay until 2021 or leave as planned in 2018, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney surprised many by opting for a one-year extension to 2019. Officials had expected a two-option choice—full eight-year term or original departure—but Carney offered a “third way,” driven by personal considerations: two of his four daughters face major exams in 2018 and the family plans to return to Canada’s education system. He emphasized the decision was purely personal, not influenced by political pressure or Brexit gloom, and noted that a new governor should oversee Britain’s economic future after Article 50.

Blackpool and Colchester United played out a 1-1 draw in which Blackpool opened the scoring after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso’s chip found Jamille Matt, but Colchester levelled from the ensuing corner as Kurtis Guthrie prodded in after a scramble. Blackpool keeper Sam Slocombe kept out Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi, while Guthrie struck the bar, and Tom Aldred missed a late headed chance. Colchester finished with ten men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a late foul on Jim McAlister.

Action Mental Health’s Healthy Me programme, piloted in five Northern Ireland primary schools and now seeking wider rollout, offers interactive workshops for P6 and P7 pupils to build emotional wellbeing and resilience through techniques like breathing exercises and relaxation, while training teachers to spot signs of distress and guide students to support networks. Launched at Carrick Primary School, it aims to ease anxieties around the transfer tests—14,681 entrants this year—and the move to secondary education, concerns echoed by pastoral co-ordinator Helen Hamilton, and to equip children and parents with coping strategies. CEO David Babington stresses the need to prepare young people for modern life’s stresses, and Chief Inspector Noelle Buick calls for stronger preventive pastoral care education to strengthen youth resilience amid changing social contexts.

Fawley Waterside developers plan to transform the 300-acre former Fawley oil-fired power station—commissioned in 1971, decommissioned in 2013, capable of generating 2,000 MW to power one million homes with its 198 m chimney and 1,100 miles of internal cable—into a £1 billion “merchant city” featuring a marina, housing, restaurants, fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth and a central petal-shaped glass structure built around the existing chimney, which they say will become the tallest such landmark south of the Shard; outline planning permission is due later this year with construction slated to begin in 2018.

At the Hong Kong Track Cycling World Championships, Great Britain’s tally rose to two medals after 23-year-old Connor Latham claimed bronze in the men’s scratch, chasing down gold medallist Adrian Teklinski of Poland and silver-winning Lucas Liss of Germany, following Elinor Barker’s earlier silver in the women’s scratch. The GB men’s team pursuit lost the bronze ride-off to Italy, while the women’s pursuit quartet of Barker, Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd and Ellie Dickinson finished fifth and missed a medal, though Barker and double Olympic champion Joanna Rowsell Shand praised their promising performance ahead of Tokyo 2020. Elsewhere, Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant, who qualified 16th in the women’s sprint, was eliminated in round one by China’s Lin Junhong but will still contest the 500m time-trial and keirin.

Ross Kemp is set to make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Peggy Mitchell’s final storyline, reuniting with his on-screen brothers and old flames following Peggy’s surprise comeback to Albert Square—her first appearance since 2010—to reveal her cancer has returned and that she will die in emotional spring episodes. Kemp, who originally played Grant from 1990–1999 and again in 2005–2006, said he couldn’t refuse the chance to bring the Mitchell family together one last time, while executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins hailed the reunion as an opportunity to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden at their very best.

Sadio Mané’s two goals in 138 seconds sank Spurs at Anfield, prompting Mauricio Pochettino to bemoan their poor start, lack of desire and inability to handle pressure, warning that if Chelsea go 12 points clear it would be “a big problem.” Tottenham have managed just two away wins since late September—beaten by Chelsea and Manchester United and held by Arsenal and Manchester City—and boast only one victory in 17 road fixtures against top-six rivals. Former midfielder Danny Murphy added that their usually formidable defence was “all over the place” without the back three that had served them well, highlighting a lack of pace and the wrong mindset on the road that must improve quickly.

The All Progressives Congress captured 19 of 28 governorships in Saturday’s elections—its biggest strike against the Peoples Democratic Party since 1999—following its presidential victory by Muhammadu Buhari. The PDP was unseated in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna and lost Adamawa to insurgency pressures, though it held Rivers and secured eight mainly south-eastern seats; Taraba’s result remains outstanding and Imo was inconclusive, with polling deferred in seven states. Observers note the APC’s successes relegated the PDP to a regional force, dominant only in the south-east and Niger Delta, while the APC failed to seize any oil-producing states—potentially jeopardizing revenue amid militant threats. Although incidents of violence and ethnic tensions occurred, the polls were calmer than past contests, and the PDP’s defeat is attributed to defections, corruption allegations and its perceived failure against Boko Haram, prompting calls for party reinvention.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will introduce an augmented reality app that lets visitors scan on-site signs and posters to access videos, band interviews, event updates and ticket purchases on their phones and tablets. Acts this year include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. Organizers say the new feature will enhance on-site enjoyment and enable people worldwide to interact with the festival and capture its atmosphere at any time.

Ofsted’s review of 21 Birmingham schools allegedly targeted by a hardline Muslim “Trojan Horse” takeover found academies Park View and Nansen Primary inadequate, prompting education minister Lord Nash to notify their trust, chaired by Tahir Alam, of his intention to terminate their funding agreements unless they respond by 4 July; Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School received similar warnings to remedy breaches such as gender segregation, discriminatory treatment of non-Muslims and a narrow faith-based curriculum, and Saltley School was placed in special measures with a temporary governing board. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw cited a culture of fear and intimidation, while school trusts and some parents have contested the findings and threatened legal challenges.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, arrested at Tehran Airport last April, was sentenced to five years in September on undisclosed charges of plotting to topple the government and has endured solitary confinement, suicidal feelings and a hunger strike before being moved out over Christmas. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, criticises the UK government’s inaction and is attending her “secret” appeal in Tehran without knowing when its unpredictable outcome—potentially quashing, reducing or increasing her sentence—will be delivered. Meanwhile their two-year-old daughter Gabriella, whose passport was confiscated, remains in Iran with her grandparents, has lost her English in favour of Farsi, and Amnesty International has labelled Nazanin a prisoner of conscience demanding her immediate release.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich conducted by optometrist Honey Rose. At Ipswich Crown Court, prosecutors led by Jonathan Rees QC allege Rose’s failure to detect and refer his swollen optic discs allowed fluid to build up in his brain, raising skull pressure and causing a preventable death. They argue her conduct fell so far below the expected standard of care that it amounts to gross negligence manslaughter; Rose, 35, of Newham, denies the charge and the trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he hired via an adult website and filming their encounters between 10 September 2013 and 17 September 2014, then sending an explicit clip to her sister on Christmas Day 2014. He was also convicted of intentionally showing sexual images to the victim’s sister and father and of threatening or abusive behavior on 25 December 2014. The woman described feeling “blackmailed” by Weatherhogg, who, having denied the charges, was placed on the sex offenders register and had his case remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing. Lady Wolffe remarked that his sentence must reflect society’s abhorrence, while the judge noted he posed a moderate risk of reoffending and defence counsel Jonathan Crowe said being remanded before sentencing was “a dramatic shock” for the first offender.

Opener Paul Stirling fell for a duck before Stuart Thompson’s 56, William Porterfield’s 39 and Gary Wilson’s unbeaten 41 lifted Ireland to 165-5 in Greater Noida, but Afghanistan chased down the target in eight overs to spare thanks to Samiullah Shenwari’s 56, Mohammad Shahzad’s 47 and a 51-run opening stand with Najeeb Tarakai; Afghan spinner Amir Hamza was the only bowler with multiple wickets (2-23). Ireland’s captain lamented falling “15 runs short” of their 180-run aim and a lacklustre bowling display, while pace bowler Boyd Rankin missed the T20s with a back problem but is due back for the five ODIs beginning 15 March.

Barcelona maintains it committed no offence in the summer 2013 signing of Neymar from Santos, insisting its only aim is to address “possible divergent interpretations” of contractual and tax obligations. Although the deal was publicly reported at €57 million (£48.6 million), Barça’s total outlay—including the £34 million paid to Neymar’s parents, signing-on fee, five years of wages, agents’ fees and recent tax payment—reaches £106.8 million. Amid allegations that the real cost was far higher and a judge’s ruling to continue investigating the transfer, the club—denying any tax-related crime—filed an additional tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 while asserting its original payment met all fiscal requirements. Sandro Rosell resigned last month amid accusations of misappropriating transfer funds but denies wrongdoing. This season Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 La Liga games and three in seven Champions League matches.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found dead on a Koh Tao beach on 15 September, and Thai police have charged two 21-year-old migrant workers from Myanmar, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, with conspiracy to murder, rape and robbery—charges that carry the death penalty—with authorities saying DNA from the victims matched the suspects and the pair allegedly confessed (a retraction was denied). Last month, Metropolitan Police detectives flew to Thailand at the invitation of Prime Minister Gen Prayuth Chan-ocha—after a summit with David Cameron—to assist Thai investigators, and they have now completed their review and will return to the UK to compile their report and brief the victims’ families. The UK Foreign Office had earlier summoned the Thai chargé d’affaires to raise concerns over DNA verification and claims of suspect mistreatment, while post-mortem findings showed Miller died from drowning and a head injury and Witheridge from head wounds.

Virtual reality is increasingly used beyond gaming—as a tool for journalists, educators, healthcare workers and retailers—to give people firsthand experiences of conditions, places and products. In the UK, the National Autistic Society created a VR film to simulate sensory overload in a shopping centre for autistic awareness, while Alzheimer’s Research UK released “A Walk Through Dementia” to show daily challenges of dementia sufferers. In retail, estate agents and Westfield use VR tours, and IKEA’s HTC Vive kitchen app let users customize and even “throw” virtual meatballs, prompting plans for in-store rollout. In healthcare, Dr Shafi Ahmed livestreamed a VR surgery to 5,000 viewers and co-founded Medical Realities’ Virtual Surgeon to democratize medical training; VR is also used to treat phobias and PTSD. In education, Google Expeditions sends children on virtual field trips, Evanescent Studios is trialing a Mandarin immersion app at Imperial College, and researchers are exploring headset-based engagement tracking—although hardware costs remain a barrier for many schools.

Investigators in Moscow opened the “black box” of the Su-24 jet shot down by Turkish F-16 fighters on 24 November, finding missing flight information and promising a report next week that could resolve whether the aircraft was in Turkish or Syrian airspace when hit. Turkey insists the Russian warplane, part of Moscow’s Syrian deployment supporting President Assad, ignored warnings to leave its airspace; Russia contends it was operating over Syria. Both crew ejected: the pilot was killed by militants on the ground, the navigator was rescued, and a Russian marine sent to help also died along with a destroyed rescue helicopter. The downing sparked a diplomatic crisis, with President Putin accusing Turkey of subservience to the US and “creeping Islamisation,” demanding an apology, and imposing sanctions, including a ban on package holidays that could cost Turkey billions.

Scotland’s women’s team have won all five Euro qualifiers and now host unbeaten Iceland at Falkirk knowing a victory would all but clinch their spot in next summer’s finals in the Netherlands; striker Lisa Evans—driven to avoid repeat play-off heartbreak after near-misses at Euro 2013 and last year’s World Cup—highlights that the head-to-head fixtures with Iceland, ranked just above them, will likely decide the group, while the rule that six of the eight best runners-up qualify automatically gives Scotland extra security. Evans, one of 12 squad members playing abroad (including BBC Women’s Footballer of the Year Kim Little), fresh from winning the Frauen-Bundesliga with Bayern Munich alongside stars like Franck Ribéry and Arjen Robben, believes that daily competition in top foreign leagues and the diverse cultures and playing styles her teammates experience are key to boosting the national team as they chase their first major finals.

A review commissioned by the Scottish government and Cosla and led by Prof Kenneth Gibb concludes that Scotland’s council tax has inherent flaws from the start and there is no “magic bullet” for reform: property taxes, common in OECD countries, are stable and hard to avoid but confuse taxpayers and aren’t linked to income, while local income taxes are seen as fairer yet create revenue volatility and limit rate flexibility; recognizing that any change is complex and tied to past reform experiences, the cross-party Commission on Local Tax Reform will hold public consultations across Scotland and publish its report in the autumn.

Apple has extended its two-step verification system to cover iCloud backups after hackers used third-party tools like Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker to steal celebrities’ photos, requiring users on new devices to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted number or the Find My iPhone app (or use a 14-character recovery key) before accessing iCloud or making store purchases. Previously two-step verification did not protect backup downloads, allowing attackers to retrieve full backups even with passwords secured. Elcomsoft’s owner confirms his software can no longer list devices or backups and praises the new download notification, but warns that recovery keys are hard to remember and risky if lost or stolen. Security experts argue that two-factor authentication should be enabled by default, and Apple says it will more aggressively encourage users to activate two-factor and stronger passwords, with CEO Tim Cook emphasizing the need to raise awareness.

From 23 January to polling day on 22 May, the six highest-spending parties poured £9,347,087 into their European election campaigns: UKIP, which won with 4,376,635 votes, spent £2,956,737 (68p per vote); the Conservatives £2,980,815 (79p per vote); Labour £1,027,339 (26p per vote); the Liberal Democrats £1,580,575—losing 11 of their 12 MEPs—at £1.45 per vote; the Green Party £534,249 (43p per 1,255,573 votes); and the SNP £267,372. All except Labour outspent their 2009 European election campaigns.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his Barrow contract to join National League rivals the Gulls and could face his former club on 18 February; the ex-Aldershot, Exeter and Italy-based player is prized for his leadership. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams, arrives subject to international clearance after spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps. Nicholson praised Anderson’s stature and voice and described Keating as young, raw and hungry, as the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred gelding owned by Trevor Hemmings and trained by Oliver Sherwood, collapsed and died from a “severe pulmonary haemorrhage” after narrowly beating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day; although he had previously shown post-race ataxia and overheating, he displayed no symptoms on Saturday and had no significant underlying health issues, prompting the British Horseracing Authority to underline the rarity of such incidents and commit to further research into their causes.

At a valedictory session ahead of the 5 May election, Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was visibly moved as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former SNP first minister Alex Salmond delivered their farewells and Conservative Annabel Goldie bowed out. McNeil, in parliament since 1999, urged Holyrood to strengthen committee scrutiny, accountability and opposition by learning from Westminster. Salmond repeated his belief that Scotland is “not divided but diverse,” welcomed devolution under the Scotland Bill yet argued it fell short of referendum pledges, joked about the Chancellor’s budget and Cheltenham Festival, and praised the honour of parliamentary service. Marwick thanked him for serving Scotland with distinction, and Goldie quipped she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “faux indignation.”

A lead actor will play Mrs Potts, the housekeeper transformed into a teapot in the 1991 animated film, while Oscar-winner Kevin Kline is cast as Maurice; Emma Watson will star as Belle; Dan Stevens as the Beast; Luke Evans as the villainous Gaston; and Josh Gad as Gaston’s sidekick LeFou. Bill Condon, fresh from directing Dreamgirls and the last two Twilight films, will helm the live-action adaptation, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and opens in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service will announce at an 11:00 BST private meeting in Warrington with Hillsborough victims’ relatives whether to charge any of 23 suspects identified in two investigations—15 from Operation Resolve into the causes of the 1989 disaster that killed 96 fans and eight from an IPCC probe of police conduct—following last year’s inquests that ruled the fans unlawfully killed; Sue Hemming, head of the CPS special crime and counter-terrorism division, will deliver the decisions as families led by Margaret Aspinall await accountability after a decades-long struggle.

Chelmsford Prison has reported numerous incidents of packages containing mobile phones and synthetic cannabis being hurled over its walls, with a local resident seeing four deliveries in two weeks and families invited to an evening meeting on how to respond. A former inmate described the jail as “notorious” for contraband flooding and alleged drones were used to fly items to windows, a claim the Ministry of Justice says lacks evidence. The MoJ said staff work “extremely hard” to stop smuggling, the Justice Secretary has asked for further measures, and new legislation allows up to two years’ imprisonment for anyone caught delivering packages into prisons.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a long-serving lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries last December outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston when a VW Golf driven by 55-year-old Brian Wright failed to stop at a red light; Wright, who says he was blinded by the low sun and cannot recall the light’s colour, accepts striking her but denies dangerous driving, expressing remorse in Luton Crown Court and prompting Judge Michael Kay QC to pause proceedings to allow him to compose himself, while Mrs Blackburn, now in residential care, remains seriously injured and the trial continues.

Laura Muir has confirmed she will miss next year’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her veterinary medicine finals in May conflict with the April schedule, prompting her to return to university for her final year despite her passion for representing Scotland. The 24-year-old middle-distance runner finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the World Championships, then set a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in London’s 5000m—where Hellen Obiri upset Almaz Ayana for gold with Sifan Hassan third—marking her fifth race in ten days. Although studies will keep her busy, Muir is eyeing the World Indoor Championships in March and believes she still has the capacity for two or three more Olympic cycles.

Trevor Deely, 22, vanished in December 2000 while walking home from a Christmas party. This Saturday Gardaí commenced excavations in a three-acre woodland at Chapelizod beside the R112 and River Liffey, a search expected to last weeks. Earlier this year detectives reviewed the case, enhancing CCTV from the night Deely disappeared which shows him retrieving an umbrella from his Bank of Ireland workplace on Baggot Street and speaking to, then being followed by, an unidentified man dressed in black. Despite releasing the footage in April, the man has yet to come forward and Gardaí have renewed their appeal for information.
