Both Tunisia and Morocco overcame CAF-imposed sanctions to secure entry to the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations: Tunisia, threatened with expulsion for its post-match protest over a contentious 2015 quarter-final penalty against Equatorial Guinea, apologised (emphasising it never alleged corruption) and resolved the dispute with CAF president Issa Hayatou, earning a place in Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti; Morocco, banned from the qualifiers and fined $1 million after refusing to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola fears, had the ban overturned and the fine cut to $50,000 by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, and will compete in Group F against Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé.

McLaren, once a dominant force with 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers’ titles and eight constructors’ championships, has slumped since a 2013 chassis crisis and its revived Honda partnership suffers engine woes. Its golden eras—highlighted by a near-perfect 1988 Honda season with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost and Mika Häkkinen’s 1998–99 Mercedes-powered titles—have been punctuated by declines and controversies: the 2007 espionage scandal that cost them the constructors’ crown, 2009’s ‘lie-gate’, and title droughts despite Lewis Hamilton’s 2008 drivers’ crown. Ron Dennis’s return in 2014 aims to arrest the slide, buoyed by Fernando Alonso’s 2015 comeback and belief in a competitive chassis and a maturing Honda unit, yet tangible results remain pending.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, and police later found patrons still on the premises and till receipts showing alcohol sold until 04:49 BST; the court subsequently ordered the bar’s closure for three months, charging licensee Colleen O’Neill with two counts and James Thomas with one count of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, fining O’Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000 after hearing the premises had been improperly run, breached licensing laws and that O’Neill had an “appalling record.”

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA single-season three-point record by draining eight threes in a 45-point, nine-assist night to spark a Golden State rally from 13 down and a 116-105 win over Portland, where Klay Thompson added 26 and LaMarcus Aldridge (27 points, six rebounds) and Damian Lillard (20 points, eight assists) led the Trail Blazers. Meanwhile in Chicago, the Bulls erased a 19-point halftime deficit with a 39-8 third-quarter burst to topple the Miami Heat 89-78, as Pau Gasol posted 16 points and 15 rebounds, Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson chipped in 14 apiece and Derrick Rose scored 12, while Miami’s Dwyane Wade managed nine points on 4-for-20 shooting and Hassan Whiteside finished with 19 and 16 as the Heat were outscored 57-27 after intermission.

At Melwood YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen, introduced to Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic as a competition-winning fan, stunned them by firing several top-corner strikes—leaving the stand-in keeper helpless—after first pretending to lack ability; the Dutch YouTube sensation, who also admired Balotelli’s well-placed free-kick, said he savored fooling the Liverpool quartet and wrapped up the session by revealing the forward’s infamous 2011 slogan t-shirt.

On Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina, 38-year-old Derek Lowe and 33-year-old Tina Lowe were struck and killed by Amtrak train No. 80, the Carolinian, en route from Charlotte to New York City on Norfolk Southern tracks; none of the 166 passengers were injured, though one man fell ill, and after a 2 hour 45 minute delay the train resumed its 13 ½-hour journey, while a scrap‐metal collector who knew the couple suggested they may have lived in a nearby homeless camp and recalled them struggling to cross the tracks with a grocery cart.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of Colombia’s Medellín cartel, spent 27 years working undercover for the DEA—helping bring down figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega—in exchange for a promised U.S. citizenship that never materialized; now retired on account of his failing health, he faces deportation, lives illegally after his temporary visa expired on January 1, has no access to benefits or official status, fears for his life if sent back to Colombia, and remains in limbo despite efforts by a former handler and colleague who each once provided him with $5,000 after the DEA declined further assistance.

The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is investigating whether Canadian registrar Vox Populi Registry Ltd.’s new “.sucks” top-level domain, approved in March, constitutes an illegal “shakedown” by charging trademark holders—among them YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, Yahoo and celebrities like Kevin Spacey—up to $2,499 a year to register or remove their names before public release; resellers have been asking about $2,000, while Vox Populi plans to open registrations to consumers for $10 annually in September. Following complaints from an ICANN advisory panel representing companies such as Microsoft, Verizon and eBay, ICANN has asked U.S. and Canadian regulators to review the scheme and may declare Vox Populi in breach of its contract.

Police solved a 27-year-old case in Norfolk by exhuming a baby boy’s body—found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag floating in Weasenham St Peter’s pond in June 1988—and extracting DNA that identified his mother, who was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but then explained she had concealed her pregnancy, delivered the baby alone, and deposited him in the pond after he was stillborn. Post-mortems found no evidence of foul play, and while prosecutors weigh charges for failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial, the child—now named Peter—has been reburied at St Peter’s church with a charity-funded headstone acknowledging his life.

Kristopher Hicks, then 23, jumped from Michael Young’s taxi—driven over 20 mph—after Young mistakenly believed Hicks intended to refuse payment and drove him nearly a mile back to the Bath rank; Hicks suffered catastrophic brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now needs 24-hour care from his mother. In the High Court, Mr Justice Edis found Young liable for unlawful imprisonment, awarded Hicks damages reduced by 50% for contributory negligence plus £250, with total compensation expected to be in the hundreds of thousands to fund specialist rehabilitation, and both parties have leave to appeal the final sum.

Wednesday night in Kansas, tornado sirens blared as storms produced a twister six miles northwest of Goddard—about 15 miles west of Wichita—that tracked northeast away from the city but threatened other communities, and spotters also reported tornadoes near Aetna in southwestern Kansas. The National Weather Service noted a possible touchdown in Potosi, Missouri, roughly 70 miles from St. Louis, where CNN affiliate KMOV documented wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, roof destruction, Instagram posts of dark clouds in Leadington and baseball-size hail in Farmington. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are particularly deadly, and forecasters anticipate more storms Thursday across the Midwest, the Mississippi and Tennessee river valleys, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold, coming off a win over Michael Bisping and seeking a fourth straight victory, vows to play the “bull” against Lyoto Machida’s elusive, “matador” style in their New Jersey middleweight bout, aiming to cut Machida off, exploit holes in his striking and ground game, and dominate with his complete MMA arsenal and superior cardio; Machida, fresh from defeating C.B. Dollaway in Brazil, respects Rockhold but trusts his karate-based timing, technique and defensive footwork honed in an eight-week camp to upset Rockhold and secure a title shot.

An Aerostar light general aviation aircraft approached Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, and touched down with its landing gear retracted, skidding on its belly as the propellers and wing tips ricocheted off the runway; after the initial bump and scratches, the pilot re-engaged full throttle, miraculously keeping the engines running despite damaged propellers, regained control, and flew the plane—accompanied by his dog Buddy—about 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The video footage, captured by a bystander who noted the pilot hadn’t lowered his gear and described the unforgettable crunching sounds, prompted an FAA investigation; such gear-up “belly” landings most often stem from human error or mechanical failure.

Manuel Pellegrini admitted he has been disappointed by Yaya Touré’s underwhelming performances this season but insisted he will back the Ivory Coast midfielder until the end of the campaign, despite reports that Manchester City will listen to offers for the 31-year-old—who has two years left on a £220,000-a-week deal—as part of an end-of-season squad overhaul. City have taken just 18 points from the last 39 available and will face West Ham without injured captain Vincent Kompany, while goalkeeper Joe Hart urged players to take responsibility for their form and affirmed Pellegrini still has dressing-room backing. Meanwhile, Sam Allardyce warned West Ham left-back Aaron Cresswell against repeating the mistakes of previous England youngsters—like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair—by moving to a big club such as Manchester City or Chelsea only to struggle for playing time.

Domenico Rancadore, a 65-year-old Sicilian Mafia “man of honour” who fled to Britain in the 1990s and lived under the alias Marc Skinner for more than 20 years, was convicted in his absence by an Italian court in 1999 and sentenced to seven years’ imprisonment for Cosa Nostra membership. Arrested on a European arrest warrant in London in 2013 and losing his final extradition appeal in February, he has nonetheless been allowed to remain in the UK after Italian law extinguished his sentence last October—double its term having now elapsed—leading Palermo’s court of appeal to drop the conviction and Italy to withdraw the warrant. His solicitor and the Crown Prosecution Service are now seeking a consent order to formally discharge the proceedings at Westminster Magistrates’ Court without his attendance, amid criticism over administrative errors, wasted time and money, and while Italy retains the option to appeal to its Supreme Court.

Mr Mole, Paul Nicholls-trained mount of AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson’s Sprinter Sacre (to be ridden by Nico de Boinville in Barry Geraghty’s absence) in the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday; it will be McCoy’s final Grade One ride, with his remaining mounts confirmed on Friday, and notably he announced his retirement after steering Mr Mole to victory at Newbury in February, while other entrants include Mick Channon’s Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter finally viewed the grisly 1975 crime-scene photos of her daughter Marcia last year, more than four decades after the 12-year-old was raped, strangled and left under a shower curtain and child’s wading pool in a cluttered Nashville garage—her body found 33 days later with a fractured neck bone, blackened mouth, pulled-out hair, blood, vomit and missing cookie money. Advised by her then-husband to avoid them, Ritter overcame lead investigator Mickey Miller’s warnings, saw the images on his laptop and vowed revenge. After years as Nashville’s most notorious unsolved murder—with a teenage neighbor briefly charged in 1979 but never tried—it was a Memphis arrest and DNA on Marcia’s clothing that led to Jerome Sidney Barrett’s 2006 capture; in 2009 a Davidson County jury convicted the 68-year-old of second-degree murder and sentenced him to 44 years.

Rory McIlroy, the 25-year-old world number one, considers it “unthinkable” that he won’t eventually win the Masters to complete golf’s career grand slam—currently held only by Sarazen, Hogan, Player, Nicklaus and Woods—and has made Augusta National a career-long target despite only one top-10 in six efforts; he describes his 2011 collapse there—leading by four shots before a closing 80 to finish 10 behind Charl Schwartzel—as the most important day of his career, a humbling experience that helped him regroup to win the US Open by eight strokes, the 2012 US PGA Championship and both the Open and US PGA in 2014, and he hopes to secure his first (and possibly multiple) green jackets this month while using the course as a sanctuary from off-course distractions like his called-off wedding and a legal fight with his former management company.

CNN’s trending roundup included four rainbows stretching across New York’s early-morning sky captured by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis; China’s vice crackdown threatening the growing practice of hiring exotic dancers for rural wakes; Robert Downey Jr. bristling at a Channel 4 interviewer probing his private life; the viral #kyliejennerchallenge lip-plumping fad; 102-year-old Alice Barker starring in a time-travel film project; a bomb-themed prom proposal rebuffed amid racism accusations; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumière in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp’s nearly unrecognizable look in the Black Mass trailer; a Fresh Prince of Bel-Air-themed pregnancy announcement; and a military dad photobombing his son.

Last year 272 children in England were hospitalized with disabilities caused by fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), though experts say many more cases go undiagnosed; World Health Organization research suggests at least one in 100 UK babies—about 7,500 annually—may suffer learning, behavioral and physical problems such as deformed limbs from prenatal alcohol exposure. Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organization for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome calls the condition “an enormous problem” with lifelong effects, exemplified by 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who was diagnosed at five and requires constant assistance, leading her adoptive parents to found the Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder Trust. Other alcohol-related prenatal issues include liver, kidney and heart damage, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy. Current government advice limits pregnant women to no more than two units of alcohol twice a week, but Mitchell argues for guidance recommending complete abstinence.

Ex-juvenile offender Shaun Andrew McKerry, 31, nicknamed “boomerang boy” for his habitual returns to crime, was jailed for six years after his attempted armed robbery of Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15 was foiled when owner Sab Dhillon tackled him and Dhillon’s wife Sam struck him twice with a baseball bat, forcing him to drop the axe and bleed from the nose before police arrested him. McKerry, who pleaded guilty at Durham Crown Court, began shoplifting at 12 and by 15 had amassed 80 arrests and convictions for aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters and burglary, once stealing 22 charity boxes disguised as a woman and earning a reputation as a one-man crime wave.

Four Royal Navy sailors—submarine engineer Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31) and Darren Smalley (35)—are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault after allegedly gang-raping a woman in her early 20s at an alcohol-fuelled party on April 10 at the Shearwater naval base near Halifax, Nova Scotia. At their Dartmouth court appearance they each posted bail of over £2,000, surrendered their passports, agreed not to leave Nova Scotia, must live at the Stadacona naval base, remain employed by the Royal Navy and draw their pay, and are forbidden to contact the victim or six witnesses. They return to court on May 27, the offences carry up to 14 years in prison, and forensic tests could bring further charges.

Valerie Jackson’s four-year-old son R.J. has Netherton’s syndrome, an extremely rare congenital skin disorder—only about 70 cases worldwide—that makes his skin red, scaly and inflamed, requiring round-the-clock applications of creams and Vaseline. The family endures widespread ignorance and cruelty, from being denied entry to play centres to a stranger mistaking his condition for abuse and calling armed police. Although there is no cure and treatment focuses on cleansing and moisturizing to prevent infections, symptoms often ease over time. Valerie discovered her son’s diagnosis via an international Facebook support group, and despite the stigma, she celebrates R.J.’s playful, charming spirit and hopes greater awareness will spare him further hardship.

Transport for London has begun removing Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” adverts—featuring bikini-clad 24-year-old Renee Somerfield—as the paid three-week campaign ends, following a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures, widespread defacement and at least 216 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority alleging the posters promote an unhealthy body image. The ASA is reviewing the complaints, TfL says it will adhere to CAP and ASA guidance on future ads, and hundreds are expected to protest in Hyde Park. The campaign sparked a social-media backlash and a debate on Good Morning Britain, where host Susanna Reid called the slogan “anxiety inducing” while Protein World’s head of global marketing, Richard Staveley, defended the unretouched image, revealed bomb threats against the company are under police investigation and vowed to maintain its marketing approach. The controversy unfolds amid booming UK protein-powder sales—rising from £73 million in 2007 to £170 million in 2012 and projected to reach £358 million by 2017—and has drawn both feminist criticism and support from figures like Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick.

Ten days after the election, rail firms announced unregulated fare rises of up to 87%—most notably First Great Western’s Charlbury–London off-peak return jumping from £33.30 to £62.40—despite both main parties pledging to freeze or cap fares, prompting Prime Minister David Cameron to write to FGW for an urgent review. FGW says the hike aligns the north Cotswolds route with its other services and is offset by advance singles from £20, while other operators are also raising fares: London Midlands will increase a Crewe–Northampton off-peak first-class single from £30 to £37, and Virgin plans 22–24.5% hikes on Stafford–Liverpool and Manchester–Stoke returns, though it stresses most rises affect its cheaper “Virgin-only” fares and that its overall West Coast increase is just 1.65%. Industry data shows hundreds of anytime and off-peak returns rose by around 40% in January, especially on rural and same-day tickets.

John Young, 66, a retired HGV driver and former Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers soldier, and his 54-year-old newlywed wife Elaine were writing wedding thank-you cards in their Oldham home at around 11 pm when vandals began pelting their front window with stones and bricks; after one brick shattered the glass, Young opened the door to remonstrate and was struck in the left eye by another brick, sustaining a forehead wound and permanent loss of sight in that eye despite emergency surgery. Now feeling unsafe, the couple plan to move to Elaine’s flat in Southport, while Greater Manchester Police, led by Detective Constable Gareth Gwilliam and citing no known motive beyond “messing around,” have launched an investigation and appealed for anyone with information to come forward.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a one-year extension keeping him at the club until the end of the 2016 season after making a successful comeback from leg injuries sustained in a road accident last April that claimed his father’s life; following an ankle operation he returned to play on Derbyshire’s pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the season, with elite performance director Graeme Welch praising his exceptional character, tireless work in training and off the field, and hoping the new deal will boost his confidence after showing promising form.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford was diagnosed with aggressive neuroblastoma in his kidney, neck, lungs and bones and, to feel stronger during radiotherapy, asked to decorate his immobilisation mask as a Ninja Turtle. He endured 80 days of chemotherapy, kidney tumour removal, a stem cell transplant and weeks of radiotherapy at Manchester’s Christie clinic, and after a year has been declared cancer-free, though he will undergo regular check-ups. His bravery earned Cancer Research UK’s Little Star Award and a starring role in its Kids & Teens campaign, while Nickelodeon sent him Ninja Turtle presents. Neuroblastoma is a rare childhood cancer of specialised nerve cells—fewer than 100 UK cases a year, mostly under five—originating in adrenal glands or nerve tissues near the spinal cord, capable of spreading to bone marrow, bone, lymph nodes, liver and skin; treatment depends on the tumour’s characteristics and may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy and antibody therapy.

Tim Sherwood, impressed by 19-year-old Jack Grealish’s starring role in Aston Villa’s FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, has urged him to concentrate on forcing his way into Villa’s first team rather than dwelling on an international allegiance between Ireland and England. Drawing on a similar situation with Nabil Bentaleb, Sherwood advised Grealish to follow his heart but insisted he needs more club minutes before deciding. Grealish’s father, Kevin, echoed that club form must come first, even as his son remains split and may feature for both nations in an upcoming friendly.

Landing fees for private jets vary dramatically, with surprising high charges at unexpected hubs—a benchmark 767-400 jet pays £4,559 to land at Tokyo’s Haneda, £3,728 at Narita and £3,594 at Kansai, while Toronto Pearson (£3,461), Darwin (£3,059), Bristol (£2,929), Nagoya’s Chūbu Centrair (£2,863), Dublin (£2,729), New York’s LaGuardia (£2,630) and Salzburg (£2,530) round out the top ten. Private aviation is a booming global business—2.5 million US and 705,000 European flights in 2013—worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe. Demand peaks at marquee events like the Super Bowl (NY–Glendale round trips $38,000–$54,000) and the Monaco Grand Prix (London–Cannes/Nice circa £8,800), and popular routes include Los Angeles–Las Vegas (~£2,890) and Milan–Rome (~$5,880 one‐way).

Katie Gallegos of Clackamas County, Oregon, who runs Dogpatch Resort, took her fast-eating Labrador Cooper and his smaller pal Daisy through a McDonald’s drive-thru for ice cream, resulting in a video—viewed over seven million times—of Daisy daintily licking her cone while Cooper crushed his in one bite; despite some critics worrying about the pups’ treats, Gallegos defends their weekly indulgences, noting Cooper’s robust health and sharing that Daisy gets only a few licks due to her size, and she’s even treated them to Starbucks “pup-puccinos” (just whipped cream) with the same speedy result.

Gary Locke, the 41-year-old former Hearts boss who joined Kilmarnock last summer as Allan Johnston’s assistant, has been appointed permanent manager after signing a three-year deal with chairman Jim Mann; since taking over in February he has lost only once in seven games at Rugby Park and will address the media at a Friday press conference.

Jessica Kemp of Eustis says teachers at Seminole County Elementary threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son Logan because the DōTERRA essential oils she applies to his head and neck—lavender, chamomile and sandalwood—“smell” and distract other students after a teacher’s aide complained. Kemp, who insists the oils help Logan stay calm and focused, received a letter from the school board calling the oils a “problem” for staff and students, but Lake County School District later told the media they would not suspend him, deeming it a health issue, and Kemp says she will continue to fight the decision.

A beachside holiday complex called Sandpiper in Westhampton Beach, the Hamptons, was engulfed by flames on Wednesday at 3 p.m., as a fire swept through 90 condos, caused the building’s collapse and sent smoke visible three miles out to sea, even melting paint off nearby structures. Twelve fire crews, hampered by intense heat, used cranes but could not enter the units; fire chief Ross Donneson said offshore winds aided visibility and they’re investigating reports the blaze began near a parked car. Residents—including owner Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber—watched in disbelief as flames poured from every window, ultimately losing all their possessions.

Despite nearing her 89th birthday, the 88-year-old queen enjoyed a spring morning ride through Windsor Great Park on her black fell pony Carltonlima Emma—riding helmet-free in a silk scarf—continuing a passion that began at age four when she received her first pony, Peggy, and has included mounts such as Betsy and Burmese. Though a niggling knee injury has curtailed her outings, she remains a dedicated equestrienne who breeds thoroughbreds, fell ponies at Hampton Court and highland ponies at Balmoral, while fell ponies themselves, a hardy Cumbrian breed prized since the Iron Age and refined by Romans, Vikings and Normans, measure 13–14hh and retain popularity as family mounts.

A noise dispute between neighbors in North Brisbane ended in tragedy when 28-year-old warehouse worker Phillip Pama, roused from sleep by 55-year-old Leon Yeaman’s loud music and yelling in his yard on Muller Road around 9pm, confronted him and delivered a single blind punch to the head, killing Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene around 11pm; Pama, a married father of three with no history of violence, was charged with manslaughter, granted conditional bail by Brisbane Magistrates Court under a 6pm–2am curfew, passport surrender and twice-weekly police reporting, and is due back in court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old Russian music teacher, allegedly tried to hire a hitman—who was in fact an undercover police officer—to torture and kill her 15-year-old pupil Damian Vanya after he ended their year-long relationship for a classmate. Secret camera footage from a sting operation in Shatura near Moscow shows her offering 100,000 rubles (around £1,400) and instructing the fake hitman to break his arms and legs, damage his kidneys so he would bleed to death, and then “finish him together.” After handing over part of the money, she was arrested in her car, charged with attempted murder and faces up to 15 years in prison, while Vanya, relieved by her arrest, said he hoped they would “throw away the key.”

Chelsea manager José Mourinho, 52, says he prays every day and has a strong faith in God—though he never prays about football or discusses the game with his wife—and tries to keep his professional and family lives separate; he goes to church only when he feels the need or when he’s in Portugal. Married to Matilde Faria and father of two, he and his family “know about poverty” and work as ambassadors for the World Food Programme against hunger. Despite his often arrogant sideline persona, he insists he’s a good family man and friend who supports others, admits he makes mistakes in football’s competitive, emotional environment, and currently leads Chelsea atop the Premier League ahead of a match with struggling QPR. Earlier this season he was fined £25,000 for alleging a “campaign” against Chelsea after Cesc Fàbregas’s booking, and his son José Mário recently celebrated the club’s Capital One Cup victory with teammates.

On the April 1 edition of The Price Is Right, 91-year-old Bob Barker—who hosted the show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007—returned for the first time in eight years to lead contestants through the opening “Lucky Seven” price-guessing game, looking spry before handing hosting duties back to Drew Carey, demonstrating he hadn’t missed a beat.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested at 12:30 a.m. Friday on the 3200 block of D Street SE in southeast Washington, D.C., by Metropolitan Police officers returning to the scene of an alleged break-in; he faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. The agency has revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave—Baldwin is posted to the Foreign Missions Branch attached to the State Department—and court records show he was to be arraigned that afternoon with no attorney listed. His arrest follows the recent placement of a high-ranking supervisor on leave amid misconduct allegations under investigation by the Department of Homeland Security’s inspector general, and comes amid scrutiny of a March 4 incident in which two senior officials allegedly drove into a secure White House area after drinking, adding to the agency’s string of controversies.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, left the safety of his car at a city safari park to approach within 10 feet of a hungry male lion, lying on the ground and firing off frames with only his camera. The shutter clicks alerted the lion, which lunged at him, forcing him to scramble back into his vehicle. Saeed said he wanted to capture the lion’s character and status in those few seconds, but now doubts he could repeat such a close encounter.

New York City police are seeking help identifying an unnamed woman, believed to be 25–45 years old, who was found unconscious and later pronounced dead on the evening of March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn’s Gravesend section. She carried no identification but bore a faded tattoo on her right leg depicting a heart topped with a rose and a ribbon inscribed with the name “Monique.” Authorities have released images of the tattoo, are awaiting the medical examiner’s report on her cause of death, and ask anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple who returned home from the UK in 2009 and couldn’t afford traditional property, bought a 1986 Hino flatbed and spent a year and a half welding a steel frame and installing wood and steel panels to create a cozy two-bedroom home in Nelson. Lined with aromatic cypress, featuring stained-glass windows, a wood-fired stove and gas-heated water, it’s powered mostly by solar panels (first bill $25) and draws water from a nearby spring, all for about $25,000, and the pair even plan to build another one.

Researchers claim that kindergarten children sharing iPads in class over an academic year significantly outscored peers with no iPads or with individual devices on early literacy tests—shared-iPad students scored about 30 points higher—based on a study of 352 Midwestern suburban students led by Northwestern University’s Courtney Blackwell, who attributes the boost to collaborative learning around the technology rather than collaboration alone and recommends schools rethink tablet use in early grades; she will present her findings at the 65th annual International Communication Association conference in Puerto Rico.

A piglet on Ms Duan’s farm in Qionglai City, Sichuan, born without hind legs, has taught itself to walk and even forage by balancing on its front trotters, wobbling but never toppling, and has become an internet sensation—nicknamed “Super Pig”—after a viral video showed it hunting for food with its snout to the ground and mingling happily with its four-legged littermates; its story has drawn villagers eager to see the remarkable animal, echoing the fame of a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo that also learned to hop on its front paws.

During the rain-soaked inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Dayle Coyne Racing’s front-outside tire changer Todd Phillips was struck and injured when Francesco Dracone spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25; Phillips received stitches for a leg cut at the infield care center and was released, while Dracone, who struggled with traction in the wet conditions, failed to finish and placed 23rd.

In Rio de Janeiro, CCTV footage shows 32-year-old Milton Vieira Severiano dragging his 29-year-old dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno) of the Jaula das Gostozuedas troupe, into their apartment garden, smashing her head into concrete eleven times, punching her face ten more times, then returning with a handgun to fire five point-blank shots into her face; the couple had been married only four days, and after committing the murder he stole a neighbor’s car but crashed it and was arrested with four handguns, a shotgun and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle, subsequently confessing that he killed her out of jealousy over men looking at her and now faces life in prison.

Journalist and best-selling author Sarah Wilson, 41, revealed that her anxiety—exacerbated by stress, thyroid disease and family distance—drove her to a near-suicidal point as she felt increasingly isolated without a partner or children and saw no way forward. She now reports having found some peace and stresses that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked, arguing that recognizing this connection is crucial to tackling rising stress and anxiety among Australian women. Wilson, who once felt she’d missed out on a “life guidebook,” warns that anxiety is becoming the “new depression,” noting that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and urges anyone in need to contact Beyond Blue on 1300 224 636 or Lifeline on 13 11 14.

In November 2014, seven-months-pregnant Portland resident Elena Curtin found her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in Curtin’s bathroom and, after the woman refused to leave, struck her in the head and arm with a crowbar; Curtin was charged with second-degree assault and faced nearly six years in prison, but prosecutors dropped the case this week—citing Oregon’s law allowing physical force against a non-leaving intruder and deeming her outrage “completely justified.” Curtin, who gave birth in January and now lives with her parents, learned through her defense that the ex-girlfriend had long harassed and threatened her to lure the boyfriend—himself a recovering heroin user who shares a five-year-old with his ex—back into addiction; the ex and boyfriend have since reconciled, while he remains uninvolved with Curtin’s new child.

Gemma, a California pit bull who helps look after two children, was filmed enjoying treats until her owner slyly tossed in a broccoli spear; she grimaced, munched it, then spat it onto the floor, prompting hopes the kids won’t copy her rejection of greens. When she’s not sampling snacks, Gemma enjoys sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website’s community projects page, meant to lead to its now-defunct Young Entrepreneur Awards site, instead directed visitors to a pornographic webpage featuring explicit images; the awards were scrapped in 2011 and, once their URL registration lapsed, the address was taken over by the adult site. Upon discovering the error, HSBC removed the hyperlink, issued an April 20 statement denying any association with the external site, apologized for the inconvenience, and stressed that its internet banking services remain secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 shortly before 7 a.m. after smelling smoke when a fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home, explaining to dispatchers during an 11-minute call that he and his nine-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped on the second floor because it was too hot to use the hallway; he kept his sister calm, soothed her fears, and guided firefighters to their location. Prince George’s County crews entered through a broken window, and Lt. Kenny Ward handed Marcus out to a rescuer before giving his gas mask to Aaliyah, who had tugged on his leg. Both children were taken to a children’s hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while their mother, older brother, and stepfather escaped on their own and were treated at MedStar Hospital.

Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured stunning neon-blue bioluminescence lighting up Jervis Bay on New South Wales’s south coast, a “beautiful supernatural scene” created by millions of single-celled phytoplankton (noctiluca scintillans) emitting light as a defense mechanism after feeding on diatoms; this naturally occurring algae bloom typically happens in spring and autumn about 90 percent of the time and was last seen in a harmless display at Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014, according to UNSW oceanographer Iain Suthers.

New genetic tests such as EndoPredict analyze tumor markers after breast cancer surgery to determine within days whether a patient’s risk of recurrence is high or low, with some low-risk women facing just a five-percent chance of return—comparable to outcomes with chemotherapy—and thus able to safely forgo its severe side effects. Although these tests currently cost about £2,500 privately, surgeons including Hemant Singhal and Kefah Mokbel argue that NHS funding would be offset by savings from avoided chemotherapy. In one case, mother of three Becca Cornford received a low EndoPredict score following surgery on both breasts, giving her confidence to skip chemotherapy in favor of regular monitoring.

More than 25 female Royal Navy sailors have been emergency-evacuated from ships for pregnancy—including five medevacs from HMS Ocean in nine years and at least one from HMS Illustrious—with 18 other vessels such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise and HMS Richmond also reporting pregnancy-related airlifts. A Ministry of Defence spokesman says a strict “no touching” rule at sea implies pregnancies occurred before deployment or during leave. This data follows the repatriation of Commander Sarah West, the service’s first female warship captain, amid allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have served afloat since 1990, making up about 9 percent of naval personnel in 2014, and in May last year three women became the Royal Navy’s first female submariners. Similarly, between January 2006 and December 2013, 99 servicewomen were flown home pregnant from Afghanistan and 102 from Iraq under rules barring expectant mothers from war zones, with personnel reminded to self-check for pregnancy before deployment and repatriated at the earliest opportunity.

A drone carrying traces of cesium—a common nuclear reactor byproduct—was found on Wednesday on the rooftop of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s Tokyo residence, its four-propeller frame fitted with a camera, smoke flares and a plastic bottle containing nonharmful radioactive material. The incident, which coincided with a court’s approval to restart two reactors at the Sendai plant more than four years after Fukushima, has intensified public opposition to Abe’s nuclear policy and prompted police investigations into potential drone-based terrorism. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga warned of future threats at major events like the Olympics and G7 summit, calling for stricter drone regulations around government sites, as current law only restricts flights near airports. Abe was in Indonesia for the Asian-African conference at the time.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer’s to work on the back of his motorbike every morning—securing both of them with a sash and riding the four kilometres slowly so she feels safe and they can chat—because after his father’s death and with his wife working elsewhere and his son at school, there was no one else to care for her and he fears she will wander off as she once did collecting firewood. At the bank where he works she has her own room and he checks on her throughout the day, feeling he must repay the devotion she showed in raising him.

Heavy drinking in the U.S. rose 17.2 percent from 2005 to 2012, driven largely by women’s alcohol use: women’s binge-drinking rates increased more than seven times faster than men’s and jumped nearly 36 percent in Santa Clara County, Calif. (nationwide 2012 rates were 8 percent heavy drinkers and 18 percent binge drinkers; CDC defines heavy drinking as averaging over one drink per day for women and two for men, and binge drinking as four or more drinks per occasion for women and five for men). County binge-drinking rates ranged from 6 percent to 36 percent, heavy-drinking rates from 2 percent to 22 percent. About 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010 were alcohol-related and excessive drinking costs over $220 billion annually. Researchers attribute rising consumption to changing social norms, greater affordability and advertising, weaker alcohol regulations, influx of affluent urban professionals and persistently stable overall alcohol-use prevalence. Findings are based on analysis of some 3.7 million adults in the CDC’s Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System and were published by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation in the American Journal of Public Health.

UN officials, citing the World Health Organization, warn that caesarean sections in England—now accounting for just over a quarter of births, more than double the early 1990s rate—are often performed without medical necessity, exposing mothers and babies to risks of infection (up to one in ten cases), serious complications, disability or death, and incurring higher costs (£2,369 per planned caesarean versus £1,665 for natural birth). Although NHS/NICE guidelines permit the operation for anxious women (“tokophobia”) or those over 40, with previous complicated births or conditions like asthma, diabetes or depression, WHO experts say the ideal caesarean rate should be 10–15% to avoid unnecessary health dangers and resource diversion.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250 and malicious destruction of property after allegedly breaking into an $800,000 Edgartown summer home on Martha’s Vineyard, living there for at least a week and selling the owners’ belongings at a yard sale. Owner Mark Conklin discovered her in his living room on April 17; she fled in a gray Nissan pickup but was arrested hours later trying to re-enter through a broken window covered by a blanket. Missing items include deck chairs, tables, lamps, framed posters, cookware, linens and a painting, and police are asking anyone in possession of these items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

Bella Crooke lost her unlocked iPhone at a friend’s birthday party and it was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW–Victoria border, where officers used it to post selfies and pun-filled Facebook updates—joking about passwords, “cell” phones, bail and battery life—which her friends quickly shared. When Bella arrived unaware of the social media campaign, police recognized her from the posts and returned her phone without needing her details. She later thanked them for their humor and has since set a password.

In iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa, a five-day-old hippo calf was tragically caught in a prolonged fight between two adult males: one rival grabbed the calf, hurled it into the air, then dragged it through the water as its mother looked on helplessly after remaining with her herd. Tour operator Stacey Farrell watched the mother chase off younger hippos before trying to rescue her baby by attacking the assailant’s neck—an effort that only made the attacker clamp down harder and fling the calf again. The calf succumbed to its injuries hours later.

A three-bedroom, two-bath, 1,990 sq ft maisonette in Knightsbridge’s Egerton Place is on the market for £575,000—equivalent to £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month—solely because just three years remain on its lease and it requires full modernization; a second, larger unit with the same lease is listed at £595,000. Featuring a reception room, utility space, lift, parking and communal garden, both properties could command £2,750–£3,000 per sq ft once refurbished, valuing the smaller at around £6 million and the larger at £7.5 million. Buyers must negotiate a lease extension with the likely freeholder, the Wellcome Trust, at an estimated cost of £3.35–£4.5 million for a 90-year term, making this rare short-lease opportunity highly attractive to developers and end users despite warnings of hefty extension premiums.

A point-of-sale computer outage during Starbucks’ daily system refresh late Friday disabled registers at roughly 7,000 US and 1,000 Canadian company-operated stores—forcing baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods or, in many cases, close early to avoid further losses—before the glitch, which also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana outlets, was resolved by Saturday and stores returned to “business as usual.” Starbucks apologized on its website, explained the outage’s cause, and promised further updates once systems were back online, while enthusiastic customers shared photos of complimentary frappuccinos, mochas and soy lattes on Twitter. The incident followed a record quarterly performance—net revenues of $4.6 billion—and coincided with a 4.4 percent gain in Starbucks’ share price to $51.50, underscoring its scale across 21,366 locations in 65 countries.

Terrorists have been using rural west Wales locations in Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire to radicalise and train militants under the guise of ordinary community activities, Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit revealed. He traced such extremist activity back to 1998, when Abu Hamza allegedly sent ten recruits to the Brecon Beacons—terrain also used by the British military for rugged training—and noted that two of the 7/7 bombers were filmed white water rafting in Bala in 2005. In 2010, three Cardiff-based would-be terrorists inspired by al-Qaeda were arrested for plotting coordinated attacks on Britain, and Michael Adebowale, later convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, set up by Iraqi clerics. Jones emphasized that terrorism in Wales is not confined to big cities and that community intelligence is vital to counter such threats.

An Omura’s whale, a species only described in 2003 and feared extinct, washed up as a 5.68 m juvenile female on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn, marking the first WA sighting and only the second in Australia. Department of Parks and Wildlife staff initially struggled to identify the rare whale but confirmed it via DNA profiling. Environment Minister Albert Jacob called the discovery highly significant, as little is known about the species, which appears restricted to tropical and subtropical waters—commonly Indonesian waters, the Philippines and the Sea of Japan. Omura’s whales are distinguished by a sleek body and unique skeletal traits, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried and its skeleton will be exhumed in a few years for further scientific study and potential museum display.

A Texas businesswoman claimed Hillary Clinton’s female hormones would make her an irrational president, but the author counters that male hormones have similarly impaired male leaders and that studies show women take fewer unnecessary risks. Time magazine even hailed Clinton as “perfectly” primed to lead as a postmenopausal woman with extensive experience, yet the focus on biology reveals deep-seated gender bias. From corporate boards dominated by men named John, Robert, William or James to student evaluations that praise male professors as geniuses while deeming women merely nice, discrimination persists. Eliminating these stereotypes, the passage argues, would boost company profits, strengthen families and marriages, improve children’s well-being and produce better overall results, so we must encourage daughters to pursue leadership despite societal prejudices.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, renowned for roles including Siegfried Farnon in All Creatures Great and Small, Winston Churchill and Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films, is auctioning over 200 antiques—among them a hand-painted 3D Battle of Agincourt diorama, Victorian Gillows cabinets, a yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle plus a portrait of him wielding it, paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers and rare books—across 238 lots at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, this Saturday, with total estimates around £100,000. At 89, he’s downsizing his Cotswolds home and reluctantly parting with a collection amassed through his medieval military history expertise—Hardy studied English under J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis, published two books on the longbow and advised on the Mary Rose recovery—and despite a stage retirement after a fall, he plans to continue television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man on parole for battery against law enforcement with a history of bipolar disorder and an involuntary psychiatric commitment, has been on the run since Saturday after police named him a suspect in the murder of his 57-year-old mother, Sandra Shemansky, whose body was found in their Winter Garden home following a well-being check. He first drew suspicion by failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son—the same day relatives discovered the death—and neighbors and his estranged wife’s attorney say Sandra, who had helped him through a divorce and prevented him from seeing their son, may have triggered his breakdown when divorce papers brought bad news. Authorities have recovered the murder weapon, will not yet detail how Sandra was killed, and report he was seen asking for water at the RV resort office before fleeing on foot without provisions or medication; anyone with information should call 407-656-3636.

Eugene, United States, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships after the IAAF council bypassed the usual bidding process to seize a “unique strategic opportunity” to stage the event for the first time in the U.S.; Eugene, which failed in its 2019 bid—won by Doha—convinced the governing body with a recent presentation, and IAAF president Lamine Diack praised the cooperation of public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC and an enthusiastic public as serving the sport’s global development, noting that the 2007 Osaka championships were similarly awarded without a bid.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years after a jury convicted her of manslaughter in the death of 56-year-old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. After befriending Hassan at a West End casino by using her looks to pose as “Rachel,” Granger lured him to his Islington flat, left the door unlocked for her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and his accomplice Nicholas Chandler, and allowed them to tie up, beat and kick Hassan to death while searching for his hidden cash. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years. Judge William Kennedy described the crime as “pitiless and wicked,” and evidence including CCTV footage and phone records showed the trio ransacking Hassan’s home, stealing around £3,000 plus electronics, then filming themselves throwing banknotes around. Kennedy rejected Granger’s mitigation that she acted out of misplaced love for Jackson, noting her deceit and lack of compassion, while prosecutors highlighted Hassan’s vulnerability as a high-stakes gambler who kept substantial winnings at home.

After a brilliant start to the season at Stamford Bridge, Cesc Fàbregas has slipped into a familiar post-Christmas decline, struggling for Chelsea and Spain, most notably earning just four out of 10 in Spain’s 2-0 loss to the Netherlands. Despite racking up 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, he’s managed only one in his last five games and four in 15 appearances in 2015, leaving him unlikely to surpass Thierry Henry’s record of 20. Fatigue from playing nearly every minute under José Mourinho has raised doubts over his late-season durability, though nine matches remain for him to regain form and help Chelsea secure the title.

West Ham are close to signing 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed during a two-week trial at their academy, despite also holding offers from Belgian clubs and interest from other European sides; meanwhile, the club has unveiled season tickets at the Olympic Stadium starting at £289—the lowest in the Premier League—to help fill its 54,000-seat capacity for the 2016-17 season.

Wiltshire Police have shelved the January investigation into the vicious assault on 40-year-old huntsman Mike Lane—who was knocked unconscious, suffered concussion, broken teeth and memory loss after balaclava-clad saboteurs armed with iron-bar-tipped ropes attacked him during an artificial-scent hunt—despite a video recording of the kicking, a dossier with names and car registrations, and a released suspect photograph. The force says the case is undetected for now due to insufficient evidence but will reopen if more information emerges. Lane, his supporters and witnesses denounce the decision as “pathetic” and “disgraceful,” while the Countryside Alliance urges a ban on protester face coverings to improve prospects for identifying and prosecuting such attackers.

Adam Gadahn, born Adam Pearlman in 1978 and later known as Azzam the American and Abu Suhayb, was an American who converted to Islam in 1995, left for Pakistan in 1998 and joined al Qaeda, where he rose to become its chief English‐language propagandist, appearing in videos threatening Western and Jewish targets, praising attacks like Fort Hood and Benghazi, urging lone‐wolf assaults and criticizing U.S. presidents. Indicted for treason and material support in 2006 and long listed among the FBI’s most wanted, he advised on al Qaeda’s media strategy—one of his 2011 letters was found in Osama bin Laden’s Abbottabad compound. The White House announced that Gadahn, 36, was killed in January in a U.S. counterterrorism operation; fellow U.S. citizen and al Qaeda operative Ahmed Farouq also died in a likely separate strike that claimed hostage Warren Weinstein and Italian Giovanni Lo Porto. Gadahn was married to an Afghan woman and had at least one child.

Chinese parents’ drive to raise prodigies has found a new hero in five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, who’s been shooting hoops since age two and a half and recently wowed viewers in a viral video by sinking successive baskets and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm; his dazzling performance has earned him legions of fans across basketball-mad China, drawn comparisons to national star Yao Ming and prompted thousands of astonished netizen comments—from disbelief and calls for special effects to jokes about wishing they’d started playing earlier and questions about his parentage.

Tom O’Carroll, a former Open University information officer and key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE)—which from its 1974 founding campaigned to legalise sex with children (including incest) and lobbied alongside the National Council for Civil Liberties to lower the age of consent to ten—has surprisingly joined supporters of media pressure group Hacked Off. He attended its February 25 rally in the Houses of Parliament, chaired by John Cleese, urging MPs to establish a statutory press regulator as recommended by the Leveson inquiry. Hacked Off, formed in the wake of the phone-hacking scandal to challenge what it deems the “biased and unfair” Independent Press Standards Organisation, says the event was open to all, but O’Carroll’s involvement is likely to embarrass the group.

Bondi’s iconic Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to host Ten Pieces’ unusual catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, inconveniencing lap swimmers but providing a striking ocean-backdrop setting where models showcased a monochrome unisex capsule of ten versatile pieces worn in 20 ways, parading through the empty pool and along the break wall as guests sampled Icebergs’ nibbles and Santa Vittoria drinks under a sunny 28°C sky while beachgoers and passers-by paused to watch.

Amir Khan, the 28-year-old Bolton-born boxer, spent a family day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in northern California alongside his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, feeding a rare white tiger and posing with giraffes and sea lions, and earlier this week he confirmed his next welterweight fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation over potential bouts with Kell Brook, Adrien Broner or Keith Thurman.

In Jerusalem, the family of 16-year-old Palestinian Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, successfully objected to the unauthorized listing of his name on Mount Herzl’s national memorial for fallen soldiers and terrorism victims; Almagor, an Israeli victims-of-terror group, also protested his inclusion—calling his killing a rogue attack rather than terrorism—and after letters from Almagor to the National Insurance Institute (which oversees the memorial) and the family’s complaint, Abu Khdeir’s name was removed from both the memorial wall and its website while a panel of judges has begun hearing evidence against the three suspects.

A California-based YouTuber filmed his young son chasing the family cat around the garden so he could rest his head on its belly; the cat cleaned itself and tolerated the plopping briefly before scurrying away several times until it finally retreated indoors, though a follow-up video shows the pair quickly reconciling as the boy gently feeds the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a 32-year-old former drug dealer and one of over a dozen witnesses for the government, lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying in a Philadelphia police corruption trial that undercover officers stole $81,000 and seven pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest—charges later expunged under probation—and also acknowledging a 2011 drug arrest and 2008 DUI, insisting he never meant to deceive the school and regrets that “bad phase,” while defense lawyers for six former drug squad officers—who face a 26-count indictment including racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping and drug dealing—portray the case as built on lying dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An oil storage facility at a paraxylene-producing plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, exploded Monday night after an oil leak, injuring six people—five cut by broken glass—and igniting a fire that was brought under control by more than 600 firefighters. Residents nearby reported hearing a loud blast and feeling tremors before posting photos on Weibo. The plant, relocated in 2007 from densely populated Xiamen amid pollution protests, had previously experienced a non-injurious explosion in July 2013, and its production of carcinogenic PX, used in polyester films and fabrics, has drawn illegal but recurring demonstrations in China.

Jack Grealish has told Premier League referees he won’t pull his socks up, insisting on wearing them low above children’s-size shin pads out of superstition, having never suffered a shin knock; he made his first league start in Tuesday’s 3-3 draw with QPR, admitted it was a tough relegation scrap, but was pleased by the manager’s faith in him and hopes to earn more starts before season’s end.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has sustained global and irreversible brain damage and, although she is no longer in a medically induced coma, remains unresponsive—she does not react to visitors, follow movement with her eyes and is breathing through a tracheostomy—according to her grandmother Cissy Houston and a source familiar with her care; while Bobby Brown recently said she is awake and watching him, the family’s attorney Christopher Brown warned that although doctors expect she may live a long life, her rehabilitation will be extensive and her eventual quality of life unknown, a view echoed by Alicia Etheredge-Brown, who noted Bobbi Kristina has left the ICU, opened her eyes and begun a long and hard rehabilitation.

Russia moved within one win of a first Fed Cup final since 2008 by taking a 2-0 lead over Germany on Saturday, as Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Görges in straight sets in the opening rubber and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova recovered from a match point against Sabine Lisicki to prevail 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3 despite 13 double faults, while Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors proved decisive.

Residents across New South Wales, still coping with last week’s east coast low that caused widespread flooding and damage, have been warned by meteorologists and the State Emergency Service (SES) to prepare for another storm system likely to bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday. The SES, which has more than 4,000 of its 24,196 outstanding jobs still to complete, is especially concerned about further hampering clean-up efforts and raising flood levels on already saturated ground, notably in the hard-hit Hunter region. Weatherzone forecaster Kim Westcott notes this low is expected to form further offshore and move more quickly—bringing up to two days of rain rather than the three days of wind and rain seen previously—while the Bureau of Meteorology cautions that intense rainfall and strong winds will focus on the state’s northeast coastal areas and southeast Queensland, with peak rainfall mid-week and uncertainty remaining over overall severity. Over 1,000 SES personnel, including 200 reinforcements from interstate, are being deployed to finish outstanding tasks and urge residents to safeguard their homes and families against further loss.

Nina Moric, the 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin’s “La Vida Loca” video, posted photos of bruises on her Instagram to deny Italian media and her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso’s claims that she tried to take her own life, explaining instead that she collapsed in her Milan apartment on Saturday night due to low blood pressure and a domestic accident that left her with a head injury and required hospital treatment; she says she is now recovering at home after rest, that the reports—echoing a similar alleged overdose in 2009—are incorrect, and that the press has misrepresented her situation.

As Kate and William prepare for their second child, a YouGov survey of 2,200 Britons for the Sunday Times shows “Diana” as the top choice (12%) for a girl—followed by Alice and Charlotte (9% each)—while “James” (13%) and “Alexander” lead for a boy, with just 3% hoping for another son versus a quarter wanting a daughter; social media users have also rallied for the name Diana, and 68% of respondents back William’s planned six-week paternity leave.

A suicide bomber struck a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday morning, killing 17 people and wounding 64, including Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon, as they marched to join a larger rally against the provincial governor; Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied responsibility and no other group has claimed the attack, police chief Faizullah Ghairat said.

Brazilian right-back Dani Alves is set to depart Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club’s final contract offer; despite seven successful years that yielded four La Liga titles and two Champions League triumphs, he could not agree a new deal, and his agent and ex-wife Dinorah Santana confirmed at a press conference that he turned down a three-year extension contingent on appearing in 60 percent of matches, declaring negotiations over.

Pablo Osvaldo, who joined Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton and has scored three goals in six matches, has called on former teammates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to move to Argentina and join him at La Bombonera, arguing their South American style and reputations—Pirlo as one of the world’s top midfielders and Totti as a Roma legend—would make them perfect fits and drive the fans wild.

Eighteen-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson suffered only a cut on his nose after a breathtaking double somersault fall from Merrion Square in the 4.20 pm race at Wincanton—an incident viewed hundreds of thousands of times online—yet by Thursday morning he was back mucking out stables at Paul Nicholls’s yard with no special treatment, undeterred and even joking that he might pursue a gymnastics career after fellow riders hailed his tumble as the most impressive they’d seen.

London Wasps captain and England flanker James Haskell marked the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron by posting an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Robert Downey Jr.’s Iron Man ahead of the Westfield London Shopping Centre premiere featuring Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth and Scarlett Johansson, captioned “avengers movie is out so thought i would release the inner iron man” with Under Armour hashtags. Haskell, who began his professional career at Wasps in 2002 and won his first England cap in 2007, enjoyed spells at Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan and the Highlanders in New Zealand before returning to Wasps in 2012, where he has since made over 100 appearances and earned 57 England caps.

Wide-leg trousers—denim, cropped, printed or striped—have emerged as a key SS15 trend, reviving a ’70s silhouette as an effortless alternative to skinny jeans. Championed by Louise Redknapp and spotted on runways from Gucci, Celine and Stella McCartney to high-street versions like Topshop’s Miller jean and Finery London, the look works best with high-waisted, floor-skimming cuts, high-heeled, foot-exposing shoes and simple knits or shirts to balance the volume, elongate the leg and keep outfits proportionate, making wide-leg flares a versatile, season-spanning wardrobe update.

Despite objections from more than 200 students—who argued that American Sniper’s portrayal of the Iraq War reflected negatively on the Middle East and people from that region, particularly in Michigan’s Detroit metro area, home to the nation’s largest Arab-American population—the University of Michigan will go ahead with the film’s inclusion in its UMix social events. Starring Bradley Cooper as Chris Kyle, the Navy SEAL and most lethal sniper in U.S. military history who was fatally shot at a Texas range in 2013, the movie’s screening was initially canceled after a petition but reinstated following a counter-petition and backlash. Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper said the reversal was necessary to uphold the university’s commitment to freedom of expression, and a screening of the family-friendly film Paddington will also be offered for those who opt out; head football coach Jim Harbaugh praised the decision.

On April 3 on Rottnest Island off Perth, two French tourists aged 18 and 24 allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a large flame to singe a quokka—a cat-sized marsupial found on small islands off Western Australia, notably Rottnest and Bald Island—which survived the incident; detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, evicted them from the island, charged them with animal cruelty, and they are due to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

At 102, former chorus‐line dancer Alice Barker—who performed at New York’s Cotton Club and Café Zanzibar in the 1930s and ’40s alongside stars like Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra—finally saw footage of herself dancing for the first time after filmmaker Mark Cantor and volunteers at jazz-on-film.com assembled a compilation of early music videos called “soundies” and showed it to her in her nursing home, prompting her to exclaim, “It’s just fabulous.”

New figures from an OSV survey of 1,100 UK drivers reveal that self-washing cars is falling out of favour: 31% of men and 75% of women have never washed their own vehicle, with only 12% of those who do cleaning regularly. Reasons cited include weekend retail openings, televised football, the rise of hand car washes, larger 4x4s and off-road vehicles, and children’s lack of interest in earning pocket money washing cars. Although an estimated 15 million cars were cleaned by their owners over the Easter holiday—often as an excuse to get out—buy-your-own upkeep varies regionally (highest in Birmingham, Chelmsford and Sheffield; lowest in Oxford, Bath and Edinburgh) and by brand (owners of Audis, Toyotas and BMWs wash most frequently; Range Rovers, Peugeots and Mercedes least). OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley laments the loss of the once-cherished Sunday car-washing tradition amid busier lifestyles and the convenience of automated and hand-wash services.

Martin Skrtel has lauded Steven Gerrard’s influence since his 2008 arrival at Anfield, crediting the Reds captain with helping him settle in and describing him as “still one of the best players in the world” and synonymous with Liverpool. Gerrard is set to lead Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley on Sunday, aiming to sign off his Anfield career in the final on his May 30 birthday before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel acknowledges that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard but insists the club has players capable of filling his void, and both he and Gerrard could return for the Villa clash after serving three-match bans.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus thrilled the Augusta National gallery by making his first-ever hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth during the Masters par-3 contest, playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw; his chip spun back into the hole amid the opening Masters Week roar. Though Camilo Villegas managed two aces that day and there were five in total—tying the 2002 record—Villegas lost the contest in a playoff to world No. 74 Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, the youngest green-jacket winner in 1963 who claimed a sixth in 1986, remains one of only five men to complete golf’s career Grand Slam (a feat Rory McIlroy could match with a third straight major).

Tornado sirens sounded across Kansas Wednesday night as storms produced a twister six miles northwest of Goddard—about 17 miles west of Wichita—that moved northeast without hitting the city, while additional touchdowns were reported near Aetna in southwest Kansas, prompting CNN expert Chad Myers to warn that nighttime tornadoes are especially deadly. In Missouri, the National Weather Service indicated a possible tornado in Potosi, 70 miles from St. Louis, where wind damage, flooding, fallen trees and roof damage were documented, and nearby Farmington saw baseball-size hail as Leadington residents shared images of ominous dark clouds. More severe weather is forecast Thursday across the Midwest, the Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Reserve deputy Robert Bates of the Tulsa County Sheriff’s Office pleaded not guilty Tuesday to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris—whom he says he meant to stun with a Taser—during an April 2 weapons sting. A judge granted Bates, 73, permission to vacation in the Bahamas, prompting Harris’s family to decry what they saw as a display of apathy toward their loss. Bates’s preliminary hearing is set for July 2, and his lawyer Clark Brewster said they look forward to presenting the facts in court. Both Bates and Sheriff Stanley Glanz have apologized, while Harris’s attorney alleges Bates was unqualified and benefited from record forgeries and favoritism; the sheriff’s office denies these claims. Over the weekend, Bates’s defense released his training documents to confirm his credentials, and two deputies involved in Harris’s arrest were reassigned amid threats.

Conor McGregor, 26, has unveiled a new tiger stomach tattoo—alongside his existing gorilla-chest artwork and the caption “if you see the tiger, it’s too late. you’re food”—as he prepares to challenge José Aldo for the UFC featherweight title on July 11 in Las Vegas; McGregor, who grabbed Aldo’s belt during a Dublin promotional stop, asserts that Aldo lacks his level of motivation in their already fractious rivalry.

Prime Minister Tony Abbott skollled a schooner of beer in about six seconds at an Australian rules football gathering—prompted by University of Technology Sydney bats coach Simon Carradous and cheered by around 50 onlookers chanting “skol” and “Tony”—a stunt decried by anti-drinking campaigners led by UTS cultural studies professor Julie Robert, who argues that it glorifies binge drinking, equates masculinity with rapid heavy consumption and undermines public health efforts in a climate increasingly wary of excessive drinking. Opposition leader Bill Shorten quipped that Abbott is finally drinking beer without lemonade, and Health Minister Sussan Ley defended his antics as harmless compared to his fitness regime, but critics insist a prime minister should model moderate drinking rather than celebrate rapid boozing.

Indiana’s governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle-exchange program in Scott County on March 26 to address a fast-growing HIV outbreak linked to intravenous opana use; two weeks in, state health officials report 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary cases (up from 106). The program has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants—about 1,400 returned—via a mobile unit building trust. Pence will decide soon on extending the program past April 25 as lawmakers—after a 54–39 House vote—debate broader exchange legislation in 23 high-hepatitis-C counties, facing Senate doubts and federal funding bans, leaving the long-term plan uncertain.

An obsessive Arsenal supporter made his girlfriend Saskia sit a 50-point, school-style exam on everything from what “FC” stands for in Arsenal FC to naming the current manager, the full starting XI in their correct positions, and even explaining in her own words why Alexis Sánchez is better than Eden Hazard; she scored 43.5 out of 50 (87 per cent), earned an A and the promise “I will not be dumping you,” then posted the test on Twitter. The quiz featured multiple-choice questions, tables to fill in, an essay section, jokey instructions (“Tottenham are scum,” “calculators may be used”) and critical margin comments on her mistakes, while online reactions ranged from hailing the boyfriend as a “legend” and Saskia as “proper gf material” to critics calling the stunt over the top.

Carlos Toro, 66, spent 27 years as an unpaid DEA informant after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s—when a confrontation with his Medellín cartel boss threatened his life—in exchange for a promised U.S. citizenship that never materialized. During his tenure he aided undercover stings worldwide and provided key information leading to the takedowns of cartel figure Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Now retired on health grounds, his final temporary visa has expired, he lacks legal status or Social Security benefits, and the DEA has refused to assist with his citizenship application. Facing imminent deportation back to Colombia—where he fears for his life—Toro lives in limbo, relying on a former handler’s $5,000 gift for medical care while he pursues a green card or passport.

A 14-year-old girl from Kosi Kalan in Uttar Pradesh, allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village when she went outside to relieve herself and urged by her family to stay silent, doused herself in kerosene and set herself alight on Tuesday; her brother extinguished the flames, she now has 70 per cent burns and is fighting for her life in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital, and the accused have been arrested. Her self-immolation amplifies a simmering national outcry over sexual violence—stoked by the recent ban on the documentary India’s Daughter about the 2012 Delhi bus rape and murder of Jyoti Singh Pandey, the ensuing protests and international outrage, and a spate of vigilante lynchings of alleged rapists in places such as Nagaland.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal says he has been dreaming of beating rivals Manchester City in Sunday’s derby at Old Trafford but will have to do so without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, whom he does not yet consider fit, as he targets all three points to climb to second or third in the table and avoid a summer Champions League qualifying fixture. He watched his team—including Wayne Rooney, David de Gea, Angel Di Maria, Radamel Falcao and Ander Herrera—train in the sunshine, warning they must control their aggression and downplaying any notion of seeking revenge for their earlier 1-0 defeat, while praising the fans’ support.

Arsenal and Liverpool supporters staged a joint protest against rising ticket prices at the Emirates Stadium by leaving seats empty for the first ten minutes of their lunchtime Barclays Premier League clash and displaying banners inside and outside the 60,000-capacity ground decrying the Premier League’s £5.14 billion TV rights deal and £64 minimum ticket cost. Organised by Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement alongside Liverpool’s Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906, fans held slogans such as “£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket” and “Football without fans is nothing,” while protest leaders Kelvin Meadows and Roy Bentham condemned “extortionate” prices, unreasonable kick-off times and late fixture changes, warned that the game risks losing a generation of working-class supporters unless prices are cut, and signaled further demonstrations after full time.

Newborn Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a rare condition affecting about 1 in 16,000 infants in which bile ducts are blocked or missing, after her skin remained jaundiced following birth. An initial Kasai procedure to restore bile flow failed, and with neither parent a suitable donor, her maternal aunt Shanell—twin sister to Star’s mother, Jade—donated part of her liver in November, saving the baby’s life. Star spent six weeks in hospital, has since made a good recovery, and will need weekly blood and liver tests plus lifelong anti-rejection medication, while her grateful parents praise Shanell’s selfless gift.

Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake teamed up against Loïc Rémy and Willian in Audi’s football challenge, with Hazard and Ake winning the first round by firing balls into a car boot 5-3, then clinching the second when they played over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus acting as a tennis net to go 6-0 up; in the final long-range shooting contest through the roof of a convertible, Rémy and Willian pulled off a surprise victory, during which Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror, much to Rémy’s stunned reaction.

Robert Dellinger, 54, a former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, pleaded guilty in February to negligent homicide and assault in the December 7, 2013, crash that killed 29-year-old Jason Timmons, his 24-year-old, eight-months-pregnant fiancée Amanda Murphy and their unborn baby after Dellinger drove his pickup across a Lebanon highway median at over 100 mph. Prosecutors say he told investigators he intended to kill himself, but at sentencing he insisted he was not suicidal; his defense attributed the crash to Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric-drug effects, Prozac and multiple sclerosis. His wife testified to his ethics and modesty, he faces 12–24 years in prison when sentencing resumes and a wrongful‐death lawsuit by Murphy’s estate, and records show he once held high‐level posts at PPG Industries, Sprint, Delphi and GE and that his family trust owns $3 million in Sunapee property.
