Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder for deliberately poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul, by loading his hospital feeding tube with lethal amounts of salt and then posting about his condition online; on sentencing she received 20 years to life instead of the 25-to-life maximum, showing no visible emotion, which prompted the boy’s father, Chris Hill, to publicly call for her to be placed in general population so she “won’t make it.” The judge acknowledged Spears’s mental illness but deemed the crime “unfathomable in its cruelty,” while prosecutors described her actions as attention-seeking and her son’s life as “short and tormented”; her attorney has vowed to appeal, arguing hospital negligence.

Australia’s influenza vaccine stocks are arriving a month late to include protection against two strains—H3N2 and B/Phuket—that caused a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the US, alongside influenza A H1N1; high-risk groups (the very young, the very old and Indigenous Australians) can access free, government-funded shots from April 20, and experts led by Dr Alan Hampson urge everyone to be vaccinated, noting the updated formula matches globally circulating strains, aims to prevent more deaths than in the northern winter and will be the same one used next season, so bookings are advised now.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln’s Springfield tomb are defending it against a National Geographic critique that likened the interior to “an office lobby” even as Illinois faces budget cuts that could eliminate the state historic preservation agency managing the site. Reduced hours and staffing from a $1.1 million funding cut led to locked doors on the 150th anniversary of Lincoln’s shooting, prompting concern from the Lincoln Monument Association. Agency spokesman Chris Wills and supporters note over $2.5 million in recent repairs—including $730,000 for interior lighting upgrades and $390,000 for vault waterproofing—and stress that the tomb, designed by Larkin Mead in 1874 and reconstructed in 1899 and 1930, remains in excellent condition. Visitors and volunteers alike dispute the negative portrayal and fear further cuts may jeopardize the historic site.

Nineties style staples—chokers, berry lips, round sunglasses and Calvin Klein tees—are back, but the revival of impractical JNCO rave jeans with 50-inch leg openings has many cringing. Femail spotlights nine retro trends best left behind: bucket hats (Christina Aguilera then, Rihanna now), camouflage print (Destiny’s Child then, Jourdan Dunn now), maximalist designer prints and double denim (Victoria Beckham, Britney Spears and Justin Timberlake then, Kylie Jenner now), Ugg boots (Paris Hilton then, Kristen Bell now), “Daisy Dukes” shorts (Jessica Simpson then, Miley Cyrus now), Juicy Couture velour tracksuits (Britney Spears then, Nicki Minaj now), coloured sunglasses (*NSYNC and Britney then, Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner now), corsets as outerwear (Victoria Beckham then, Selena Gomez now) and harem trousers (Kim Kardashian then, Elle Macpherson now).

During the week’s top trends, New Yorkers spotted four rainbows stretching across the sky after heavy rain; China cracked down on exotic dancers at funerals; Robert Downey Jr. grew visibly agitated during a Channel 4 UK interview; the #kyliejennerchallenge lip-plumping craze went viral; 102-year-old Alice Barker collaborated on a time-travel film project; a bomb-themed prom-posal was banned amid racism accusations; Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumière in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp appeared nearly unrecognizable in the Black Mass trailer; one couple announced pregnancy with a Fresh Prince of Bel-Air reference; and a military dad photobombed his son’s photo.

The Miami Open has turned into a celebration of career milestones with giant cakes presented to Andy Murray for his 500th win and, the following day, to Serena Williams for her 700th, awarded after Williams beat Germany’s Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 to reach the semi-finals. Williams’s bid for a sister showdown ended when Venus lost to Carla Suárez Navarro, leaving world No. 1 Williams to face Simona Halep—who defeated Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5—for a place in the final.

Sabeen Mahmud, who transformed her second-floor Karachi café T2F into a psychedelic haven of books, street art and progressive discussions on technology, human rights and women’s entrepreneurship, was gunned down at close range after hosting a banned debate on Balochistan’s mass disappearances; her mother, also shot, survived. Her fearless defense of free speech and secular dialogue made her a national icon for tolerance and humanism, and her murder—unclaimed by any group—ignited widespread grief and social-media tributes in Pakistan.

Mangu Ram, now 82, is one of roughly 100,000 “West Pakistan refugees” – predominantly Hindu families who fled to India’s Jammu and Kashmir during the violent 1947 Partition – yet for nearly 70 years they have been barred by pre-independence law from owning land, voting in state elections, working for the state government or attending state colleges, trapping three generations in slum poverty; successive Muslim-majority governments feared granting them rights would alter the demographic balance, but after Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s BJP joined the Kashmir coalition and pledged to normalize their status, refugees and activists like Labha Ram Gandhi are hopeful their long-denied citizenship rights may finally be restored, warning they will resort to protest if promises are broken.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is weighing a summer move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, who have reportedly bid around £4 million and intend to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem, but the 22-year-old insists he wants a team where he can play regularly and develop. His former coach Ranko Popović has praised his exceptional intelligence, pace, strength and confidence, while Chelsea manager José Mourinho, mindful of financial fair play and a recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, says he knows a little about Muto but prefers not to comment on players at other clubs, emphasizing that Chelsea only sign good players or promising prospects.

Applauding Australia’s decision to scrap its ban on overseas-based players, the passage criticizes England’s Stuart Lancaster for maintaining an outdated policy that restricts Test selection to those at domestic clubs, arguing that World Cup success depends on picking the best XV regardless of club affiliation. It highlights the improved performances of Matt Giteau, Drew Mitchell, Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon and Jonny Wilkinson after moves to French clubs, and notes that powerhouses like South Africa and Wales freely select top overseas talent such as Bryan Habana and Leigh Halfpenny. The author insists England must abandon these self-imposed constraints—driven by the RFU and Premiership rules—to field their strongest possible squad at a home World Cup, rather than leaving fans speculating on “what ifs.”

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle uses her own 240-lb body and a 2014 TED Talk recently posted online to reclaim “fat” as a neutral self-descriptor alongside “short” and “wife,” arguing that it needn’t equate to “ugly.” She highlights a 66 percent rise in size discrimination over 30 years and a study showing that girls aged 11–17 most often wish to be thinner, then counters with evidence that exposure to diverse bodies increases acceptance and preference for different shapes. Since beginning burlesque in 2012, Bustle has found performing both empowering and body-positive, overcoming early nerves about her arms by recalling a “courage reference” from her first show. Her talk has drawn nearly 38,000 views and mostly positive feedback—including letters and a teen’s story of renewed self-esteem—reinforcing her belief that body positivity is gaining ground.

Theo Walcott has spent much of the season on Arsenal’s bench—named among the substitutes in 17 of 33 Premier League games and making only late cameo appearances such as the final six minutes of the goalless draw with Chelsea—and is keen to earn a starting place in the upcoming trip to Hull, his first since March 14’s win over West Ham. Off the pitch, the 26-year-old joined Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Özil and model Olga Sherer for a photoshoot with Lanvin—Arsenal’s official tailor since 2013—and the first team will wear the same attire at Wembley for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30.

At the end of May, Prop Store will hold a no-reserve live auction at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online on May 29 featuring more than 400 original props and puppets from legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker’s Cinovation Studio, spanning over 50 productions in his 30-year career (including Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Batman & Robin, Hellboy, Mighty Joe Young, Moonwalker and Thriller). The $746,100-estimated collection includes marquee lots such as the Alien Edgar bug from Men in Black (valued at $40,000), the Mikey costume from the same film ($30,000), the Grinch costume ($8,000), a hammerhead alien ($8,000), a Two-Face mask from Batman Forever ($1,500), the Harry suit from Harry and the Hendersons ($6,000), multiple Gremlins puppets ($6,000–$8,000), the Worm Guy from Men in Black II ($10,000), Michael Jackson’s robotic transformation face from Moonwalker ($3,000) and the Hero Joe head from Mighty Joe Young ($6,000), all set to be sold to the highest bidders.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell of Talybont-on-Usk, Wales, a confident skier and snowboarder who began at three and admired Bear Grylls, died after separating from his mother on the final run of the family’s ski holiday in Flaine, French Alps, when he skied into dense woodland and fell over a 164-foot drop. Footprints and sliding marks in the snow led police to his body, and investigators led by Judge Pierre-Yves Michau and police chief Michel Ollagnon concluded he removed his skis to reach the resort he saw below. Described by family and friends as daring, outgoing and caring with a “handsome smile,” Carwyn’s mother Ceri, sister Antonia and brother Gerwyn said his loss has left a “vast void” in their hearts, while his school and the local community—where his family runs an award-winning farm shop—have rallied around them following what had been “the most happy ski holiday.”

Fifteen-year-old Laura Scurr from Whitley Bay developed anorexia nervosa at 13 after being bullied about her weight and feeling pressured by the “size zero” ideal, hiding food and surviving on as little as an apple or orange a day (around 100 calories), which caused her to collapse and spend a week on a heart monitor; after a two-year struggle she began recovery with the help of eating-disorder charities and CAMHS, regained her health and confidence, and has since reached the semi-final of Miss Teen GB to promote positive body image.

Liverpool showcased their new 2015/16 home kit—designed by New Balance under a record £300 million four-year deal—at Anfield, with Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Škrtel and Simon Mignolet unveiling the gingham strip, complete with all-white branding and a memorial flame/number 96 tribute to Hillsborough. Fans packed the Centenary Stand to chant “hold nothing back,” urging Sterling—fresh from rejecting a £100,000-a-week offer and linked with Arsenal—to commit his future to the Reds. Club legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush joined the launch alongside a Q&A, during which players praised the supporters’ impact as Liverpool gear up for an FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley.

University of Manchester researchers led by Dr Sarah Bridle have produced the first high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the night sky (about 150 times the full moon) by measuring distortions in 130 million galaxy images via gravitational lensing with the 570-megapixel Dark Energy Camera on the 4 m Blanco telescope at CTIO. Released at the American Physical Society meeting, the map reveals red clumps and blue voids of a substance thought to make up at least 80% of all matter, showing large filaments where galaxies cluster and empty cosmic voids. As part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey—which will map 12.5% of the sky by 2018—this work will build a 3D picture of dark matter and dark energy, enabling studies of galaxy formation and the nature of cosmic acceleration.

Manchester United has formally approached PSV Eindhoven for 21-year-old Netherlands international winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal—who worked with him at last summer’s World Cup—keen to make him one of his first signings. PSV’s technical director Marcel Brands confirmed contact from United, Paris Saint-Germain and another major European club, noting offers exceed last summer’s £15 million bid. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie games to help PSV win their first league title in seven years, showcasing pace, dribbling and explosive long-range shooting. Born in Moordrecht, he joined PSV at age 12, has made over 100 senior appearances, debuted for the national team in 2013 and scored at the 2014 World Cup.

Chelsea’s youngsters ran out 3-1 winners at Manchester City’s Academy Stadium in the first leg of the Youth Cup final, racing into a 2-0 first-half lead thanks to Tammy Abraham’s fierce volleys before Isaac Buckley-Ricketts pulled one back for City and Dominic Solanke applied a late gloss. Chelsea’s side, anchored by keeper Bradley Collins and a backline of Fikayo Tomori, Jake Clarke-Salter, Ola Aina and Jay DaSilva, controlled midfield under captain Charlie Colkett and stifled City’s spirited efforts—including a commanding shift by defender-captain Tosin Adarabioyo—but punished their opponents’ wasted chances with clinical finishing.

Florida Senator Marco Rubio, who recently announced his presidential bid and secured over $51 million in early donor commitments, told CBS’s Face the Nation that while he believes sexual orientation is innate and would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer out of love and respect, he does not view same-sex marriage as a constitutional right and maintains that the definition of marriage—between one man and one woman—should be set through state legislatures rather than courts; he similarly said that although his Catholic faith teaches that divorce is wrong, he would continue to love someone who had divorced.

Spanish 27-year-old Pablo Mandado and 31-year-old Latvian Ilze Zebolde quit their Manchester restaurant jobs to cycle the globe with no fixed agenda, living on under three euros apiece per day by camping (161 nights), couchsurfing (66 nights) and using WarmShowers (44 nights). In 356 days they’ve pedaled nearly 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) across 16 countries—starting in London, down France’s coasts, through Spain and Portugal, then northeast through Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece into Turkey, and on to Georgia and Armenia—subsisting on staples like pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk and seasonal produce, plus occasional invitations, wild foraging and dumpster dives. They plan to press on into Asia, cross the Pacific and cycle the length of the Americas, intending to stay on the road indefinitely.

A Texas couple who wed in 2012 discovered months later that their rented photo booth prints bore the racist caption “poor n***** party,” and after hiring attorney Cathy Hale, they sued Premiere Photos owner James Evans under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract; Evans has denied any link to the offensive caption, refused to apologize—telling the couple to “sue” him—and claimed no evidence of harm at their 103-guest reception at the Bell Tower in northwest Houston, while the couple insists they simply want an apology, with mediation set to precede a July trial.

England and Harlequins full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious, stage-by-stage approach to his return from concussion after withdrawing from Quins’ Premiership match at Wembley, remaining unsure when he will play again. Knocked out in England’s win over Italy and suffering a post-France game headache, Brown – mindful of the season-ending advice given to Northampton’s George North and Johnny Sexton’s 12-week lay-off – is undergoing controlled tests, including monitored bike sessions and neurosurgical checks, to avoid long-term damage. Crediting World Rugby’s online concussion modules for teaching him to recognise symptoms, he pulled out of a Six Nations clash with Ireland and now urges teammates to be equally honest, comments he made while launching Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” Rugby World Cup 2032 campaign.

Research cited by Cambridge statistician David Spiegelhalter in his book Sex by Numbers shows that the average heterosexual British couple now has sex three times a month—a drop from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. He and British National Survey researcher Catherine Mercer suggest this decline stems largely from smartphones and the internet eroding the boundaries between work, home and leisure, leaving people constantly checking emails, juggling competing demands and losing the quiet, focused time once reserved for intimacy. They also note that more people living alone may play a role, but point to ever-busier, hyperconnected lives as the primary factor pushing sex down couples’ priority lists.

Tibetan Mastiffs, massive dogs weighing up to 80 kg once prized in China as status symbols—with puppies selling for as much as £1.2 million—have in the past year fallen out of favour amid the government’s anti-corruption drive that ended lavish gift-giving to officials, city bans on dogs over 50 kg, rampant urbanisation and overbreeding that degraded the breed. Animal-welfare groups recently rescued twenty mastiffs bound for slaughterhouses, where their meat feeds cheap hotpots and their skins become leather goods, with many found dead, injured, unfed and crammed into cages. Stolen street dogs and “imperfect” puppies are also trafficked to abattoirs, reflecting a broader collapse of China’s once-booming mastiff market.

A poll of 600 women in the Paris region found that every respondent had experienced sexual harassment on public transport—ranging from insults, whistling and insistent flirting to unwanted touching, sexual assault and rape—with half the women facing their first incident before age 18. Six in ten women admit fear of using buses and trains, compared with three in ten men, and many have changed their routes, schedules, modes of transport, attitudes or clothing to avoid intimidation. The High Council for Gender Equality’s report, handed to the French women’s rights ministry, warns that largely unreported abuse restricts women’s freedom and effectively excludes them from public space. Council president Pascale Boisard and member Ernestine Ronai have called for a campaign to curb sexist or threatening behavior, stressing that such acts are criminally punishable and that women, bystanders and perpetrators must recognize that this treatment is neither normal nor acceptable.

Direct Line’s #everydayfix design makeathon asked London’s Makerversity teams to solve the top ten “everyday emergencies” identified by a 2,000-person survey—led by sleeplessness (46%), lost keys (37%), traffic delays (35%), lost documents (33%), parking shortages (32%), printer failures (31%), dead phone batteries (31%), missing toilet roll (30%), machine customer service (26%) and forgotten bank cards (25%)—and produced three prototypes: Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to ensure uninterrupted sleep; the Forget Me Lock, which swivels red or green on your key to confirm door lock status remotely; and Nipper, a pocket-size phone charger powered by any household battery. The public votes for their favorite by retweeting its pitch with #everydayfix through April 26, and the winning concept will be funded on Kickstarter for full development.

Northumbria’s police and crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under Ministry of Justice investigation after allocating more than £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a victims’ charity she co-directs with Chief Constable Sue Sim, prompting critics like Labour’s Keith Vaz to call it a conflict of interest and “a soap opera.” Baird maintains she followed all MOJ procedures after victim services funding was devolved to PCCs from April 1, while the MOJ confirms it can probe any conflicts and withdraw funding if necessary. Sim—who faced previous bullying allegations—will retire in June, and the charity was launched to replace Victim Support after its referral numbers plunged.

In late March 2014 in Mayfair, Northeast Philadelphia, 21-year-old Corry “Corey” Campbell—who believed his tenant, 53-year-old Greg Valecce, had injured his cat Pebbles and stolen money and drugs—along with girlfriend Sandra Ng (19) and friend Carl Halin (18) held Valecce in a basement torture chamber for about 42 hours, during which they punched, slapped and spat on him, tied him to a chair and forcibly tattooed him with “RIP Pebbles,” swastikas, racial slurs and sexualized imagery; Valecce escaped on April 1 and police found a tattoo gun, needles, ink, prescription drugs, marijuana and his stolen debit card. All three pleaded guilty to aggravated assault, conspiracy and false imprisonment, with Campbell and Halin each sentenced to 20 years and Ng to 23 months in state prison, while two other defendants, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, await sentencing and trial.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven and Dutch international Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to reunite with him after his part in the Netherlands’ 2014 World Cup. PSV technical director Marcel Brands confirmed that United, Paris Saint-Germain and another major club are in talks, following Tottenham’s rejected £15 million bid last summer. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 Eredivisie games this season to lead PSV to their first title since 2008, and his journey from grassroots side VV Moordrecht through Sparta Rotterdam to over 100 PSV appearances underlines his development. Renowned for his pace, dribbling, shooting and explosive right foot, he has been compared to Arjen Robben and even a young Cristiano Ronaldo, though he can sometimes over-elaborate with the ball. Capped since 2013, Depay scored in the World Cup win over Australia and earned a nomination for the tournament’s Best Young Player.

Chelsea’s Under-18s took a 3-1 first-leg lead in the Youth Cup final at Manchester’s Academy Stadium, with Tammy Abraham’s first-half brace and a late Dominic Solanke strike sealing victory after Isaac Buckley-Ricketts had briefly levelled; Chelsea’s midfield was dominated by captain Charlie Colkett, their defence marshalled efficiently by Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter with full-backs Ola Aina and Jay Dasilva providing width, while City’s backline led by Tosin Adarabioyo and Cameron Humphreys-Grant showed promise but goalkeeper Kjetil Haug and forwards such as Aaron Nemane and Bersant Celina spurned chances in an ultimately insufficient effort.

Marco Rubio, who recently launched his presidential bid, argues that sexual orientation is innate but that marriage—defined as a union between one man and one woman—should be determined by state legislatures rather than the courts, and not enshrined as a constitutional right; he has nevertheless said he would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer and respects loved ones’ choices, just as he would continue loving someone who divorced, reflecting his Catholic faith’s opposition to divorce but personal refusal to ostracize individuals.

Spanish 27-year-old Pablo Mandado and 31-year-old Latvian Ilze Zebolde quit their Manchester restaurant jobs to pursue an open-ended dream of “discovering different parts of this planet a pedal at a time,” and in 356 days they’ve cycled nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries on less than €3 each per day.  By camping under the stars for 161 nights and relying on Couchsurfing (66 nights) and Warmshowers (44 nights), they avoid transport costs entirely and spend only €2.74 per person daily on food, subsisting on pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce, occasional free meals, wild fruits and even dumpster finds.  Starting in London, they’ve ridden through France, Spain, Portugal, northern Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece and Turkey into Georgia and Armenia, and they plan to continue into Asia, cross the Pacific and cycle the length of the Americas over the coming years.

Mike Brown, the England and Harlequins full-back, is taking a cautious, stage-by-stage approach to recover from his latest concussion, having pulled out of Harlequins’ Premiership match after suffering headaches following England’s win over France. Unsure when he’ll return, Brown is determined not to rush back and risk an extended layoff like Northampton’s George North, who has been advised to end his season after four concussions, or Ireland’s Johnny Sexton, who was stood down for 12 weeks. Brown credits World Rugby’s online concussion modules with helping him recognise symptoms and make the tough call to miss England’s Ireland game, and he now urges honesty about symptoms among teammates. He made these remarks at the launch of Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” Rugby World Cup 2027 campaign, which highlights grassroots rugby.

Smartphone and internet use has been blamed for a decline in how often British heterosexual couples have sex, now averaging three times per month compared with four in 2000 and five in 1990; Cambridge statistician David Spiegelhalter argues in his book Sex by Numbers that constant email checking and improved technological connectivity have blurred boundaries between work and home, squeezed private time and pushed sex down the priority list, a view echoed by researcher Catherine Mercer, who links late-night emails and competing demands to partners’ inability to focus on each other.

Tibetan mastiffs, once prized status symbols in China and capable of weighing up to 80 kg—with puppies fetching record prices of £1.2 million—have plummeted in value amid the government’s anti-corruption drive that ended lavish gift-giving to officials, city bans on dogs over 50 kg, rapid urbanisation unsuited to their size and profit-driven overbreeding. As demand collapsed, many are now rounded up by gangs or offloaded by breeders to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather; a recent rescue found 20 cramped, starved or dead mastiffs en route to slaughter, and animal-welfare groups fear hundreds more suffer similar fates.

Direct Line’s #everydayfix campaign surveyed 2,000 people to rank their top daily emergencies—led by sleeplessness (46 %), lost keys (37 %), traffic delays (35 %), missing documents (33 %), parking woes (32 %), printer failures (31 %), dead phone batteries (31 %), lack of toilet roll (30 %), machine-operated customer service (26 %) and forgetting bank cards (25 %)—and asked Makerversity designers to prototype solutions. The three finalists are “Snooze,” an alarm clock that mutes phone notifications for uninterrupted sleep; the “Forget Me Lock,” a key-mounted swivel indicator showing green when unlocked and red when locked; and “Nipper,” a pocket-sized charger powered by any household battery. Twitter users vote by retweeting with #everydayfix to select which gadget will be Kickstarter-funded and developed, while other inventive non-shortlisted ideas included a bone-conduction navigation helmet, a sensor-based parking pin and a message-relay app for dead phones.
The 2009 convention featured over 512 guests and musical performers, among them Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.

The 2009 convention featured over 6,000 guests and musical performers, including notable actors Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.

As of 12 March, among countries with at least one million residents, Italy recorded the highest per capita rate of confirmed COVID-19 cases—206.1 per million, 3.6 times China’s rate—and ranked second worldwide in both total cases and deaths, behind China.

Italy leads nations of over one million people with 206.1 confirmed COVID-19 cases per million—the highest per-capita rate worldwide—surpassing all of mainland China outside Hubei province, and ranks second only to mainland China in both total confirmed cases and deaths.

By 19 March, COVID-19 had spread to over 170 countries and territories with more than 237,000 confirmed cases, resulting in over 9,900 deaths and 86,000 recoveries, and on 13 March the WHO declared Europe the new epicentre of the pandemic.

By 20 March, COVID-19 had spread to over 170 countries and territories, with more than 241,000 confirmed cases, over 9,900 deaths and about 87,000 recoveries, and on 13 March the WHO designated Europe as the new epicentre of the pandemic.
